story:
Our Story

Imuhira International is a growing Non profit organization founded by Justin Semahoro Kimenyerwa, Jules Gikundiro and Dan Rugomba. These three are individuals from the Banyamulenge community, a marginalized group of people from the Eastern part of Congo. We are counting it as Grace that we are not victims of the 13 year war that has struck our homeland. Today we celebrate the fact that we are survivors who have received a second chance to life. With the ongoing unrest and instability in our country Congo most of our Banyamulenge people are dispersed out in the diaspora and neighboring countries. Safety and peace is the best gift offered in the refuge countries where they have ended up. 

There is also one remaining concern, one which threatens the future of our community's identity. Our culture is quickly fading away. if something is not done, if the issue is not addressed with urgency, the Banyamulenge may end up loosing their identity. That's why we have set our cause on stage to campaigning for the preservation of our dying culture.

The Impact

A sustainable programme of promoting awareness of our beautiful culture. This will hopefully stir up the desire in our children, separated from their home in Africa, to know their history and encourage them at one point to participate in the construction of the countries future. 


It will remind the Banyamulenge people of their roots, including their identity, homeland history,


It will be a most unique opportunity for the international community to have a 1st time opportunity

to view on screen the cultural heritage of the Banyamulenge people which has been unknown for centuries.


What We Need & What You Get

We have set a time frame to travel to four different states within the US by the end of June 2011 to educate the younger generation on the importance of practising and identifying with the Banyamulenge culture.  We plan to use song, dance, video, and personal testimonials to tell the story of the Banyamulenge and help preserve their culture.The majority of the funds will be used for travel and accommodation.

In addition, we are hoping to procure a prosumer video camera that will be sent to five different countries in Africa: Congo, Rwanda, Burundi, Uganda and Kenya

This camera will be used to document, celebrate, preserve the culture, and bring unity to Banyamulenge people separated due to war in their home land. The footage will highlight varied aspects of their culture and will include:

How the Banyamulenge lived before war broke out in their villages

  • What life looks like for a particular family
  • Various community gatherings
  • Cultural songs and dances (dances for their cattle, families, religion, etc.)
  • General community life, interpersonal relationships, beliefs, and norms

How the Banyamulenge are living now, in foreign lands to which they have had to flee

  • How the Banyamulenge are received in various countries
  • How the Banyamulenge are relating to each other and their current communities

In helping us to raise our goal, you will he helping to aid people who have been persecuted and denied their basic human rights for over 13 years. As an appreciation of your help, those who donate will receive various perks such as: thank you cards and letters from our organization, pictures from home, copies of a special DVD documenting Banyamulenge culture, and other special items.

Other Ways You Can Help

Imuhira international has a goal to reach and we hope to share our cultural richness with every individual across the globe. There is a limited time frame to raise $8,000 that can accommodate the requirements to make this cause a success. Please share this blog with families, friends and relatives, at every opportunity you get. For it can't happen without the generosity of your support.


Every donation, no matter how small, will be used to help further our cause and go towards the purchase and shipping of cameras to Africa and the beginning of our travel budget for our outreach and awareness trips throughout the US. Help us to preserve our culture and give a voice to the voiceless. 


For more information visit: http://www.imuhira.com/ and view this informational clip from a recent documentary featuring one of our founders: http://www.vimeo.com/3180086

story:
OUR STORY

The Share Your Voice Foundation's mission is simple.  We strongly believe in the transformative power of the Arts to change lives. We're dedicated to helping young people (primarily disadvantaged and at-risk teens in rural areas ages 13-17) through powerful collaborative experiences such as the Empowerment through Performance (ETP) Workshop program. 

Thank you for watching our video (feel free to check out more media in the gallery page of this campaign). The inaugural workshop was held in 2007 and it's been a remarkable journey thus far. We're so proud to still be going strong - changing the lives of a special group of young people each year, one summer at a time. 

SYVF serves these teens regardless of race, religion, creed, sex or socio-economic status.  We are committed to making a difference through the tremendous power of the Arts by helping them find and share their voice to promote positive difference.

We ask for your support in making this vision come true in 2012.  It will not happen without your contribution.

The workshop is being held July 16-20 with the final performance night for the community, 'Night at the Landing' being held at beautiful Stillwater Landing, 15 miles from Whitefish in Northwest Montana on Saturday, July 21.

Funds raised on IndieGoGo ensure we will be able run the 2012 workshop and also contribute to recording songs the participants write with a singer-songwriter during the workshop. 

SYVF is a qualified 501(c)3 nonprofit association so all donations are tax-deductible.

 

THE IMPACT

We're very proud and excited that this will be our 6th year of providing the workshop to young people. This is due to the commitment and generosity of individuals, local organizations, returning graduates, talented guest educators, assistants and volunteers in Montana.

SYVF has already helped over 100 young participants develop higher self-esteem, contribute to their community and become the best they can be. They have graduated from high school, gone on to be awarded college scholarships to Princeton, degrees at MSU, joined and performed in other community theatre groups, and generally succeed living their lives with a greater sense of happiness and solid self-concept. Many choose to return the following year as volunteers to champion the next group of participants.

Through the unique mesh of the creative fields of writing, performance, music and film, participants from SYVF's summer outreach program are encouraged to unleash their creativity in a safe environment while improving self-esteem and developing strong, effective communication skills. They are guided to discover their own innate talents, cultivate a sense of pride and appreciate the importance of collaborating with others.

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

To run the workshop a lot of careful preparation, team effort, commitment, skilled guest educators, dedicated volunteers and local support is required. It is made possible entirely through community and individual philanthropy. 

Your generous contribution to this IndieGogo campaign will enable us to ensure that each participant is given a full scholarship to attend the program and enjoy the benefits of a safe venue, access to talented guest educators, adequate supplies, qualified care and meals during the workshop plus help make the experience of recording a music track in a professional recording studio a reality. Watch the clip from a previous year for the beautiful song, Love Is The Bridge To Peace.

Our donors are offered a number of benefits for sponsorship, from VIP access to the gala event night, recognition in media and photo opportunities with the graduates. Read the perks and get involved!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!  You can make a huge difference by involving others.  Please tell all your friends and family about our IndieGoGo campaign and share the donation page link on facebook, google, twitter and via email. This really helps us get the word out - the more hits - the higher our profile.

BECOME A VOLUNTEER!  If you are located in the Flathead Valley in Northwest Montana, consider volunteering during the 5-day workshop, or helping out on the final performance night. We need all the help we can get to make the experience the best it can be for our young participants and it's a great way to meet other creative, service-minded folk and members of the community. Contact us via our website.

DONATE ITEMS!  If you live elsewhere but have access to 'goods and services' or wish to donate in this way, please consider donating to the 2012 workshop.

For participants involved in the workshop we need:  25 CARRY BAGS, 25 WATER BOTTLES, 25 PENS, 25, BINDERS, 100 PLASTIC SLEEVES, 25 MARKERS, 25 HIGHLIGHTER PENS, 25 NOTEBOOKS & BLANK CDS/DVDs.

Thanks for any help and donations you can make ~ Time to Shine!

Share Your Voice Foundation:  Helping Teens Empower Themselves Through The Arts

story:
Our Story

“[sic] Seems to really connect with kids. Has been practicing martial arts for several years and was teaching karate to "at risk" kids out of his garage until the classes became too large for his limited space. Not saying he is against money but believe his true aim is to mentor kids into becoming responsible adults. Has a great relationship with hands-on parents and prefers family participation where possible.”  --Michael Stokes, Sunnyvale CA

Collette Martial Arts (CMA) is a community outreach program that focuses on building a strong foundation of the core principles in our members.  We use martial arts to strengthen the individual by instilling a sense of Respect, Self-Confidence, Courage, Self-Control, Integrity, Discipline, and Humility.

By participating in our classes, students learn to work both individually, and as a team.  Our students are able to take these skills into other aspects of their lives, and apply them to work, school, and relationships.

CMA is structured as a legal, for-profit business entity; however, it is run as you would a non-profit organization.  This allows us more flexibility to take support from any place we find it, and to make decisions based on what is best for the student base, rather than what is best for the bottom line.  To date, this project was funded entirely from our own pockets; we just really believe that this is something that is needed in our community.  By functioning this way, we are able to provide our students with a commercial setting and allowing our students to keep their dignity, rather than feeling as though they were being given a hand-out.


This project is to allow us to continue to go and grow for the next 12 months, and to become completely self-sustaining.

The Impact

Funding from crowdsourcing will help us bring CMA to hundreds of students in the San Francisco Bay Area.  It will also help us to provide uniforms, and require gear to our students, and allow them to participate in the fantastic Martial Arts Seminars and Tournaments in the Bay Area.

Our staff and supporting parents are genuinely troubled by the recent global wave of horrific bullying incidents resulting in expulsions from school, physical and verbal abuse, and in some cases, suicide.

These incidents are prime examples of what our programs are designed to prevent.  The idea is to help bring out the positive in each student; by not only bringing kids in off the street to do something more productive physically, but also mentoring them on how to they can become a positive influence on future generations.  We are focused on building a better future, one kid at a time.

What We Need & What You Get

To keep this project going and growing, we need a total of 15,000.00.  What we are asking for is 8,000.00, and the rest is funded by family and friends.  To date, my wife and I have put in over 10,000.00 to get the project launched. We are working very hard to not just keep the project going, but to spread the word about the project.  In the end, our goal is not to be known as Just Another Karate School, but to be known as the program that turned out some of the bay areas finest, most upstanding, and unique individuals.  Help us to get the program off the ground.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please - please - spread the word about our project!  The more people that know about it, the more at-risk and underprivileged people we can help.

story:
~ The  Vision ~ 

The Positive Mom Foundation is a non-profit organization passionately committed to  strengthening families and communities worldwide.

~ The Mission ~ 

To provide accessible, comprehensive character development education for parents, youth and children to partner in creating a WHOLE family.


~ The Resources ~

The Positive Mom Foundation programs, tools and resources include:

 Family Kit: The 3M's Of A W.H.O.L.E. Family ©

 Program: You,Family,Community,The World©

 Workshop: Leadership in Competence and Character©

Book/Manual :   "A W.H.O.L.E. Family : 52 Principles For Success At Home"©

Activities :  W.H.O.L.E. Family Awards©  Contests [art, writing, music]

...and much more!


~ What You Can Do To Help ~


Simply contribute what you can using your credit card.  Every little bit helps! Even $1 if that's all you can afford.

You can blog about it, update your status, tweet about it or send the link by IM or 

E-mail...anything you can do to spread the word.

The campaign ends on my birthday (December 16th) so I consider your contribution an early birthday present to me! Thank you! 

 I also have a special perks to those who contribute, so make sure you claim them! 


~ What You'll Help Me Achieve ~

The Positive Mom Foundation offers training programs designed and implemented to inspire and enable moms to teach and model fundamental principles that develop character in their children. 


Moms learn strategies for success at home through creating intentional partnerships with their spouse, community or support system. 


By reaching the campaign goal, your contribution will specifically cover government fees, technology equipment, training materials, and some promotional tools to launch the programs.  You will support my focus is to directly improve the lives of children and youth by celebrating and nurturing their talents, enhancing their skills and building their character. You will inspire WHOLE families!


In deep gratitude and appreciation,

story:
Short Summary

I am a middle school music teacher at Norwood School in Bethesda, MD with an incredible passion for African music.  My life was forever changed by a choir tour I took to South Africa in 2009.  

I will travel to Kibera, Kenya this summer for four weeks.  The first two weeks I will be chaperoning sixteen high school students who will be volunteering at the Red Rose School, a subsidiary organization of the Children of Kibera Foundation.
 
While I have recieved a small grant through Norwood School to make this journey, I still need some additional funds to support the fourth week of my trip-- when I will take classes in Kenyan drumming and folk song and lead professional development with local teachers in Kibera.

What I Need & What You Get

Important Note: In contributing to this campaign, you are making a donation to me and not a tax-deductible donation to the Children of Kibera Foundation.  The total cost of my trip is $7,500.  After fundring from the Children of Kibera Foundation and Norwood School, I will be responsible for ~$2,000 myself.  This will cover:
  • Food and housing in Nairobi for the fourth week of the trip.
  • Coursework at Bomas of Kenya, where I will do my training.
  • Transportation within Nairobi.
  • The purchase of instruments to bring back to the U.S (including instruments for use at Norwood School).

Any extra funds raised will be donated to the Red Rose School. 

The Impact

Kibera is aproximately the size of Central Park and has somewhere between 200,000 and one million residents.  The police do not patrol Kibera.  Children in the slum grow up incredibly poor. Here is a snippet from the Wikipedia article on Kibera: "Kibera is heavily polluted by human refuse, garbage, soot, dust, and other wastes. The slum is contaminated with human and animal feces, due to the open sewage system and the frequent use of "flying toilets". The lack of sanitation combined with poor nutrition among residents accounts for many illnesses and diseases." 
 
Children in Kibera deserve a good education, including training in music and the arts. I have the opportunity to start the first-ever Red Rose Choir.  I will bring American folk music (including music of the Civil Rights Era) to Red Rose and have the students teach me Kenyan folk music.  If I can bring beauty into the lives of even a few of these students, my trip will be a success.  No doubt I will learn far more from the students than they will learn from me.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please spread the word about this campaign and about the Children of Kibera Foundation.  They're doing phenomenal work!
http://childrenofkibera.org/

story:
Hi, I am Laura Hope-Gill, founder of Asheville Wordfest. The video above features Quincy Troupe, who read his poetry at Wordfest 2010. I figured it's best to let the fest speak for itself and hope I'm right!
 
I started this poetry festival in Asheville, NC, six years ago with the help of about fifteen other poets. Our vision was manifold:

Create a festival that:

  • reflects the true diversity of Western North Carolina
  • draws on Cherokee history
  • holds the inspiration of Black Mountain College
  • activates both the ancient power of language and the modern tools of tech
  • draws a multicultural audience by featuring a multicultural line up of poets

Your donation will help me add:

  • children and youth events
  • poets from the world
  • classes and workshops
  • residencies
  • more events
  • better pay for poets!
  • make Wordfest sustainabie
  • expand into more genres, more conversations!

I have since childhood found poetry to be a unifying field. It connects things. This is why I believe Western North Carolina needs a strong poetry festival. We need non-divisive spaces.

I grew up in Canada, England, and in the United States. I've traveled and lived in Australia and China.

Global connection is vital to this festival and to me.

I'm seeking to raise money to offset costs of producing this festival. It is free to everything, but it is not free to produce.

Your donation promotes cultural understanding and community.

Your donation pays for hotel, meals, airfare, and poets' stipends.

Your donation pays for promotion so we can reach deeply into communities.

All Wordfest readings are made available on the website for free access in schools and by anyone who needs to hear a human voice.

Your donation helps me dream up more ways Wordfest can grow.

 

Sincerely,

Laura
story_txt:
Hi, I am Laura Hope-Gill, founder of Asheville Wordfest. The video above features Quincy Troupe, who read his poetry at Wordfest 2010. I figured it's best to let the fest speak for itself and hope I'm right!
 
I started this poetry festival in Asheville, NC, six years ago with the help of about fifteen other poets. Our vision was manifold:

Create a festival that:

reflects the true diversity of Western North Carolina
draws on Cherokee history
holds the inspiration of Black Mountain College
activates both the ancient power of language and the modern tools of tech
draws a multicultural audience by featuring a multicultural line up of poets

Your donation will help me add:

children and youth events
poets from the world
classes and workshops
residencies
more events
better pay for poets!
make Wordfest sustainabie 
expand into more genres, more conversations!

I have since childhood found poetry to be a unifying field. It connects things. This is why I believe Western North Carolina needs a strong poetry festival. We need non-divisive spaces. 
I grew up in Canada, England, and in the United States. I've traveled and lived in Australia and China.
Global connection is vital to this festival and to me.
I'm seeking to raise money to offset costs of producing this festival. It is free to everything, but it is not free to produce.
Your donation promotes cultural understanding and community.
Your donation pays for hotel, meals, airfare, and poets' stipends.
Your donation pays for promotion so we can reach deeply into communities.
All Wordfest readings are made available on the website for free access in schools and by anyone who needs to hear a human voice.
Your donation helps me dream up more ways Wordfest can grow.
 
Sincerely,
Laura

story:
The Longest 90 Seconds in History

well it sure felt that way. can you imagine how challenging it is to get a 12 year old boy to stay focused on a project this big! not easy. alot of blood, sweat and tears...well maybe just tears. but he did.

syama (shama) shot this video with his Nintendo 3DS game system.

stop motion

claymation

2 months to build the set out of whatever he could find and shot in one take.

You're Thinking - "That's Awesome"

-and you're right, but what's even more impressive, is that syama knows what he wants, has known for sometime, and somehow this school has come into his life. see, when we first found Arthur Morgan School, i couldnt believe it was possible AND then he interviewed AND then they loved him (you would too).

this school is on over 100 acres, just north of asheville, nc. they have classes like any normal school, but they learn basic skills like growing their own food, preserving the harvest, cooking, woodworking.

i couldn't have dreamed for a more perfect space for him.

So Now What?

as parents we know that we will raise our children, they will leave home and make their magic in the world. i never imagined mine would be ready so soon. of course ill miss him, but this is what we are here for, to empower their inate wisdom.

the thing is, this is more than a boy going to a fantastic school. this is about us believing that we can raise our children to be aware and to trust and to be courageous and to love life. Arthur Morgan School only accepts 28 kids.

think about that........and he can be one of them.

the school costs 26,000$ per year, i know, right? but of course it does, 'cause it's amazing.

we received a scholorship of 8,000$ so now we need to raise the rest,

we need 18,000 more.

and we really need your help.

ALL OF YOU!

Tell your friends, family, lover, those people you work with,

hell even your boss

donate,

get some fun stuff and sit back.

we see so many stories floating around that restore our faith in humanity,

this is your chance to be a part of one of those stories!

story:
In brief:

My name is Wanja Ngure. I am a Kenyan human rights activist and VSO volunteer currently working with an NGO in Malawi called Center for the Development of People (CEDEP). I have lived in Malawi for over three years, and worked tirelessly as an advocate for the rights of sex workers, vulnerable children, and LGBTQI individuals. My work at CEDEP has comprised grant writing, overseeing monitoring and evaluation of ongoing projects, advocacy, and implementing trainings and workshops. In this capacity, I have grown especially passionate about working with sexual minority populations who often face severe discrimination and violence in many African countries. At CEDEP, I have been a key catalyst in expanding programming for LGBTQI individuals living in Malawi. For example, I founded a support group for lesbian and trans* identified individuals in Lilongwe, providing them with a safe space for sharing challenges, learning safe sexual practices, and coming to terms with their sexual identities. I am proud to be part of the team that has pioneered the fight for the rights of sexual minorities in Malawi.

It is now time for the next phase of my career as a lifelong activist. In September 2013, I will commence a year-long course of study at Kingston University outside London. This Masters of Human Rights program will provide me with the technical and epistemological tools needed to continue my advocacy and programming work. Specifically, I look forward to being exposed to international perspectives on sexual minorities and other pressing human rights issues I’ve become familiar with in Malawi and forging networks with other organizations and individuals working in Africa that will prove instrumental in the more global struggle to protect the rights of sexual minorities. After completing my course of study at Kingston, I plan to return to sub-Saharan Africa to continue my advocacy work focusing on sexual minority populations living in homophobic contexts.

Although the cost of completing the Masters of Human Rights degree is almost prohibitive for me, my passion drives me to overcome this challenge. I have been lucky enough to be awarded a partial scholarship to attend Kingston. I have also managed to save some funds from my small stipend as a VSO volunteer in Malawi. I plan to work part time while completing my degree at Kingston. Unfortunately, my family’s financial situation will not permit them to provide me with support. I come from a small farming village in central Kenya and I am one of six children. My dad passed away last year and my mother is a peasant farmer.  

Here, I am requesting your financial support to help me cover accommodation costs while completing my degree at Kingston. Though I plan to live as cheaply as possible, my part time work will not fully cover my housing costs and partial tuition fee. In this regard, I would most appreciate even the smallest increments of financial support. Your support will enable me to devote my time to my academic work while in the UK, and ensure that I return to Africa most equipped to lead the struggle for LGBTQI and other minority populations.  

Thanks so much for your consideration. Please do contact me if you have any questions about my plans, would like references from my work or academic colleagues, or would like further information.

Asante sana.

Wanja Ngure

Email: wanjangure@gmail.com

story:
Campaign Update:

Michelle has made the decision to forego the NARM Study Retreat.  Therefore, she only needs $700 for the NARM Test, plus $300 for the Self Study Program she has chosen instead. Thank you for your donation & for helping Michelle meet her goals.

Michelle is graduating!

It has taken her 7 years to complete her degree requirements through the National College of Midwifery, which includes:

  • 1350 hours of clinical experience.
  • 833 hours academic (classes, homework, reading, and testing).
  • NCM requires Michelle to pass the NARM exam to earn her degree.

Michelle has been working almost full time while in school, attending prenatals, births, and attending extra training programs. She is now ready to step out into the world as a midwife.

She needs to Apply for the NARM Exam, and for the NARM Study Retreat: 

  • NARM Requires $700 in cashiers check or money order to be sent in when the NARM application is sent- MUST BE POSTMARKED BY JUNE 10, 2013.
  • The self-study program Michelle has chosen costs $300.
  • She will take her NARM exam on August 21, 2013!

The World Needs Midwives

Once Michelle passes the NARM exam, she will be a Certified Professional Midwife (CPM), and will be considered qualified to serve families all over the world!

  • The World Health Organization says we need for 300,000 midwives NOW!
  • Midwives save lives of mothers and babies and protect the spirit of birth.
  • Your contribution will directly make an impact in Michelle’s life and the lives of all the families who she will serve once she graduates.

Midwives Help Babies Out!

  • Please spread the word to help Michelle meet her goal.
  • Please send your prayers to midwives all over the world.

Thank you and many, many blessings!

story:
Who We Are

We are a group of women based in the Central Valley of California. 

Some of us choose to legally carry a gun everyday, 

some of us just want to learn how to use our husband's gun for those "just in case" home protection instances,

some of us still have never touched a gun and are taking part in classes and lessons and learning to feel more comfortable around firearms. 

Some of us hunt with rifles and shotguns to put food on our tables and live off our California land. 

ALL of us live safely and legally with firearms. We are passionate about educating the public and getting people in classes and safety courses offered by their local gun shops.


  • We are Women and Moms, Husbands and Fathers, Grandparents and children.
  • Law-abiding, gun owning, American Citizens.
  • Friends, neighbors, business partners
  • We all have the right to bear arms, to protect our children, to stop a criminal. 


The answer is to band together and learn how to use firearms accurately and efficiently. To Learn how to store them safe, learn how to take control of your life and not be victim. To learn how to be ready for the worst situations. 

"It is better to have a gun and not need it, than to need one and not have it."


What We Need 

Your donation money goes toward:

  • funding Handgun safety classes for women 
  • Helping women get ccw training and gun handling courses.
  • Adolescent hunter safety classes and hunting opportunities. 
  • Classes and courses promoting gun safety

We need local gun shops and instructors that want to team up with us and offer your classes with our program. 


The Impact

Ignorance is now a choice. Education is a gift. 

  • Women are learning they have options other than to be a victim, and don't have to live in fear.
  • Protective Husband's are feeling at ease while at work knowing their wife is trained with their gun and she is capable of protecting herself.
  • Families are coming together and embracing their right to bear arms. They are learning together how to handle guns, including the littlest children who are taught to NEVER TOUCH A GUN, and TELL AN ADULT if they find one. We can lock up our guns in our homes but you still need a back up plan with children these days. They need to be taught they are not toys. 
  • Elderly people are able to have more of a fight back against the increasing number of criminals taking advantage of them. Their decreasing physical strength makes them common targets and a gun is giving them their strength back.
  • Adolescent hunters are able to learn to live off our land and support California Department of Fish & Wildlife by promoting good hunting practices and following regulations. They are taught safety educational classes and get to practice and tune in the skill of shooting, you never know it might be your teen that saves your life one day in a home invasion.
  • Gun safety and education classes make our community an educated community. An active and ready community. It takes one armed citizen to stop one armed phsyco. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Sign up for information on how to attend a free class.
  • Come to our monthly meetings and fellowship with families like you.
  • Learn how to disable a firearm and make sure it's empty of ammo. Say a neighbor kid runs up to you with a gun he found and is surrounded by other children? This skill will be one that can quickly and easily make a very dangerous situation safer.
  • Buy a gun safe to make sure your firearm is not in hands it shouldn't be! 
  • Email us and ask us a question! 


[And p.s. if you've found this page and are so outraged and anti-gun you are cursing at your computer and turning blue in the face, please don't email us to let us know how you feel. 

We know how you feel, "guns kill people" and should be taken away. 

In that case to be cliche "spoons make people fat" "pencils misspell words" and "cars drive drunk"

 If you've never held a gun and you hate them so, let us pay for you a handgun safety course, take the class, shoot a gun, and then feel free to tell us how you feel, and how you would feel unarmed in an alley with a criminal?]


We really hope you're with us! Check out our Facebook page www.facebook.com/guneducationcampaign

story:
La version française (avec l'élément nouveau de l'entreprise solidaire CoMaLoC): 

Construire l'Espoire: Mobiliser les ressources pour bâtir des modules de classe pour le Lycée de Kpingni

You can learn amazing things if you actually listen, with humility, to what people have to say. This is particularly true if the people you’re talking to are children.

This is what students from CEG Kpingni have to say:

“We want to go to school. We want to learn about health and medicine to help our families and friends when they get sick. We want to learn about science and agriculture to help our parents produce more food and make more money. We want to learn French and English to communicate with more people. We want to get an education to help improve our lives of their families and their communities.   

Many of our parents want us to go to school too. Four years ago, parents from Kpingni and surrounding villages met and decided to ask the local government to establish a secondary school in the village. They didn’t want our older brothers and sisters to have to walk 2 hours to get to the nearest secondary school.  That distance, on top of a lot of other difficulties, discouraged so many of them from continuing school. The drop out rate in our villages was very high. We wanted a school in our village so kids didn't drop out.

With a big effort by the parents, the school was established in 2010. They built 2 makeshift classrooms to have class. 80 of my brothers and sisters and I enrolled. We didn’t have to walk far and we liked going to school.

Every year, more of our brothers and sisters enrolled. This was very good, but it created another problem: there weren't enough classrooms for the amount of students. Every year, our Director and the parents had to find the means to build more makeshift classrooms. We had 5 makeshift classrooms last year for 350 students.

This year we have 500 students at the school. But we are tired of building makeshift classrooms. We are tired of getting wet when it rains. We are tired of getting dirty during the dry season when the winds blow dust all over us. We are tired of being the only school without a real school building.  

We are the students of CEG Kpingni and we ask you to help us build a real school building.”

-Placide, 9th grade student at CEG Kpingni

CEG Kpingni is the only secondary school in the area without an actual school building. Because of the lack of classrooms, class sizes are too large, class time is being cut, and next year, students who want to enroll will be turned away.

With your help, we can change this.

We ask you to make common cause with the Director, the parents and students of CEG Kpingni and help them build the first school building at their school.

Why is a school building important?

As Christy says in the video and Placide says above, the students are tired of having class in make-shift classrooms. During the rainy season, they get wet when it rains. During the dry season, dust constantly blows into the classrooms and its hard to concentrate. A school building will  solve these problems, as well as provide students an important sense of dignity. When you go to the only school in the area without a real school building, and no one will help you build one for four years, it's hard to be proud of your school. 

The more serious issue is how the current lack of classrooms is affecting the quality of education.  With 500 students this year and only 5 classrooms, the Director and professors are afraid they cannot provide all the students with the education they deserve. The Director is also afraid that, without more classrooms, he will have to turn away students who want to enroll next year. 

The Director, the parents and students of CEG Kpingni have all said that they need a school building to ensure that students can keep going to school and keep getting a quality education. Their voices should be valued.  They shouldn't be neglected. 

What your donation will be used for:

Your donation will go towards the construction of a 3-classroom school building for CEG Kpingni.  All donations are tax-deductible.

Follow the link for a breakdown of the construction costs:

Budget for 3-classroom School Building

Even though we are fundraising here for $20,000, the completion of the whole school will require around $27,186. We are not asking for the total amount now since we are afraid that not reaching it would mean paying a higher percentage for this crowdfunding service. Still, if we only reach $20,000, we will be able to build the foundation, part of the walls and the roof. The more funds we receive, however, the more we can realize the construction plan.

If we don’t reach $20,000, the funds will still be used to start constructing the school building. We hope to get enough funds to at least build the foundation and get a roof over it, so the students can have class inside when the rainy season starts in April.

Our Team

Mama’s Inc.: Mama’s Inc. is a grassroots program, still in its infancy, dedicated to serving communities dealing with tragedy all over the world. Their mission is to teach young people everywhere that they can make a difference and it starts with them. Mama’s Inc. was the lead actor in planning this project and will help fundraise for the project.

Benin Education Fund (BEF): Launched in 1998, the Benin Education Fund is a U.S.-based 501(c)(3) nonprofit that provides scholarships and educational support to ambitious students in rural West Africa. BEF will help manage the donations and monitor the project.

Anicet Kpondehou: Anicet is an entrepreneur/architect in Dassa-Zoumé. According to Anicet: “My goal is to constantly think about how we can exploit our local materials to construct safe, economical, aesthetically pleasing buildings. I want to make this happen with other entrepreneurs and create a demand for buildings constructed with local materials like granite, bricks from clay, vegetable fiber, etc.”. Anicet will design the school building and supervise the construction.

Mark Huelsenbeck: Mark is an American volunteer in Dassa-Zoumé. He has worked at CEG Kpingni for the past 2 years facilitating a weekly environmental club with around 30 students. Mark will be responsible for monitoring and evaluating the project. 

Hilarion Vegba: Hilarion is the Director CEG Kpingni. He will be responsible with managing funds and supervising the construction of the school building.

The diversity of our team creates a strong accountability structure. We are all passionate about making this project work and using your donations exactly how we say we will.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out and make some noise! Share the campaign and video on facebook or by email.

effort by the parents, the school was established in 2010. They built 2
makeshift classrooms to have class. 80 of my brothers and sisters and I enrolled.
We didn’t have to walk far and we liked going to school.
Every year, more
of our brothers and sisters enrolled. This was very good, but it created
another problem: there weren't enough classrooms for the amount of students.
Every year, our Director and the parents had to find the means to build more
makeshift classrooms. We had 5 makeshift classrooms last year for 350 students.This year we
have 500 students at the school. But we are tired of building makeshift
classrooms. We are tired of getting wet when it rains. We are tired of getting
dirty during the dry season when the winds blow dust all over us. We are tired
of being the only school without a real school building.  
We are the
students of CEG Kpingni and we ask you to help us build a real school building.”
-Placide, 9th grade
student at CEG Kpingni
CEG Kpingni is the only secondary school in the area without an actual school building. Because
of the lack of classrooms, class sizes are too large, class time is being cut,
and next year, students who want to enroll will be turned away. 

With your help, we can change this.
We ask you to
make common cause with the Director, the parents and students of CEG Kpingni and
help them build the first school building at their school. 
Why is a school building important?As Christy says in the video and Placide says above, the students are tired of having class in make-shift classrooms. During the rainy season, they get wet when it rains. During the dry season, dust constantly blows into the classrooms and its hard to concentrate. A school building will  solve these problems, as well as provide students an important sense of dignity. When you go to the only school in the area without a real school building, and no one will help you build one for four years, it's hard to be proud of your school. The more serious issue is how the current lack of classrooms is affecting the quality of education.  With 500 students this year and only 5 classrooms, the Director and professors are afraid they cannot provide all the students with the education they deserve. The Director is also afraid that, without more classrooms, he will have to turn away students who want to enroll next year. The Director, the parents and students of CEG Kpingni have all said that they need a school building to ensure that students can keep going to school and keep getting a quality education. Their voices should be valued.  They shouldn't be neglected. What your donation will be used for:
Your donation
will go towards the construction of a 3-classroom school building for CEG
Kpingni.  All donations are
tax-deductible. 

Follow the link for a breakdown of the construction costs:Budget for 3-classroom School BuildingEven though we
are fundraising here for $20,000,
the completion of the whole school will require around $27,186. We are not asking for the total amount now since we are
afraid that not reaching it would mean paying a higher percentage for this
crowdfunding service. Still, if we only reach $20,000, we will be able to build
the foundation, part of the walls and the roof. The more funds we receive,
however, the more we can realize the construction plan.
If we don’t
reach $20,000, the funds will still be used to start constructing the school
building. We hope to get enough funds to at least build the foundation and
get a roof over it, so the students can have class inside when the rainy season
starts in April. 
Our Team
Mama’s Inc.: Mama’s Inc. is a grassroots program, still in its infancy, dedicated to serving communities dealing with tragedy all over the world. Their mission is to teach young people everywhere that they can make a difference and it starts with them.
Mama’s Inc. was the lead actor in planning this project and will help
fundraise for the project. 

Benin Education Fund (BEF): Launched in 1998, the Benin Education
Fund is a U.S.-based 501(c)(3) nonprofit that provides scholarships and
educational support to ambitious students in rural West Africa. BEF will help
manage the donations and monitor the project.
Anicet Kpondehou: Anicet is an entrepreneur/architect in
Dassa-Zoumé. According to Anicet: “My goal is to constantly think about how we
can exploit our local materials to construct safe, economical, aesthetically
pleasing buildings. I want to make this happen with other entrepreneurs and
create a demand for buildings constructed with local materials like granite,
bricks from clay, vegetable fiber, etc.”. Anicet will design the school
building and supervise the construction. 
Mark Huelsenbeck: Mark is an American volunteer
in Dassa-Zoumé. He has worked at CEG Kpingni for the past 2 years facilitating a
weekly environmental club with around 30 students. Mark will be responsible for
monitoring and evaluating the project. 

Hilarion Vegba: Hilarion is the Director CEG Kpingni. He
will be responsible with managing funds and supervising the construction of the school building. 
The diversity of
our team creates a strong accountability structure. We are all passionate about
making this project work and using your donations exactly how we say we will. 
Other Ways You Can Help 

Get the word out
and make some noise! Share the campaign and video on facebook or by email.

story:
We are.....

David's Heirs,  members of Bethel Campus Fellowship (BCF), a campus ministry that God is using radically transform the college experience on campuses worldwide.

Our goal is to raise $1000 to send students to BCF's Annual National Conference, a conference that has touched and changed every single one of our lives. 



This year we are expecting 1500 students from as many as 35 colleges, high schools,and several church youth groups from across the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom.

What We Need 

To meet the budget for the conference, members of BCF have volunteered to raise $1000.00 each. Each of us has volunteered to help this cause and understand that we work even better as a team. Your donation will be used to:

  • Sponsor students who desire to attend this conference but do not have the means
  • It will help us to secure hotel accommodation, transportation from our various campuses, and meals for the three days. 

Your donation is tax deductible. 

We pray that God will lead you to support our goal with a one time donation of $10, $25, $50, $100, $150, $250, $500, or $1000.

God bless you as you support us!

-Solomon's Wealth

What  Students Are Saying About BCF...

"BCF gave me a place where I could encounter God's love thorugh His people; people who lived out the word of God and encouraged me in my pursuit of real love."

- Sophia N

“If it were not for BCF, I more than likely would not be here today. The conference last year wrecked me and I’ll never be the same.”  

- Temi O.

“God used BCF to lead me to Him. It is in this ministry that I first caught a glimpse of what it meant to be on fire for God. It remains the ministry that gives me the desire to delve deeper spiritually in order to maintain an engaging, loving, experiential relationship with the Lord.”

- Victoria P.

“BCF means everything to me. It has truly allowed me to understand what it means to walk with Christ through fellowship with other young believers. My walk has been forever changed because of it.”

- Jamal N.

“BCF was the catalyst for me to experience a relationship with God and His people in a  new and awesome way. BCF showed me Christ in a way no one else has before.”

-Janicia M.

“BCF has been a catalyst for spiritual growth in my life. God has used so many different people in the ministry to build my faith, broaden my understanding of God, challenge me to continue learning,and so much more. Being a part of BCF has showed me time and time again, that God is real and that He changes lives for the better.”

- Idara I

“BCF showed me what true friendship looked like."

- Lu A

story:
Who doesn't love an experiment?

“I’ve been through a lot in the name of science,” says Jay Ingram, the much admired and often sacrificed former co-host of Discovery Channel’s Daily Planet. "I've been punched in the face, sprayed with molten lava, dropped from a building, rescued from an ice floe, thrown against a Velcro wall, just to name a few."

Now he needs help to pull off the craziest experiment ever – A Sequence of Unexpected Events – as the official Opening of Beakerhead, a big smash up of art, science and engineering that will be launched – with your help – in Calgary, Alberta (CANADA), this September 12, 2013.

Be a part of this experiment – a particularly fun one!

Jay is asking anyone with (and even without) a passion for the arts, sciences and engineering to help him out. Depending on your donation, you could even play a live role in this unfolding spectacle involving the iconic Calgary Tower.  

The impact

Here’s how you can help Jay fulfill his lifelong duty to suffer for science (in the safest and most amazing ways, of course)!

story:
Why Cuba?

Visiting Cuba has been a lifelong dream so when I learned of this educational opportunity I couldn't pass it up.

In October, I’ll be traveling to Cuba with a group of social workers from the National Association of Social Workers to study Cuba’s social welfare system. Despite the poverty in Cuba they have a generous social welfare system that is a cornerstone of its economy. Michigan and much of the United States have cut funding to their social welfare programs and explain doing so due to financial hardship. The United States could learn much from Cuba.

Who Am I?

Those that know me may describe me as someone that cares passionately about helping others. As a social worker I’ve dedicated my life to this and I am always seeking to learn more.

I have seen firsthand how cuts in funding to Michigan’s social welfare programs have impacted Michigan’s citizens. My goal is to return from Cuba with information that can be used to make positive changes.

What I Need

I’m asking for your help so that I can become a better advocate in our community and our world.

My time in Cuba is a very unique opportunity – not only are there are very few options for traveling there legally as a US citizen – but Cuba serves as an excellent social welfare model.

This opportunity is beyond my budget so I'm asking for help from you – the community, my friends and family- to help me with $4,000. The costs associated with this trip include tuition, flights and transportation, tour registration fees (including required health insurance, visa, taxes, and interpreter/guide), food and water, and accommodations.

What You Can Expect

While in Cuba I will be visiting and meeting with professionals at a senior center, farmers market, children’s theater, University of Havana, community centers, the Center for Psychosocial Investigation, a family doctor clinic, school for special needs children, and Cuban Institute for Sex Education and Gender Studies.

Upon returning home, I will share the inspiring stories and lessons that Cuba’s citizens have to offer and use the knowledge I gain to advocate for change.

By supporting my campaign, not only will you get the opportunity to get some great perks, but I promise to come back from this trip inspired to work harder to make this a better world for all of us.

Please feel free to ask me questions!

Other Ways You Can Help

I appreciate any level of donation, but if you aren't able - or want to do more than contribute financially - yes, you can still help!

  • Please help me get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Check out how to use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Get involved in your community

 

Thank you for your support - let's change the world together!

story:
Summary

Hi! Thanks for stopping by.

My name is Esbeida Flores. I am a student at Ivy Tech Community College in Indiana. I just finished my third semester towards a fine arts degree. There’s a detail and it’s that I am undocumented.

Now, let me tell you guys how that happened.

Since I was born and up until the age of 9 I lived in Mexico. I lived in this little house with my mom, my brother, and my father. We had to deal with economic problems, barely having enough to survive. Not only that, my father was an alcoholic. He was a very serious and short-tempered man as it was but the biggest problem is that he got violent when he was drunk. I was blessed with a good memory, so I remember sometimes more than I’d like to.

I remember that if my dad was not home by 9:30pm we knew he was going to come late into the night drunk. The three of us would wait in silence trying to brace ourselves for what we knew was coming. This went on for years (before I was even born) and it got so bad to the point that our nervous systems couldn’t take it anymore. Because of the trauma we went through we started to physically get sick and that’s when my mom decided to bring us here to the U.S.

And I will forever be grateful to her for taking us out of that life and giving us the chance to start over. I always wondered why she didn’t left earlier but I guess she thought it was better for us to have a father than not have one, until there was proof that that was not the case. When we got here I wanted to make my mom proud and my way of thanking her was to do my best in school. I always knew I was going to college I didn’t know how I just knew I would. So in the meantime I kept working. Not just in my academics but also working hard at getting better with my art since I always knew that’s what I wanted to do.

Senior year in High School I dedicated myself to researching as much as I could to know to how to get myself to college. That’s when I found out about HB1402. This bill makes undocumented students pay out of state tuition. So instead of paying 3,000 a year I have to pay over 6,500 dollars. My family is not able to help me economically since my mom is currently unemployed and my brother is the only source of income. So that’s a huge amount of money especially since I have to come up with it on my own. To be honest it was devastating it felt like everything I had worked for was collapsing to the ground.

That was when I started to apply to as many scholarships as I could. I told myself that if I got even only one I would do everything I could to finish. So it happened. I have this scholarship from which I receive $2,000 a year. That covered a little over half from 1st semester. But I have no other scholarships to help me with this upcoming semester.

I would like to keep moving forward with my education and what I set out to do. I want to make my family proud and one day give back a little of what they’ve given me. My ultimate dream would be to someday open up an art gallery/community center. Now, I don’t know how that’s going to happen yet but I figure I will cross that bridge when I get to it. For now I have this one problem, tuition for next spring. So that’s why I’m here today to ask for your help.

I am looking to raise $3,450. This would cover my tuition costs for the spring semester. And if you could donate anything, a dollar, or even if you can’t if you could just share this with someone who might be interested in donating you will already have a huge part in helping me get an education.

I am determined to keep working hard because I really believe I can do this. I have been working on some projects to give to anyone who contributes. And I promise you that when you get your bookmark, postcard or print you will know that you have made a difference in someone’s life.

The Impact
If you would like to know the actual breakdown of how it goes:

Each course is $751 and there is a $60 technology fee. Now, the reason I need to take 12 credit hours (4 courses) is that one of the requirements to get the scholarship that helps me in the fall is for me to be a full time student both semesters. So any donation will be helping me TREMENDOUSLY. I won’t have to worry every day about where and how I am going to get money to pay Ivy Tech. My ultimate dream is to be educated in the field of fine arts and one day open up an art gallery/community center. I want to help other students get to information and resources when they are still in high school so they won’t have to go through the frustration I had to go through when I had to do it all on my own. If I can share my knowledge and make the road easier for those who come after me that will be the greatest feeling in the world. Anything you could do to help me now will already be huge to get there in the end. I can’t even begin to articulate how thankful and how much this would all mean not just to me but to my family as well.

If don’t reach my goal everything I do raise (minus 9% that go to indiegogo) will all go towards paying tuition. If something absolutely amazing were to happen and I raise more than the listed amount I will pay off tuition, rent the math book for the math course I’ll be taking, and maybe get art supplies I will need for classes such as a new sketchbook, paint etc. In other words it will all go exclusively towards education. (4% goes to indiegogo)

The Perks
I have been working hard on various projects to send anyone who contributes! I’ve got some key-chains, bookmarks, postcards, thank-you cards, and even prints! Some of them are digitally-made and some are hand-made, scanned then printed. The originals will also be available for certain donations. With the exception of postcards and thank-you cards all goodies will be mailed after the campaign is over. I will do this just so I will have a set number of how much I need so I won’t have a shortage or surplus of anything. There are more details about these on the boxes to the right. →

If you would like to get in contact with me for any reason, questions, suggestion, a good-luck wish, anything don’t hesitate to! Here’s how to do it:
esbeidaflores@gmail.com

I can’t promise a same-day response because I do not have internet at home but I promise to check it at least twice a week and as often as possible.

If you would like to take a look at some of my art work there’s a place for that as well:

https://www.facebook.com/Esbeida.CaptnZBella24/...

Thank you so much for everything. Don’t forget to share it with friends! :)

story:
International Academy of African Business & Development

The annual conferences of the International Academy of African Business and Development (IAABD) are open to scholars, professionals, and graduate students of any nationality who are interested or actively engaged in the research and performance or administration of business and economic development issues as they relate to Africa. These conferences aim at facilitating multidisciplinary research on Africa’s related issues, stimulating collaborations between Africa based researchers and their counterparts around the world, broadening and deepening global understanding of the various challenges facing African development and business, and advancing alternative solutions to Africa’s business and development challenges.

The 2013 conference continues to focus on the various impacts of the recent economic downturn on African business and development, how integration of African economies might enhance economic growth and development.

Donating to this fund will aid in getting my research in front of peers, practitioners and other industry experts. The process will be filmed and made into a short documentary for future scholars, specifically Business PhD students, who are interested in doing research on the international level. It will share the ins and outs of writing, submitting to academic journals, the review process, traveling, presenting, and networking with other scholars in your field. 

Thank you for your help
Armond Sinclair
story_txt:
International Academy of African Business & Development
The annual conferences of the International Academy of African Business and Development (IAABD) are open to scholars, professionals, and graduate students of any nationality who are interested or actively engaged in the research and performance or administration of business and economic development issues as they relate to Africa. These conferences aim at facilitating multidisciplinary research on Africa’s related issues, stimulating collaborations between Africa based researchers and their counterparts around the world, broadening and deepening global understanding of the various challenges facing African development and business, and advancing alternative solutions to Africa’s business and development challenges.
The 2013 conference continues to focus on the various impacts of the recent economic downturn on African business and development, how integration of African economies might enhance economic growth and development.
Donating to this fund will aid in getting my research in front of peers, practitioners and other industry experts. The process will be filmed and made into a short documentary for future scholars, specifically Business PhD students, who are interested in doing research on the international level. It will share the ins and outs of writing, submitting to academic journals, the review process, traveling, presenting, and networking with other scholars in your field. 
Thank you for your helpArmond Sinclair

story:
Being Brave: Is Enlightened Society Possible?

In May 2014, hundreds of people will gather at the Crane Pavillion in Richmond, California to explore how meditation and contemplative practices can impact how we approach the global challenges faced today.  The Being Brave: Is Enlightened Society Possible? weekend retreat, led by Sakyong Mipham Rinpoche and Pema Chodron, explores important and impactful questions:

  • What does meditation practice offer to the pressing personal, social, and ecological challenges that we face?

  • How can we apply inner peace and bravery to develop outer compassionate action?

  • How can we open our hearts to meet fear with bravery?

  • How can we connect with the fundamental practice of compassion and the recognition of our shared humanity?

We need your support to ensure that everyone who wants to attend this powerful retreat is able to.  All donations are tax deductible.

Help everyone be able to attend!

Here, some of our scholarship applicants share their inspriations and aspirations for attending the Being Brave retreat:

I'm a composer living in Oakland, California.  The Shambhala teachings are the inspiring force for my creativity, but they are so much more than that.  The practice helps me to rest in my deep intuition and connect with the core of a musical idea. As a music teacher, the teachings help me to be present with, and truly hear, each student. Thank you for helping me attend this program with the Sakyong and Pema!                                   - Alex Van Gils

As I am the sole caregiver for my 2 elderly parents, both with dementia, I am constantly challenged to expand my capacity for loving kindness and compassion for myself and others. I hope to bring back renewed inspiration to continue to be present with the challenges of every-day life in a more compassionate and loving way.                - Suzanne Lichau

Since the revolution in Iran 1979 and witnessing my friends to be executed, I was looking for a answer to problems in the world. I have realized that the answer to problems does not come with aggression.

                                                                  - Anonymous Scholarship Applicant

My aspirations for the collective effect of this program is that each of us who are involved may attune to a place of compassion for our humanness and that this compassion be fuel to ignite our hearts into action that is sustainable and supportive of a more humane existence for all.

                                                                   - Lana Maree

For donations of $25 or more, your name will be entered into a raffle to win a Retreat and Renewal Weekend at the beautiful Shambhala Mountain Center in Red Feather Lakes, CO.  The prize will entitle you to a private room in one of the Lodges, meals, a tour of the Great Stupa of Dharmakaya, and access to mediation instruction, dharma talks, yoga classes through out the weekend.  This is a wonderful way to get away from the speed of everyday life and deepen your practice in a peaceful and powerful environment.

Our previous Being Brave retreats have been a huge success, with thousands of attendants touching in with their inherent wisdom and goodness and bringing that back into the world with them.

The Impact

During this retreat, participants will learn how to rouse strength and compassion in order to make a difference in their communities and in their own lives.  By touching in with the wisdom inherent in all humanity, we can relieve overhelm, transform fear, and inspire our hearts, our communities, organizations, cities and nations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you can contribute financially to our campaign, please share our campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, and neighbors! You can also share this indiegogo page on your Facebook and Twitter accounts.

To learn more about the Being Brave retreat, or to register, please visit www.creatingsociety.com.

Event Sponsorship:  If you know of someone who may want to sponsor the event, please contact Camren Von Davis at camrenvondavis@gmail.com

Remember, anyone who donates $25 or more, will be entered into our raffle to win a Retreat and Renewal weekend at Shambhala Mountain Center.

story:
Thanks to 362 donors, and to the hundreds more who spread the word via social media and email blasts, we've surpassed our initial goal of $85,000! Many many thanks, everyone!!!
With time still remaining though, we're now focused on raising additional funds to offset some of the debt that I discussed at the beginning of the campaign.

Briefly, this debt includes:

  • SBA disaster relief loan for the 2007 Castle Rock fires.
  • Loan to landlord to pay off debt related to the seizing of our bank. 
  • Taxes, which Gary had fallen behind on prior to his death. 
  • Various lines of credit to help the store through the recent fires and subsequent lost season.  (See our GOAL at the end of campaign.)  

We are in good standing with all of these debts, but they are preventing us from moving forward. Moving forward for Iconoclast means …

  • Restructuring the corporation to allow partner investment to make this a truly community owned bookstore. Significant obligations must be met before we can do this.  
  • Continuing to support our collective by being a community hub for readers, authors, musicians, poets, actors, children and teens.  
  • Improving Iconoclast with necessary upgrades to the cafe and retail spaces. 
  • Increase our work with non-profits, including schools, libraries and arts organizations. 
  • And to realize our long sought goal of becoming an incubator for Writers/Artists in Residence Programs.

We’ll continue to borrow from Mr. Gaiman's ideas in hopes of describing our plight and our hope, because we don’t just sell stories, we tell them too.  And we believe in happy endings. 

“Fairy tales are more than true: not because they tell us that dragons exist, but because they tell us that dragons can be beaten.” 

The Story of Iconoclast Books began with a starry eyed bookseller who opened a humble downstairs shop on Fourth St. twenty years ago.  Over time, the store grew to become a town institution.  We are a meeting spot, a study hall, a performance space, a play room, an idea factory, a launch pad for flights of fancy for young and old alike.  In our store, friends meet for tea, authors speak, musicians perform, children learn to read, curiosity is aroused. Customers and causes count on us to support or be their partner – The Community Library, the Sun Valley Writers' Conference, the SV Center for the Arts, the Trailing of the Sheep Festival, Schools and book fairs, seasonal festivals and more.  

We have grown with the community, while honoring the legacy of the store and the needs of our neighbors.  

Like all good tales, we've had our share of dragons, especially in the six years since the loss of my husband and business partner, Gary Hunt.  We've suffered from the  impact of the recession, the seizing of our locally owned bank, and the rise of online competition.  Last summer we all experienced the most difficult summer we've had when the Beaver Creek fires caused the evacuation of our valley during the most profitable time of year.  Additionally, the impact of Amazon and its egregious attempts to put bricks and mortar stores out of business, is possibly the biggest dragon to slay.  

Our recent efforts to downsize the store to meet both our financial obligations and the needs of the store look to be a part of a successful formula and though it's been melancholic watching the history and Gary's touch on the store leave by the truckload, we feel hopeful that with these changes and your help we can continue to be your community hub for another 20 years.  



But first, a bit more of the Icono story and our recent downsize here:  Los Angeles Review of Books ~ 20 Years of Iconoclastic Bookselling  as well as a few photos of our tale.  


Way back when...


And now...


Our commitment to our valley's youth and the thousands who visit each year, is to maintain the best selection and the most knowledgeable staff to help your kiddos, just as we helped you years ago!
 


Our renowned Author Events, where we've had the pleasure of listening to their words and witnessed a few dance on table tops, break into song, down growlers of beer, paint the wall with their autographs, make us weep, laugh and think.

 


Some of our favorite occasions each month, in-store or in Town Square: Our incredible Open Mic Nights and Poetry Slams. Mark our words - these two will be famous musicians one day!

 


The impact of the fires and Amazon have created a difficult environment and we have fallen seriously behind on rent and with some of our most beloved vendors.  Many of these vendors are local -  people who have been our partners for years.

  • Approximately $55,000 to back rent and late fees. 
  • $30,000 to local vendors, authors and publishers.  
  • If we exceed this goal we will continue to pay down bills to publishers and outstanding loans.   
  • Additional funds to pay down balances owed to publishers, outstanding loans and debts.  Among these: The SBA disaster relief loan (2007 Castle Rock fires), back taxes, line of credit and revolving accounts.  Approximately $250,000. We are in good standing with these debts, but they are preventing us from moving forward.  

At the time of Gary's death I made the decision to accept Letters of Testamentary which made me solely responsible for his actions.  Possibly an unwise decision, but one I made because I didn't want to lose him AND the bookstore.  The burden of the store's debt was far greater than I imagined,  yet all of these years later, with some of it paid off, I feel even more strongly about keeping up the fight.  

We've had wonderful support from our landlord, a record-breaking year in sales during the height of the recession, and I've been able to pay off many of our creditors while not incurring any new debt.  

Our community has been quite vocal this week about the importance of keeping our doors open.  We've determined that Iconoclast Books is an undeniable asset to this community, but for continued growth and sustainability, we need to pay off the debt I inherited.  

Despite the bleak picture I've outlined, the store continues to grow and be refined with the changes in the economy and technology.  We've identified many areas that will be profit centers or add value to our community if we can redirect debt payments towards expansion. 

  • More Children's Programming - from art classes to poetry projects.
  • Gift and Travel store - We've identified many products - that go beautifully with books - that do not exist in the valley.  
  • A Cafe upgrade, with a secret too great to share at this time! 
  • Sidelines, sidelines and more sidelines!  Our card selection has been the best in the valley for years and we've numerous ways to get even better, including other unexpected necessities.  
  • Beer and wine license, because what goes with books as well as our locally roasted, organic coffee does?  Yes, wine. 
  • Writers in Residence Program  - A dream of ours for a long time and one we believe we can play a large role in creating. 



We realize this is an enormous amount of money to ask for, especially in a small community.  You can help this campaign by sharing it wherever you can, here in the valley and outside.  Get the message and into the hands and hearts of people who care about Independent Bookstores.  

  • Give what you can.  We'll remember you forever!  (Check out the perks, you could have a shelf named after you!) 
  • Please share this campaign via email with those who may be able to help;  notes saying that Iconoclast Books is a favorite store of yours or your children, go along way.    
  • Post it ALL OVER your social media.  People have passion for Indie Bookstores! 
  • Share it even if someone cannot help ~ they may pass it along to someone who is able to.  
  • Check out our donor gifts and spread the word that a little money will go a long way!  
  • Lastly, but very importantly, consider ditching the amazon "buy now" button and have a real experience with people who love books!  If you're an e-reader, you can buy your e-books through our website!  

                       


This is your community, your store.  We thank you deeply for the first 20 years and hope to be here to serve you for another 20!  

THAT would be a happy ending!  

Note ~ We have a video coming and will shorten the length of this campaign.    Check back in a few days where there will be new perks, as well!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Peyton Abdelbaki. I am a 6th grade student at Prairieville Middle School and I have been nominated to be a Student Ambassador with the People To People Program.   I have earned straight A’s during my academic career and I was nominated for student of the year by the school staff.  I also play football, baseball, and soccer

 

         People To People select students from across the country who have achieved recognition from their teachers and maintained high grades. They challenge tomorrow’s leaders to expand their global awareness about other cultures.  This opportunity will take me on a 12-day trip to Canada where I will be representing the United States. I will have a chance to meet Canadian Mounties, go to a wolf reserve where they rescue and release the wolves back into the wild, and meet members of and learn about the Blackfoot tribe.  I will go whale watching and for part of our community service, we will adopt a whale! In all of these experiences, I will build both my confidence and responsibility, because I will be going on the trip without my parents. This program is a one that colleges around the country look at and 80% of People To People alumni make it into their 1st choice college.  If given another opportunity to participate in this program, I can even begin earning college credits starting in 7th grade, which is one goal I would like to achieve

 What We Need & What You Get

The amount of money I need to raise is $5,000 and if you help me reach this goal by contributing you will get a photo diary of my trip.

The Impact

By contributing to my cause you will help me gain both confidence and responsibility. This trip will also help increase my education, which will give me an edge I need to get into colleges around the country.

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Stretch goal added! T-shirts for everyone who donates $75 and above if we reach $5,000!

"You're gonna do what now?"

Hello, I'm Bradly Richards. The chances are good, if you know me, that at some point over the past sixteen years I have served you coffee. Since that went so well, I am trying something different. 

Most of my adult life I have been looking for a barber. Most traditional barbers I have found retire or die, so I have decided to throw my hat into the ring. I started attending the Barber School of Pittsburgh in January and will finish in October.  Through the competent teachings of my mentors and my own research, I am learning traditional men's haircutting. I am not trying to reinvent the wheel or follow fashion trends, but rather continue the practices of traditional barbers that are fading away. The Humble Barber Co. is my attempt to keep that proud history alive. 

As a backer of my effort you will help Carrie and I lessen the tuition burden of $15,000 to the Barber School of Pittsburgh and help me gather tools and implements of the trade that have been neglected or forgotten. Everything else above and beyond will go towards the goal of getting The Humble Barber Co. off the ground. 

Designer Colin Miller has graciously created a brand for this venture, and I have branded some items with his mark to be offered as incentives, and to help spread the good word. My ultimate goal is to open a barber shop in Pittsburgh proper. This campaign will help me to gauge interest in such an establishment and gather information from potential clients. In the meantime, I am cutting hair at the Richards Family Homestead and collecting the experience needed to perform this craft with consistency and integrity. Thank you for your consideration and traveling this road with me. 

~Bradly Richards, The Humble Barber Co.
