story:
Short Summary

Joel Duah Afi, is a young energetic final year medical student at the Kwame Nkruamah University of Science and Technology who believes in the application of acquired knowledge and skills to the betterment of the global society.
He supports preventive health for all and a youth activist championing the role of the youth and education and quality healthcare on realization of the Millennium Development Goals in Ghana.

He recently conducted a research and sat on the MDG Committee in WorldMUN 2013, Melbourne Australia to discuss the post-2015 development agenda and the world we want with like-minded youth leaders from all over the world. The resolution post-2015 framework for global development which was adopted by unanimous acclamation by some over 2000 delegates have been forward to the United Nations through UNESCAP.

He also worked as the Health Officer of the KNUST Medical Student Association and the National Health Officer of the Federation of Ghana Medical Students’ Association, and have been quite exposed to some of my society’s needs with regards to health and its achievement through the initiation and organization of social intervention programs such as the Annual National Health Week celebration and the health outreach programs notable among them is the ‘’Safe Blood Saves Lives’’ with the aim of recruiting safe blood donors and the prevention of blood related infections such as HIV/AIDS and viral hepatitis.

He has been a delegate and speaker at the Global Model United Nations Conference 2011 in Incheon, South Korea, where they discussed Sustainable Development: Advancing Human Progress in Harmony with Nature. During the 2nd Ghana International Model United Nations conference, he was an official in the Social and Humanitarian committee of the General Assembly. 

The major motivation of Joel Duah Afi in seeking social change is his zeal to see people develop and attain economic emancipation and a just society where people are accountable to one another. A society where the people are healthy, a society where opportunities abound for youth empowerment and development

Joel has currently been invited to attend the Clinton Global Initiative University but since there is no financial assistance for the airfare, i have the pleasure to ask of you to help me pay for the airfare and a few other expenses.

CGI U is an annual gathering of college students and youth leaders who come together to address some of the world’s most pressing challenges. Each attendee makes a Commitment to Action, a concrete plan to make a tangible difference within the five following focus areas: education, environment and climate change, peace and human rights, poverty alleviation, and public health.

Students whose commitment get selected receive funding and mentorship program from the Resolution Project to implement this socially responsible projects

The commitment that i am working on is called: Mobile Health. Mobile Health is a social venture that seeks to deliver quality well structured health education and screening programs to rural communities in Ghana whiles donating part of the profit so raised from the project to help rural schools,  setting up libraries etc. It will also provide a platform for medical students to volunteer in rural communities whiles providing mentorship programs for high school students.

By supporting me to the CGIU 2014, you are doing me a big favor and eempowering me to reach out to many under priviledge in society.


What We Need & What You Get

I have the pleasure to ask of you to support me to pay for the airfare and other expenses explained below:

1700USD     Economy return air ticket from Ghana to Phoenix, USA.

180 USD      Shared Accomodation for two nights (*Total stay of 4 nights, but the CGIU Host team  is already paying for two nights)

40USD        Ground Transportation

100USD      Feeding for 5 days

80USD        4% fees to Indiegogo

Total= 2100USD

It would be much appreciated if you could help me raise the funds to cover this budget, which i am hopeful that, you would be touched to donate in support of this course.

I am much confident that with your support, i will reach this go. However, in the unlikely event that the total funds for the airfare is not raised, such that i am not able to embark on the trip, which i hope would NOT happen, because you are here to support, any funds raised would be donated to Mobile Health Consult to support free medical screening programs for deprived communities in Ghana. 

Below are some few listed perks: The benefits quoted as part of this write up may not be appealing enough, and are not meant to be an exchange bargain. Rather together supporting me and the Mobile Health and YOU will be fulfilling a major social responsibility, one that society will be grateful for. It would be a great opportunity of indirectly providing health care delivery to the good people of Ghana.

The Impact

participaing in the CGIU provides me with training and knowledge, leadership and networking which will empower me in running the a social venture.

It is also a platform for me to participate in the Resolution Social Venture Challenge and stand the chance of getting my project selected to recieve funding and mentorship to implement these socially responsible programs in rural communities in Ghana. 

more details can be found at: http://www.cgiu.org and http://resolutionproject.org/

Other Ways You Can Help

Help me spread the word to others. share the story. 

Also use use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
My Story: Music Heals, Loves, and Inspires

I grew up loving music and the cello more than anything else in life. I've wanted nothing more than to be able to reach my audiences with my music and make a difference in their lives with it! Although the benefits of being a performer are huge, they also come with a price. I've endured a long and hard road as a student and musician these last 5 years during my undergrad at Central Washington University. I've had amazing opportunities, travelled to really cool places to compete and perform, made music with great friends, and have learned a ton, but I had a dark shadow following me everywhere I went that no one knew about. That figure was anxiety and depression. The pressure to be perfect was unmatched and I spiraled further and further down the hole of depression until I came to a place of self-loathing. I had forgotten the most important thing I held dear: music is not about being perfect. Music is about sharing a piece of myself, exposing my spirit, becoming vulnerable, giving my audience the opportunity to experience something unique, and opening the eyes of my listeners to their own souls. Having forgotten this, I came to do the unthinkable. At a time in my life where everything seemed to be crashing down around me, I tried to commit suicide. I overdosed on xanax and alcohol and began cutting myself. I was found by my roommate and after a string of phone calls had been made, my parents decided to pull me out of school and put me on a medical leave. I underwent months of counseling, physical therapy, and other doctors appointments, having no idea what the outcome would be, but I just kept trudging on. 
This was the worst thing I have ever gone through, but I made it out on the other side. I have God and the gift of music he gave me to thank for that. Having to rebuild myself from the foundation up, I learned once again what it meant to be an artist. I learned it's ok to not be perfect, to learn from my mistakes, and to love what I do and stand by my craft no matter what happens. I learned to love music again for the sake of music. My passion for playing the cello and God's promise that he would provide, is what made me fight this ugly condition and come out of this place as a better human being and artist. After having taken so much time off from school, I didn't think it was possible to finish on time and attend grad school the following year. But with hard work, doubling up on classes my last two quarters, and preparing my best for auditions, I graduated this spring with my undergraduate degree and got accepted to study at the Glenn Gould School of the Royal Conservatory in Toronto! I am also off every medication I had been on for the last two years and am the happiest I have been in a long time. I have experienced the lowest of lows and the highest of highs in the span of 9 months. This is an incredible opportunity but I need financial support in order to make it a reality. I'm coming from the small town of Ellensburg, WA, where the rent is 1/4 of what it will be in Toronto, ON. It's a huge gap and I will need all the help I can get to make this transition! Every little bit helps. Thank you for reading my story and for your support! 
This was a very personal experience I chose to share, but I'm doing so in order to magnify the power of music and what it has done in my life. Thank you for your time and I hope this has helped someone who needed to read it! 
Just remember to love what you do, and do what you love. <3

story:
We are the Cully Young Farmer’s Project, a passionate group of 3 individuals (plus many supporters) bringing learning to life in our fall and spring garden education program.  We are located in Portland, Oregon, where there’s no shortage of learning opportunities for those interested in urban farming.  Our garden education teacher delivers lessons in the children’s garden, a part of Cully Neighborhood Farm, on property owned by Trinity Lutheran Church. 

Until this summer, the school year ended mid-June, and we were left to weed, water, and harvest what the students had planted.  Students returned in the fall, and we harvested those vegetables which lasted into September.  Students missed out on experiencing the full cycle of the garden as it was flourishing, and didn't get to see many of the vegetables they'd planted from seed.  This summer, we’ve been invited to participate in the summer camp program offered at the school!  That’s what this fundraiser is about.

Our goal is to have the students who are attending Trinity's summer camp, along with other children, farm in the children's garden two days a week from mid-June to late August under the direction of our garden education teacher. 

Our program has been embraced by the community, teachers, parents, college supervisors, friends, and, most importantly, the students.  CYFP continues to expand, and we consistently receive unequivocally positive reviews from the staff.

The students anticipate their weekly garden lessons, have eaten vegetables they’ve never even heard of, use “farming” vocabulary, and can’t get enough of discovering soil, bugs, seeds, etc.

This year, for the first time, students had a cooking lesson (making pesto), and a huge, end of the year feast, which among other things, included kale chips, with kale harvested from their garden. 

We know how many people support our mission, and our hope is that this support will turn into dollars! Help us keep the momentum of CYFP going!

For further reading about the success of our school year program, see below:

·       Students continue to gain knowledge necessary to effectively raise food sources in their own gardens.

·       Students have shown an increased interest in eating more fruits and vegetables, thus inspiring a healthier lifestyle.

·       Students have shown a willingness to try new vegetables, increasing the variety they consume.

·       Teachers have integrated the curriculum into their own classrooms, thereby enhancing student learning.

·       Students have deepened their connection with nature and continue to learn about its beauty, power, and fragility.

·       The school garden has enhanced the beauty of the school grounds. 

·       CYFP hired a certified elementary school teacher, who delivers expert instruction and continues to align the program with state science standards.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Despite our successful fundraising efforts last year (we raised $2,500 through indiegogo in August 2013), and several grants (the Lorenz Family Foundation and East Multnomah Soil and Water Conservation District), we are unable to fund the summer program and maintain the garden without further fundraising. Right now, our director and teacher are volunteering their hours, as they have been doing for the last two months! Our goal is to raise $4,500.

Continuing to employ our certified garden education teacher this summer provides consistency for TLS students, and a guarantee that lessons will be relevant and inspirational, so that we can engage the children, from age 5 to 14.  

For your contribution, you will hear back from one of our students in the form of a drawing or quote, get a tour, or receive a basket of produce.  One of these will remind you of the unbridled enthusiasm of children and how you have helped make a positive difference in their lives.  

    The Impact

    The CYFP has and will continue to foster relationships between families, congregation members, university students, pre-K-8 students, and Cully neighborhood residents.  The Cully neighborhood is located in one of the most economically challenged and ethnically diverse areas of the city.  CYFP will assist Trinity Lutheran Church's mission of reaching out into their immediate neighborhood and helping meet the needs of those around them in whatever way they can.

    CYFP will serve as a model for the single family owners in the Cully neighborhood, many of whom enjoy Cully’s characteristically large lot sizes and suitability for urban agriculture.

    Our summer program will enable the children to actively participate in maintaining the garden, harvesting produce, and trying recipes using garden produce.  This is the FIRST year they have this opportunity to participate in the summer, when the garden is flourishing.

    Children’s academic skills will stay sharpened by using math, reading, and writing.

    Participants and their families will have regular access to green space, in a neighborhood where 2,780 people per acre have access to parks vs. 40 people per acre citywide.

    Participants will:

    ·       be physically active

    ·       learn more social skills, working side by side with other gardeners

    ·       gain more knowledge about harvesting vegetables

    ·       have more opportunities to cook, prepare food, and try recipes in the school’s commercial kitchen

    ·       have the opportunity to try a large variety of vegetables, which are harvested only in the summer

    ·       continue to deepen their connection with nature, as they experience flora and fauna unique to the summer season

    ·       share their enthusiasm for nature and the garden with family and friends

    ·       have an extended period of time in the garden twice a week without being limited by a traditional school schedule

    ·       witness the operation of Cully Neighborhood Farm, which serves 32 CSA members

    ·       have access to the expertise of Matt Gordon, who runs Cully Neighborhood Farm

    ·       learn how to compost

    Risks & Challenges

    We are such a small organization, with limited resources, that it is challenging for us to get the word out about the program and thus secure funds to fulfill our mission.

    We know what the possibilities are for this program, and we know that with social media and things like a webpage, we could build up our financial resources.  Lack of time (we have to support ourselves by other means) and money (mostly to hire a grant writer) – those are what challenge us the most.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      1. pass on this link to as many people as you can - use the indiegogo share tools
      2. if you know of any organizations that would be potential donors, please let us know or contact them directly for us
      3. if you're unable to contribute monetarily but would still like to help, contact us about volunteering
      4. we can't emphasize enough how important it is for a campaign like this to get the word out in any way you can through social media, etc.

story:
About Me

My name is Deniece Brown, I am 17 years old and a junior in high school .I am an active participant of the Harlem Children's Zone at the Employment and Technology Center and I have also volunteered at many organizations including Saint Lukeâ€™s Hospital, the Foster Care Advocacy program, and Flying Manes. During my time at St. Luke's Hospital I worked in the rehabilitation center, I helped create a PSA for the Foster Care Advocacy program, and through Flying Manes I worked with horses as a method of communicating and improving the communication skills of children ages 4 through 14 with disabilities. My goals for this year include the opportunity to travel abroad and volunteer in another country while broadening my horizons and getting out of my comfort zone.  

Program Overview

Global Teens is a leadership development and service learning program that engages teenagers (ages 14-18) in a year-long empowering international experience, culminating with 2 weeks service abroad on July 15 - July 29, 2012. The program includes deep personal growth, discovery, cultural awareness, meaningful service, home stay experiences, and interaction with teens from around the globe. 

The Impact

I have been selected by the International YMCA to participate in the 2012 trip to Brazil, where myself and 15 other teens will have the privilege to do service work which will address poverty and environmental education. The need to understand the interdependency of the world's many cultures, communities and nations has never been more important.  

What I Need 

Although this is volunteer work, the International YMCA can only cover a portion of my trip, which cost $2800. I am charged with fundraising the remainder of the cost which includes the plane tickets, room, and food. With your support I will be able to gain a deepened sense of the social issues impacting our world, and explore methods for positively contributing to our global community. I plan to return and influence other teens to think of themselves as global citizens, infuse a desire to communicate across cultural lines and spark their interest in being civically responsible. I am do all that I can to fund raise this money by contacting city council members and government officials in NYC.  I would deeply appreciate your help to allow me to take part of this amazing life changing experience 

 

The cost for the trip will be distributed 

$200 Passport fess

$100 Travel bag

$300 emergency money 

$2,000 Plane ticket, Transportation

 

The remaining money will go to help to assist other YMCA global teens groups with fundraising.

The Most Important Thing Is What You'll Get  

Donate $10 I will Update You on my blog/websites while on my trip
Donate $20 I will send detailed pictures of  my volunteer experience in Brazil 
Donate $100 You Will get detailed pictures of my team's trip to Brazil as well as a video on DVD of my volunteer experiences with Global Teens. A tote bag with a custom made global teens team Brazil logo on it as well. as updating you on what I am experiencing daily while on my trip.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please Donate! I know that this site has a lot of campaigns and a lot of amazing opportunities but I will be making a wonderful influence in the world. If you can't afford to donate please pass this along to everyone, post on facebook, twitter, blogs. Remember no contribution is a too small or a too LARGE of a contribution.

home stay experiences, and interaction with teens from around the globe. 

The Impact
I have been selected by the International YMCA to participate in the 2012 trip to Brazil, where myself and 15 other teens will have the privilege to do service work which will address poverty and environmental education. The need to understand the interdependency of the world's many cultures, communities and nations has never been more important.  

What I Need 

Although this is volunteer work,
the International YMCA can only cover a portion of my trip, which cost $2800. I
am charged with fundraising the remainder of the cost which includes the plane tickets, room, and food. With your support I will
be able to gain a deepened sense of the social issues impacting our world, and
explore methods for positively contributing to our global community. I plan to
return and influence other teens to think of themselves as global citizens,
infuse a desire to communicate across cultural lines and spark their interest
in being civically responsible. I am do all that I can to fund raise this money by contacting city council members and government officials in NYC.  I would deeply appreciate your help to allow me to take part of this amazing life changing experience 

 
The cost for the trip will be distributed 
$200 Passport fess
$100 Travel bag
$300 emergency money 
$2,000 Plane ticket, Transportation
 
The remaining money will go to help to assist other YMCA global teens groups with fundraising.

The Most Important Thing Is What You'll Get  
Donate $10 I will Update You on my blog/websites while on my trip
Donate $20 I will send detailed pictures of  my volunteer experience in Brazil 
Donate $100 You Will get detailed pictures of my team's trip to Brazil as well as a video on DVD of my volunteer experiences with Global Teens. A tote bag with a custom made global teens team Brazil logo on it as well. as updating you on what I am experiencing daily while on my trip.




Other Ways You Can Help
Please Donate! I know that this site has a lot of campaigns and a lot of amazing opportunities but I will be making a wonderful influence in the world. If you can't afford to donate please pass this along to everyone, post on facebook, twitter, blogs. Remember no contribution is a too small or a too LARGE of a contribution.

story: A big thank you to everyone who helped with this campaign!
story_txt: A big thank you to everyone who helped with this campaign!

story:
PLEASE HELP THE FOLLOWING STUDENTS WITH THEIR NATIONALS TRIP:

Katarina Dewey

Sam Dugan

Kiersten Cleveland

Grace Elbert

Ellie McDearman

Amanda Jack

Brooke Hasl

Joie Filippini

 

The North Oldham High School Speech Team (which was founded in 2003 when the school opened) has had its MOST SUCCESSFUL SEASON YET!  We have grown from 3 members back in 2003 to 26 members this year (check out our page on Facebook to see pictures of the team members and notes on our competition season - the page is listed under 2012-2013 North Oldham High School Speech Team).  


We are currently:

TOP TEAM IN THE REGION--For the 2nd year in a row!

TOP TEN TEAM IN THE STATE--For the 2nd year in a row!

TENTH STRAIGHT YEAR SENDING STUDENTS TO NATIONALS!

 

And to think it all started in 2003 with a trio of students riding to a competition in a mini-van!  My, how we have grown!

 

We have traveled to many tournaments across the state this year and have placed in the top overall sweepstakes category at nearly every competition.  We have had high numbers of finalists each time and many repeat champions! 

This year, we are proud to have 8 NOHS students to represent our school and the KCFL state speech league at the National Grand Tournament in Philadelphia this coming Memorial Day weekend!

The students work throughout the year to raise money for the team.  Because we don't receive any funding whatsoever, we must work constantly to raise funds for competition fees, transportation, scripts and supplies, etc. 

We have membership fees, sell cookies/fruit/poinsettias, host a tournament, etc. And since we have 26 students on the team, our monetary needs have essentially doubled this year.  These students are continuing to do what they can when it comes to our fundraisers, but we REALLY need your help to not only get these EIGHT students to nationals, but also to get a head-start on our budget for next year.  We anticipate having 30 students on the team next year, so please do your part to help these students!

 

We are currently the NUMBER ONE team in our county, NUMBER ONE in our region, NUMBER FOUR with the KCFL state speech league, and NUMBER TEN in the state for the Kentucky HS Speech League! 

 

That's why we need YOUR HELP!  We are asking that you please donate to our cause--get these 8 students to nationals and also help us with next year's needs!  We are a small school and it is difficult to find sponsorships for our students--and they deserve this honor without having to worry about the money issue.

 

In short, we would be honored if you could donate and help these talented, honorable, sweet, wonderful students to be the best they can be--especially on the national level!  We will always make you proud!

 

SPECIAL NOTE:  If you are an alumni member of a speech team, then you especially know the importance of keeping our funds up for the season!  I am hoping that my former team members (from both BGHS AND NOHS) will help us for sure!

 

The Impact

Coach Cundiff-Brown speaking here:

 

I believe in the importance of competitive speech activities.  I fell in love with the activity when I was in the 6th grade.  I went on to compete on the middle school, high school, and college levels.  And I have been coaching speech teams since 1999.  From my wonderful students at Bowling Green High School to my most recent speech team kiddos at North Oldham High School, I consider it an HONOR to be a part of these students' lives. 

 

Being a part of the speech team is not just about competition--sure, the trophies are nice to have, but it teaches so many other positive things.  I can honestly say that the speech team community is a family.   And once you become a part of that activity, you have lifelong family members that support, love, and keep you in their hearts.  Speech also does SO MUCH for a person's confidence.  Many of us who now are coaches were speech team members in middle and high school in our home towns.  Some of us even competed on the college level.  Once you are a part of the speech team community, you never truly leave it.  The confidence you receive from being a part of speech is a major factor.  You use the public speaking skills forever in both your personal and career paths.  And we have all different types of students in this activity--that's the beauty of it.  It is an accepting, warm, and special team to be a part of for the rest of your life. 

 

Most of our students go on to college and pursue majors in everything from communications to teaching to engineering to nursing.  They go to college with confidence and determination.  And after having spent thousands of hours preparing and competing in the speech world, they know that the speech world has better prepared them for the real world.  We are proud that our students are Rhodes Scholars, Governor's School for the Arts students, Governor's Scholars, National Merit Scholars, and Gold Key Art students.   And, of course, regional and state champs--and now headed for nationals!  We are proud that we have had students compete on the national level every year since 2003.  We have had team members reach the semi-final round of competition on the national level--always a feat!

 

Our students compete in 12 various events--and many of them are triple or quadruple entered at each tournament!  All while maintaining their GPA status and other commitments!

 

As their mentor, I am truly proud that they are kindhearted, caring, giving people who are a joy to coach and call a part of my family!  I can't imagine my life without it.  But we can't do it without your monetary help--so please support us!

 

What We Need

The costs of these tournaments include travel expenses, entry fees, hotels, and food.  Any leftover monies will be utilized for next year's competition season.  We can certainly go over our requested fundraising amount--and hope we do so!  Every dollar makes a difference!

The $3,000 we are asking for would cover the hotel costs and airfare for our 8 students competing at the NCFL Grand Nationals Tournament in Philadelphia May 23-26, 2013.  Philly is an expensive place to visit--and we are not allowed to drive due to school board rules and regulations. 

We would appreciate your help--

And if we happen to raise more than $3,000 we will use the extra money to offset our upcoming expenses for next year (we typically need up to $10,000 to operate for the year).

story: Hello! My name is Jenna! I am a 27 year old senior at Cal State Fullerton. I will be earning my degree in Child and Adolescent studies in the spring. Also I have just been recently engaged to my fiance Joe. I was also recently accepted to the Masters of Socisl Work Program at Cal State Fullerton. I am the first one to go to college in my family, and I have continied to work two to three jobs in order to pay my way through school. I recently found out that when Joe and I have our wedding in March of 2014, we will not be able to go on a honeymoon, because I will be in the midst of my graduate program. Cal State Fullerton is offering a senior trip to Europe, but I figured that I did not want to go one my own without my fiance for ten days, so I really thought nothing of it. Upon calling the organization putting it on, they said Joe is more than welcome to come. Now I am just trying to come up with the money. This could be the most amazing opportunity of a lifetime as well as the perfect honeymoon. My paypal information is aerodarln@yahoo.com and even $1 is so greatly appreciated. Thank you for reading my story all I ask is that you pass it on if you could.

story:
My name is Tobias Hallwood, I am British/American and I am an international school teacher. I have spent my most of life living and traveling overseas. During this time I have been privileged to meet and work with some amazing people.  It is one such person that has inspired me to start this campaign to help him. I spent two years living in Niamey, Niger working at the American International School of Niamey. During my time there I met a man named Boubacar Oumarou, who was the school’s physical education and math teacher.  From the beginning of our friendship I knew Oumarou was not just passionate about education, but determined to help his community however he could.

In one of the first conversations Oumarou said to me “I want to start a school in my village, Dogondoutchi, because I would like to help the people to be more educated in my community so that we can contribute to the development of our humanity.”

Over the two years that I worked with Oumarou he talked about starting a school in his village Dogondoutchi, to provide an education for the children their and a place for them to go. At that time children had to travel long distances to go to school. It just so happened that the year I left Niamey, Oumarou decided to follow his dream and start this school. He was not sure how he was going to do it or where the money was going to come from, but none of that mattered because he knew it was what his community needed.

Oumarou was able to open a school for the younger children of his village on January 3rd 2015, thanks to some small contributions locally but he is struggling to support the school and provide the ALL children of his village the education they deserve. This is where you come in!

I am trying to help him raise $25,000 to have a building, pay the staff and buy educational materials for the school. Here is the breakdown of costs that was given to me

Buildings 
Rental for the first year: $1780
Construct their own building: $5000 
Total: $6780

Educational Materials:
Books: $1000
Writing Materials: $500
Classroom Furniture: $2000
Whiteboards/Blackboards: $500
Art Supplies: $500
Sports Equipment:$500
Computers and Printers: $1000
Total: $6000

Annual Salary Breakdown:
- Principle/Director: $2800
- Classroom Teacher 1: $3600
- Classroom Teacher2: $3600
- Custodian: $1500
- Security Guard: $1500
Total: $13,000

Grand Total: 25,780 

I will be transferring all of the money raised into the schools bank account with Eco Bank in Niger.

I know $25,000 might seem like a lot but when you break everything down and look at what it is for it almost does not seem like enough.

I would love to be able to get Oumarou and the school the entire $25,000 but whatever money we can raise I know they will be grateful for and will use it to help the school by buying supplies and paying the staff.

story:
Little Free Libraries

Hi.  So I'm Runa, and as you may already know, I'm excessively enthusiastic about libraries and community access to literacy.  I've decided to participate in the Project for Awesome for the first time this year, setting up an IndieGoGo for one my favorite projects, Little Free Libraries.  

Little Free Libraries are free, public book boxes where any member of a community can take a book and leave a book.  It's a book swap that enables people who may not otherwise have had access to books a place where they can find books to own.   The project is run by Little Free Library, Ltd, a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.  Every LFL I have ever visited had high quality novels, picture books, non-fiction, popular fiction, pretty much anything in print that you could find at a library.  Community members are responsible for maintaining their own LFLs and these can often turn into community hubs.  


You may NOT know that Little Free Libraries also run some other projects that spread access to literacy in communities.  They have programs where they set up LFLs in high-need communities, in rural communities who may not have access to a full-sized public library, in communities with large populations of elderly people, and more!  

Any program that brings literacy to a place where literacy may not have previously been an important factor is invaluable to me, and I hope you feel the same way.  As a child growing up in a low-income family, I didn't own very many books of my own.  The public library is always a great resource for borrowing books temporarily, but I know getting to have my own, personal copies meant a lot to me, and having a community hub like a Little Free Library book exchange box would have been a source of great joy and excitement.

Funding

All of the money raised from this campaign is going directly to Little Free Library, Ltd.  The perks are all being donated, shipping and materials will be completely out of pocket.   I'm not expecting to raise $500, that's just IndieGoGo's minimum, but every little bit is appreciated!

Perks & descriptions are all on the side, hope you decide to participate-->

Other Ways You Can Help

Find a Little Free Library in your area!  Swap books with cool people!   

If one doesn't exist where you live, consider becoming a steward and setting up your own.  The Little Free Library website goes into great detail about what's involved in creating your own LFL!  

(It might be a cool idea to get your local nerdfighter group together to fund and create your own Little Free Library, if you're up for that!  )

story:
Short Summary

The Harvard Prize Book Program was established by Harvard alumni in 1910 as part of an effort to attract the attention of talented young students to the opportunities at the College. Today, nearly 2,000 Prize Books, sponsored by local Harvard alumni, are awarded in schools all over the world. The Harvard Prize Book is also an important way for the Native American Alumni of Harvard University to recognize the achievements of high school students in Indian Country who have made positive contributions to their school and community.

What We Need & What You Get

To establish a Prize Book award, a NAAHU member need only contribute the cost of one book.

  • The cost for supporting sponsorship of one school's Prize Book is $35.
  • The more funds we raise the greater impact we will be able to have on schools throughout Indian Country.
  • Last year NAAHU awarded Prize Books at 17 schools across the nation. This year we aim to expand the program to over 20 schools. 
  • Any funds raised will go directly to supporting the Prize Book program for the 2014-2015 academic year and to support the program in future years.

The Impact

As was defined by the Harvard Alumni Association, the Prize Book is awarded to the outstanding student in the next-to-graduating class who 'displays excellence in scholarship and high character, combined with achievement in other fields.' The winners of this award, through their intelligence and variety of achievement, exemplify Harvard's commitment to excellence.  As former dean of Harvard College Fred Jewett has said the Harvard Prize Book is "one of the highest awards a school can make to a student." Additionally, the award helps raise the profile of an Ivy League education, oftentimes prompting talented juniors to apply to prominent universities (and especially Harvard), which they might not have otherwise considered prior to receiving the Prize Book.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute online or would like to contribute to the program in another way please feel free to contact us at naahu@post.harvard.edu

  • Feel free to ask others to contribute to this campaign.
  • You can find out more information about the Harvard Prize Book Program on our website at: http://www.naahu.org/

Thank you for your support!!

story:
THE IDEA

Children deserve to play. Children also deserve to feel like they can save the world.  Help make these two ideas can happen through the purchase of play-therapy supplies and the creation of children’s books made specifically for Caribbean children with disabilities.  Your contributions will give the residents of a foster home for disabled children in Grenada the chance to have toys that both accommodate their limitations and empower them towards positive change.

 

THE BACKGROUND

Sacha Lewis-Stott and Alli Cost organized this project after working and falling in love with these incredible children in Grenada. Sacha is a special education coordinator who spent two years directing the early intervention outreach program which served families from all over Grenada. Alli is an occupational therapist who has worked with the Dorothy Hopkin Centre for the Disabled designing and implementing therapy programs for residents, while also training staff, teachers, and parents.

The Dorothy Hopkin Centre is a foster home for individuals with disabilities.  The diagnoses are varied, ranging from mental retardation, Down’s syndrome, seizure disorders, autism, cerebral palsy, hearing/speech/visual impairments, and genetic abnormalities. This broad array in the severity and type of impairments leads to challenges in creating appropriate play activities that address several residents at once.

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHY

TOYS…so that I can play!

Children use play not only to explore, but also to strengthen their bodies and improve their brain functioning. Play teaches us how to relate with others, problem solve, and interact with the world around us.  

People have good intentions when they donate toys, but most of these residents need toys that are relevant to their specific limitation and strength. For example, it’s hard to know what an ideal toy or tool is for a child who has a type of cerebral palsy that makes it hard for her to use her hands or sit up on her own.

Most of the residents remain at the center long term due to the severity of their disabilities limiting independent living. This is their home and their family; their whole life. Immediate needs of food, shelter, and safety are taken care of by the loving staff. But due to lack of appropriate play items for the residents, there is minimal time spent moving and playing effectively. Your contributions will provide the supplies to create a play area that facilitates therapeutic improvement of speech, language, and physical skills, along with opportunities for positive staff/volunteer and resident interaction.

BOOKS…so that I can save the day!

Stories help us define how we see the world and its potential. Think about the books you read as a child and identified with. Now consider how much more challenging that would be if all the characters you encountered looked, moved, and thought differently from you. Reading a book that’s actually about you provides a sense of power, identity, and belonging in the world.

Although there are a few books with main characters that are disabled, they often focus on the impairment by showing how these “types” of kids fit in, rather than simply having one that is different. And there aren’t any books specifically about Caribbean children with disabilities.

Displaced children, such as those living in orphanages or foster homes like Dorothy Hopkin Centre, often grow up without a secure sense of a family, home or self-identity. Having a disability further challenges the creation of a positive, empowering identity. I want to give these children the opportunity to see themselves in a way that I see them: as independent beautiful individuals who have the ability to solve problems, connect, and grow in their own unique way.

There will be 4 stories in total, at reading levels accommodating the ability of the residents. Three will be at a 1st grade reading level and one at a 3rd grade reading level.  They will be distributed not only to the residents but also to their schoolteachers so as to allow for educational use. The characters will be based directly off the children at the center. Each book will demonstrate the skills of exploration, self-expression, and problem solving, while being written in a format to facilitate therapeutic and educational use. All of the books will have a page at the end with suggestions for staff and teachers as to how to further discuss the topic and utilize the lessons in real life.

  • Story 1 will be about the children going on walk and identifying local animals and structures, and then using their imagination to see jungle animals and adventures.  This encourages the skill of abstract thinking and safety.
  • Story 2 will be focused on a dance class, it will show different ways that each person dances. This teaches children about different movement patterns and body awareness.
  • Story 3 will be built around the cultural events of Grenada and the feelings and activities they encompass. This facilitates children’s self-regulation through sensory preferences and cultural awareness.
  • Story 4 will be the higher level (3rd grade) book and directed at issues facing females in the Caribbean. This teaches women’s empowerment as tangible solutions rather than just a list of issues.

Budget

Item

Notes

Cost

Publishing books

From artbookbindery.com and distributed not only to the residents but their teachers, the local library, and special education schools around the island.

$700

Center-wide play toys

Items that several/all children will play with such as door swings, mini-trampoline, roller-boards, marker spots, therapy balls, pop up tents, etc.

$1000

Individual specific toys

One therapeutic toy for each resident such as a body sox for a child with autism, corner seats (made by local carpenter) to allow child with cerebral palsy to sit up, and cause-and-effect toys for young children without full hand function.

$800

Shipping

Cost to bring the items.

$500

 

Total

$3000

 

WHAT YOU GET!

Besides the delightful sense of doing something good for the less fortunate, look over to the right and read through the list of perks possible with each contribution.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We completely understand that everyone's financial situation is different. If you aren’t able to contribute financially at this time, you can still help out the project. Let other folks know about the campaign and encourage them to contribute by posting a note on facebook, sharing it in an email, or simply mentioning it to folks in random conversations.
story_txt:
THE IDEA
Children deserve to play. Children also deserve to feel like they can save the world.  Help make these two ideas can happen through the purchase of play-therapy supplies and the creation of children’s books made specifically for Caribbean children with disabilities.  Your contributions will give the residents of a foster home for disabled children in Grenada the chance to have toys that both accommodate their limitations and empower them towards positive change.
 
THE BACKGROUND
Sacha Lewis-Stott and Alli Cost organized this project after working and falling in love with these incredible children in Grenada. Sacha is a special education coordinator who spent two years directing the early intervention outreach program which served families from all over Grenada. Alli is an occupational therapist who has worked with the Dorothy Hopkin Centre for the Disabled designing and implementing therapy programs for residents, while also training staff, teachers, and parents.
The Dorothy Hopkin Centre is a foster home for individuals with disabilities.  The diagnoses are varied, ranging from mental retardation, Down’s syndrome, seizure disorders, autism, cerebral palsy, hearing/speech/visual impairments, and genetic abnormalities. This broad array in the severity and type of impairments leads to challenges in creating appropriate play activities that address several residents at once.
 
WHAT WE NEED AND WHY
TOYS…so that I can play!
Children use play not only to explore, but also to strengthen their bodies and improve their brain functioning. Play teaches us how to relate with others, problem solve, and interact with the world around us.

Story 1 will be about the children going on walk and identifying local animals and structures, and then using their imagination to see jungle animals and adventures.  This encourages the skill of abstract thinking and safety.
Story 2 will be focused on a dance class, it will show different ways that each person dances. This teaches children about different movement patterns and body awareness.
Story 3 will be built around the cultural events of Grenada and the feelings and activities they encompass. This facilitates children’s self-regulation through sensory preferences and cultural awareness.
Story 4 will be the higher level (3rd grade) book and directed at issues facing females in the Caribbean. This teaches women’s empowerment as tangible solutions rather than just a list of issues.

Item


Notes


Cost




Publishing books


From artbookbindery.com and distributed not only to the residents but their teachers, the local library, and special education schools around the island.


$700




Center-wide play toys


Items that several/all children will play with such as door swings, mini-trampoline, roller-boards, marker spots, therapy balls, pop up tents, etc.


$1000




Individual specific toys


One therapeutic toy for each resident such as a body sox for a child with autism, corner seats (made by local carpenter) to allow child with cerebral palsy to sit up, and cause-and-effect toys for young children without full hand function.

story:
UPDATE:::: We are so incredible thankful for the unbelievable support we have received from everyone.  Unfortunately, due to being so far away from reaching our goal, we have made the very difficult decision to supsend our indiegogo campaign and are no longer taking donations.  If you have made a donation, and would like your money refunded, please contact us at info@campcommonplace.com.  We are going to donate the money we have raised on here to the Hetrick Martin Institute (HMI), which is a NYC based organization that works with LGBTQ youth, where most of our campers were coming from.  HMI's Homeless Project provides LGBTQ Youth with one-on-one counseling and group support, referrals, meals, hot showers, clothing and laundry and assistance in locating housing. Camp will not be taking place this summer, but please, please look for us in Summer 2014!  Again, we thank you for your support and we look forward to bringing this amazing camp to life next summer!~ Alicia, Elsa and Amanda

 

 

 

Camp Common Place began as a big idea...A really, REALLY big idea!  Amanda and Elsa (Alicia joined later) sat in a little NYC coffee shop and what began as a simple conversation turned into a plan...A really, REALLY, big plan. After sharing our own camp experiences, we came to the realization that there weren't too many options for summer camps in the New York area for LGBTQ (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Questioning) & Straight- Ally youth.  So, we decided that we wanted to start a summer camp for LGBTQ & Straight-Ally Youth. Easy, right? This idea felt like a natural progression and fit with the mission of the youth development organization that we work for, The Leadership Program (TLP).  To give you a little background, TLP works with over 20,000 underserved urban youth in New York City Public Schools every year. As a leading youth development provider, we have seen the detrimental effects of sexual orientation bullying and cyber bullying first hand in the school and communities we work in:

  • Eight of ten LGBTQ students have been verbally harassed at school;

  • Four of ten have been physically harassed at school;

  • Six of ten felt unsafe at school; and

  • One of five have been the victim of a physical assault at school

(Based on a 2009 study conducted by the CDC)

We also had the opportunity to focus more closely on this topic when we were asked to contribute to the resource section of Dan Savage’s book, It Gets Better: Coming Out, Overcoming Bullying, and Creating a Life Worth Living.  Our mission is to create a safe and supportive environment where youth can be themselves.

We've been working over the past year to get this camp off the ground, and are very excited that Camp Common Place will have its first summer session this coming July 29th-August 4th 2013!

Now a little bit about our camp.  Camp Common Place is a residential summer camp for youth ages 13-17. We focus on traditional camp activities in an environment that celebrates LGBTQ & Straight-Ally youth. Our camp activities are designed to be interactive and to help each camper enhance their self-confidence, independence and awareness. Our team of enthusiastic, nurturing and dedicated staff bring their intensely creative energy and heart to the development, facilitation and supervision of youth programs. 

Camp will take place at the Ramapo for Children campground located in the Hudson Valley region of New York State. The campground offers 250-acres of scenic wooded lakefront views. The facilities are modern and include outdoor and indoor spaces for a variety of activities including challenge ropes, fields for sports, a pool and a private fresh water lake for swimming, canoeing or kayaking, and much more.

Here’s how you can help:  We will be hosting 50 campers this summer and we have set up this campaign to help provide scholarships for those kids who may not have the financial resources to attend camp. With your help, we are hoping to provide (20) campers with full scholarships and also allow campers to attend camp on a sliding scale.  Any amount helps and is greatly appreciated.

On behalf of the Leadership Program and Camp Common Place, we want to thank you for your support and help for making camp possible for our campers! Now let's send some kids to camp!

 

 

* If we do not receive enough funding for CCP scholarships, funds will be put towards our youth development programs with underserved urban youth in NYC schools. For more information on our programs, please visit www.theleadershipprogram.com

story:
ATTENTION: All donations can be made anonymously. See instructions in your emailed receipt. Thank you.

NEWS ON TRIP:

The previous trip I was going on through KIIS was cancelled due to students backing out, and as a result there were not enough people to meet the requirements. However, I have found another program through USAC. The changes in location, funds needed, and deadlines are listed below.

New location: Chengdu, China (成都, 中国）

New amount needed due to program change: $3,000. Due to Indiegogo's stipulations i could not change the goal. So, feel free to donate beyond the set goal :)

New Deadline for total payment to USAC: May 1st. If I do not reach my goal, I will post another fundraiser before then. 

Sorry for all of the confusion.

NOW FOR THE GOOD STUFF!

Who I Am

My name is Jesse Burleson (薄杰斯）. I am a junior at Middle Tennessee State University. I am an English writing major, and a Global Studies minor.

Traveling the world has always been a dream of mine, and China in particular has taken a special place in my heart. 

By donating to this fund you can be a part by helping me gain more insight into the Chinese culture, build upon my existing skills the Chinese language, and fulfill my Global Studies field experience requirement.

The Trip, and It's Impact

I have always had a curious spirit which has motivated me to learn about other nations and their people in order to capture the beauty of these cultures, and bring them home. As a writer, this opportunity is a tremendous start for this process.

I will arrive in Chengdu China in Sichuan province on May 24th. After settling in for a couple days I will start my month long studies which include: Intermediate Chinese 1, a Chinese Conversation course, and a study of Chinese Culture and Social Cognition. These course credits will help me gain insight into China's culture, and also go towards my English BA major and my Global Studies Minor helping me graduate even sooner! After 5 weeks of studying in China I will return to the US around July 6th.

This journey will not only engulf me in the Chinese culture, but also serve as a foot in the door for future endeavours in China where I hope to one day teach English.

Needs

Overall trip is going to cost me around 7 1/2 thousand dollors. Through scholarships and a student loan I have payed for a little more than half of it. My airfare still remains which is somewhere between $2,100-2,500 along with about another $750 due to the differences in housing, meals;etc between the programs. What you donate will literally make my way to the beautiful land of China.

If I reach or even exceed my goal, all of the money will being going towards my airfare and other educational costs; however, 4% will be go to Indiegogo, and another 3% will be given to the card companies for processing fees. If I do not meet my goal, 9% of any money raised will go to Indiegogo along with the additional 3% for processing. So what do you say, will you help me reach my goal?

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute  financially, you can help by spreading the word! I can use all the help I can get! So, if you will share this on Facebook, through e-mail, or even just by word of mouth it would help my cause tremendously. Any and all you do is appreciated.

 

Thank you very much,

Jesse Burleson.

谢谢，

薄杰嘶。

story:
Update 24th December: the campaign has finished! Thanks to everyone who contributed. Now follow us at www.linuxvoice.com

Announcing Linux Voice

We were the majority of the editorial team behind Linux Format magazine.

Over many years, we helped make our title the market leader. We interviewed everyone we could think of, crammed each issue full of tutorials, reviews and thought-provoking features, and spread the good word about Linux, open source and Free Software.

We were the first to cover the Raspberry Pi from the newsstand. We beat the C.I.A. before it was cool. We sent a comfort package to Edward Snowden, and taught the world how easy servers were to hack (er, sorry, crack). Our fortnightly TuxRadar podcast entertained thousands of insightful and generous listeners, and we loved every minute of it.



Last month we quit, and we quit because we wanted to do something different. We want to create an even better magazine; a bigger, more entertaining and more accountable magazine for the community we love to serve. The magazine we want to make is called Linux Voice.



Who we are

Graham Morrison is the former Editor of Linux Format. He worked on the magazine for nine years after starting out as its staff writer in 2004. He also has a slight obsession with analogue synthesizers.
Graham's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format


Andrew Gregory is the former Deputy Editor and Operations Editor of Linux Format. He dreamt up many of the ideas that went into the magazine, and also wrote tutorials, features and the news section.
Andrew's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format


Mike Saunders has written for Linux Format since the very first issue, and also worked as the New Media and Communities Editor. He's a passionate Free Software developer and still plays Frontier.
Mike's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format


Ben Everard worked on Linux Format for two years, writing features, reviews and tutorials, and creating the software-packed DVD that came with the mag. He has helped to spread Free Software in the developing world.
Ben's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format


What makes Linux Voice different?

  • We want to give something back. 50% of our profits will go back to Free Software and Linux communities, and our readership will choose where the money goes. We want to sponsor projects, events, developers, and evangelise the cause. We want to build long-term relationships with the people we sponsor, so there's less uncertainty for projects year-on-year.
  • Our first issue will be better than any other Linux and Free Software magazine. We've got the brain share, the provenance and an unrivalled motivation to succeed. We know our readership, which is why our focus will always be on the quality of content. We've been bucking the trend of declining print sales for years, and we're not going to stop now by messing around with the magic formula. We want to make a larger magazine with a broader scope and more representative content. We want to be fair and accurate. We want to be the voice of the Linux and open source community, but above all, we want to help that community to grow.
  • Our pricing will always be fair. Magazines are expensive to create (see FAQ for more details), but we want to remove much of the mystery. We're going to charge a flat rate for a baseline print or digital subscription and only charge cost for distribution. This won’t make our magazine dramatically cheaper in the UK, where we're based, but it will make the magazine much cheaper elsewhere. We won't have community sapping fire sales or unpredictable marketing strategies. The price we charge is the cost of making the best magazine we can, and nothing else.
  • Our content will be published for free after 9 months, and we aim to use an open source/Creative Commons licence. We want to create a library of our tutorials, interviews, features and code that is accessible to everyone, whether that's a Python tutorial for a 10 hour flight, or a Raspberry Pi class guide for a school club. We don't believe in charging several times for the same 'evergreen' content. UPDATE: We've committed to making all the content available under CC-BY-SA after nine months. For more details see our blog here.


(Sample tutorial - click for bigger)


What you'll get

You can buy a print or digital subscription to Linux Voice now (see the list of perks on the right) and help to fund the launch of the magazine in February. You'll get:

  • 12 issues a year
  • 116 pages in each issue
  • 100,000 words of incredible content each month

We will offer significant discounts to organisations, user groups, universities and non-profits.

We will make the podcast a central part of Linux Voice. We’d like to expand the format to include many of the ideas our listeners have contributed over the 6 years we’ve been recording; interviews, location recording and guest contributors. We also promise to be more punctual, but we can’t promise to always complete our challenges.

The podcast will always be free and released under the terms of a Creative Commons licence.



Endorsements

Nick Veitch, creator of Linux Format: "A group of my ex-colleagues have decided to create their own magazine. They're going to dedicate a huge slice of their profits back into the community. I think that's a great idea, and that's why I'm signing up to a lifetime subscription..." (See more)


Jono Bacon, Ubuntu Community Manager: "I know the guys looking to crowd-fund Linux Voice magazine - they are good guys, great writers, and have a wonderful idea - go and support them. This could revolutionize how magazines are created and shared with others." (Jono on Google+)


Simon Phipps, President of the Open Source Initiative: "I'm looking forward to getting my first copy of Linux Voice. The team behind it has been a key part of the open source publishing world for years, and this project hits all the right notes for relevant high quality content, digital rights of readers and fair compensation to contributors."


Philip Newborough, CrunchBang Linux creator: "The idea of Linux Voice, a truly independent Linux magazine, is an exciting prospect for the Linux ecosystem. Profit sharing aside, the wide exposure that print magazines can provide is invaluable. The CrunchBang community recognises this fact (having had the distro reviewed and featured on cover disks in the past) and we're happy to support the campaign by advertising it on the CrunchBang website."


Les Pounder, OggCamp: "It's good to see the team back together and eager to start on their ambitious project. The OggCamp team fully supports Linux Voice and their endeavour to produce a magazine for the FOSS community. Good luck to them all."


Eben Upton (sporting a lustrous moustache in aid of Movember), Founder of the Raspberry Pi Foundation: "The Linux Voice team has a fantastic background in the world of free and open source software, and shares the same ethos as Raspberry Pi - that computing should be open, and that cost shouldn't be a barrier to access. I'm very much looking forward to my first copy."


Karen Sandler, Executive Director of the Gnome Foundation: "The guys at Linux Voice are dangerously fun to talk to - you can easily forget you're being interviewed! Congrats on your new gig, I look forward to following it!"


And our appearances around the web...

  • The Guardian - Greenslade Blog
  • MVC - The Market for Computer and Video Games
  • journalism.co.uk (includes interview with Andrew Gregory)
  • betanews (includes interview with Ben Everard)
  • Podcast: LINUX Unplugged 14 (Ben is 2 minutes in)
  • iTWire - Latest IT News and Information
  • BITblokes (German Linux news website)
  • Muktware - Web magazine for Linux and open source users
  • Techrights - People's rights in the digital age
  • The Register - Biting the hand that feeds IT


FAQ

Q. Isn't the print and magazine business dead?

A. No. Our previous magazine grew its print circulation last year, making it one of only a handful of publications to do so in the UK. If you’ve got a strong community and low overheads, there’s no reason why a magazine like Linux Voice can’t flourish.


Q. When will you get the first issue out?

A. We're already working on it, and depending on print schedules, we'd like to get our first issue in the post in February 2014.


Q. Will Linux Voice be available in shops and newsagents?

A. Yes. We want it to be. But the big shops won't listen to us until we’ve got plenty of readers. This campaign will solve that problem and we’ll be able to negotiate with them after a successful campaign. And if you want to sell our magazine in your own store, get in touch!


Q. Will Linux Voice include a DVD?

A. We'd love to have a DVD packed with distros, software, video tutorials, magazine articles and more. But DVDs take extra time and money to make, so we need to gauge interest first: if you're interested, please let us know in the comments tab above and we'll add a perk later in the campaign.


Q. Will you create an interactive HTML 5/Ubuntu/Android/iOS/Windows 8 app for digital magazine delivery?

A. We will get our magazine onto digital storefronts straight away. And we have ambitious plans for our own app - one where our community becomes part of the editorial. But to start with, we need to focus on getting our new magazine out of our heads and into your hands. We’ll then be able to invest in our other ideas.


Q. Why can't you commit to releasing your content under an open source/Creative Commons licence now?

A. We want to talk to our contributors first. Our competitors take copyright ownership over the content they commission, and we'd like to do the right thing and give this back to our authors. That means we'll then need their permission if we release their work under a Creative Commons licence.


Q: When distribution is effectively free, why are the digital subscription prices so expensive?

A. Print and distribution is only a relatively small part of the overall expense. To show our commitment to transparency, and also address what seems a popular misconception, here’s our estimated costs for a single issue:

  • Contributors: We pay a typical rate of £100 per page to our contributors, and we’ll need around 44 pages of content not written by ourselves each issue. That’s £4,400.
  • Design/Art: It’s a skilled full time job designing and laying out a magazine and we need to work with someone awesome who understands our style and content. We estimate that person will cost £2,500 per month. Plus, we’ll need additional artwork for the cover and features. A typical issue would require around £400 of art, bringing the Design/Art total to £2,900.
  • Hardware/software: We’re going to need a bare minimum of equipment, plus the software. Our estimates for a year put this at £8,000, which divides down to £666 per issue.

That’s a grand total of £7,966 per issue. Divide this by the 2,000 subscribers we need for a successful campaign and we have a per issue cost of £3.98.

This price doesn’t include printing, distribution, VAT or the percentage taken by app stores, PayPal and Indiegogo. Nor does it include our salaries, but we’re obviously hoping to attract more subscribers over the twelve months following a successful campaign.


Q: Will the magazine be produced using open source software?

A. Initially, for speed and efficiency, we need to use what we used before, and that's Adobe InDesign. But we want to make a commitment to work with free software projects such as Inkscape and Scribus with the intention of migrating from proprietary software when it’s feasible to do so.


Q: I've never heard of the previous magazine you allude to. How can I trust you?

A. Read the stuff we've written over the last thirteen years. Read the Google Play reviews written prior to our departure (September/October 2013). Listen to the things we've said, listen to our previous podcasts and read the comments. Linux Voice is going to be even better.


Q: I already have a subscription to another magazine. What can I do?

A. Contact their customer support lines. In many cases you can cancel an existing subscription. For Future magazines, for example, phone 0844 848 2852 (UK) or +44 1604 251 045 (international). If your subscription is with Imagine Publishing, call +44 (0)1202 586200.


Q: Why can I only pay with PayPal?

A. That's just a limitation of Indiegogo with fixed funding.


Q. Is Graham Morrison involved in this campaign?

A. Graham Morrison, the editor of our previous magazine, quit at the same time but a restrictive covenant in his employment contract means he can't be involved in any similar activity until 20th December 2013. Update (20/12/2013): Graham has joined the team! Yippeee!
story_txt:
Update 24th December: the campaign has finished! Thanks to everyone who contributed. Now follow us at www.linuxvoice.com

Announcing Linux VoiceWe were the majority of the editorial team behind Linux Format magazine.Over many years, we helped make our title the market leader. We interviewed everyone we could think of, crammed each issue full of tutorials, reviews and thought-provoking features, and spread the good word about Linux, open source and Free Software.We were the first to cover the Raspberry Pi from the newsstand. We beat the C.I.A. before it was cool. We sent a comfort package to Edward Snowden, and taught the world how easy servers were to hack (er, sorry, crack). Our fortnightly TuxRadar podcast entertained thousands of insightful and generous listeners, and we loved every minute of it.Last month we quit, and we quit because we wanted to do something different. We want to create an even better magazine; a bigger, more entertaining and more accountable magazine for the community we love to serve. The magazine we want to make is called Linux Voice.Who we areGraham Morrison is the former Editor of Linux Format. He worked on the magazine for nine years after starting out as its staff writer in 2004. He also has a slight obsession with analogue synthesizers.Graham's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format
Andrew Gregory is the former Deputy Editor and Operations Editor of Linux Format. He dreamt up many of the ideas that went into the magazine, and also wrote tutorials, features and the news section.Andrew's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format
Mike Saunders has written for Linux Format since the very first issue, and also worked as the New Media and Communities Editor. He's a passionate Free Software developer and still plays Frontier.Mike's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format
Ben Everard worked on Linux Format for two years, writing features, reviews and tutorials, and creating the software-packed DVD that came with the mag. He has helped to spread Free Software in the developing world.Ben's articles on TechRadar | Linux Format
What makes Linux Voice different?
We want to give something back. 50% of our profits will go back to Free Software and Linux communities, and our readership will choose where the money goes. We want to sponsor projects, events, developers, and evangelise the cause. We want to build long-term relationships with the people we sponsor, so there's less uncertainty for projects year-on-year. 
Our first issue will be better than any other Linux and Free Software magazine. We've got the brain share, the provenance and an unrivalled motivation to succeed. We know our readership, which is why our focus will always be on the quality of content. We've been bucking the trend of declining print sales for years, and we're not going to stop now by messing around with the magic formula. We want to make a larger magazine with a broader scope and more representative content. We want to be fair and accurate. We want to be the voice of the Linux and open source community, but above all, we want to help that community to grow.
Our pricing will always be fair. Magazines are expensive to create (see FAQ for more details), but we want to remove much of the mystery. We're going to charge a flat rate for a baseline print or digital subscription and only charge cost for distribution. This won’t make our magazine dramatically cheaper in the UK, where we're based, but it will make the magazine much cheaper elsewhere. We won't have community sapping fire sales or unpredictable marketing strategies. The price we charge is the cost of making the best magazine we can, and nothing else.
Our content will be published for free after 9 months, and we aim to use an open source/Creative Commons licence. We want to create a library of our tutorials, interviews, features and code that is accessible to everyone, whether that's a Python tutorial for a 10 hour flight, or a Raspberry Pi class guide for a school club. We don't believe in charging several times for the same 'evergreen' content. UPDATE: We've committed to making all the content available under CC-BY-SA after nine months. For more details see our blog here.(Sample tutorial - click for bigger)
What you'll get
You can buy a print or digital subscription to Linux Voice now (see the list of perks on the right) and help to fund the launch of the magazine in February. You'll get:
12 issues a year116 pages in each issue100,000 words of incredible content each monthWe will offer significant discounts to organisations, user groups, universities and non-profits.
We will make the podcast a central part of Linux Voice. We’d like to expand the format to include many of the ideas our listeners have contributed over the 6 years we’ve been recording; interviews, location recording and guest contributors. We also promise to be more punctual, but we can’t promise to always complete our challenges.
The podcast will always be free and released under the terms of a Creative Commons licence.

Endorsements
Nick Veitch, creator of Linux Format: "A group of my ex-colleagues have decided to create their own magazine. They're going to dedicate a huge slice of their profits back into the community. I think that's a great idea, and that's why I'm signing up to a lifetime subscription..." (See more)
Jono Bacon, Ubuntu Community Manager: "I know the guys looking to crowd-fund Linux Voice magazine - they are good guys, great writers, and have a wonderful idea - go and support them. This could revolutionize how magazines are created and shared with others." (Jono on Google+)
Simon Phipps, President of the Open Source Initiative: "I'm looking forward to getting my first copy of Linux Voice. The team behind it has been a key part of the open source publishing world for years, and this project hits all the right notes for relevant high quality content, digital rights of readers and fair compensation to contributors."
Philip Newborough, CrunchBang Linux creator: "The idea of Linux Voice, a truly independent Linux magazine, is an exciting prospect for the Linux ecosystem. Profit sharing aside, the wide exposure that print magazines can provide is invaluable. The CrunchBang community recognises this fact (having had the distro reviewed and featured on cover disks in the past) and we're happy to support the campaign by advertising it on the CrunchBang website."
Les Pounder, OggCamp: "It's good to see the team back together and eager to start on their ambitious project. The OggCamp team fully supports Linux Voice and their endeavour to produce a magazine for the FOSS community. Good luck to them all."
Eben Upton (sporting a lustrous moustache in aid of Movember), Founder of the Raspberry Pi Foundation: "The Linux Voice team has a fantastic background in the world of free and open source software, and shares the same ethos as Raspberry Pi - that computing should be open, and that cost shouldn't be a barrier to access. I'm very much looking forward to my first copy."
Karen Sandler, Executive Director of the Gnome Foundation: "The guys at Linux Voice are dangerously fun to talk to - you can easily forget you're being interviewed! Congrats on your new gig, I look forward to following it!"
And our appearances around the web...
The Guardian - Greenslade BlogMVC - The Market for Computer and Video Gamesjournalism.co.uk (includes interview with Andrew Gregory)betanews (includes interview with Ben Everard)Podcast: LINUX Unplugged 14 (Ben is 2 minutes in)iTWire - Latest IT News and InformationBITblokes (German Linux news website)Muktware - Web magazine for Linux and open source usersTechrights - People's rights in the digital ageThe Register - Biting the hand that feeds ITFAQ

story:
Green Technical Education and Employment

Solar Suitcase Project 

Green Tech students build solar suitcases and deliver these valuable sources of energy to people living without adequate sources of light.  The suitcases have been used in critical medical emergencies and can also be used for daily neccessities.

Green Tech instructors train students in emerging green collar skills and provide introductory activities for career opportunities in clean energy. The Green Tech program strives not only to develop a skilled workforce, but also to encourage sustainable communities and low environmental impact initiatives.

Your generous contribution today will support these courageous students in their efforts to provide critical human assistance to countries overseas. The students will also be learning the basic principles of photovoltaic technology while serving as humanitarians.

Funding

We are raising $5,000 to send solar suitcases to orphanages and medical clinics in Haiti and Cameroon.

Each solar suitcase costs about $1500 to build.

The number of cases we build is contigent upon additional funds we can raise; the more we raise, the more suitcases we build. 

Impact

Green Tech recruits and trains high school students for careers that contribute to energy efficiency, renewable energy and overall efforts to develop sustainable communities.  Students are taught the core element of “Going Green” is to improve health conditions for all humans sharing the earth.
  • This provides instruction to high school students in renewal energy.
  • This is the 3rd year of the success of this project: Solar cases have gone to Haiti, and several countries in Africa.
  • These cases have supported many doctors and nurses in many countries and their use has had a positive effect on many people.

Benefits

Remember, your contribution is 100% fully tax-deductible. Your support will make a difference here and abroad. 
 
Help us give our students an Eco-Advantage!
