story:
Short Summary

Hi all! My name is Taylor Ferguson, I am a twenty year old college student studying Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at the University of Connecticut. This past fall I was accepted to study abroad in the amazing country of South Africa through a program called African Field Ecology and Renewable Resources Management. This program includes a lecture portion, in which I am currently enrolled, and a field portion, which will be taking place for three weeks in August 2012 at the Entabeni Nature Guide Training Reserve in Limpopo, South Africa. During my time there I will be learning the fundamentals of field ecology, getting trained in First Aid and Track & Sign, learning how to perform a necropsy, studying the amazing flora and fauna of South Africa, learning about South African culture, visiting and donating my time to a school of underprivileged children, potentially doing research for a senior thesis, and overall shaping myself as a global citizen! This will be my first time travelling abroad, as previously I have not had the financial funds to have such an experience.

The trip will cost about $5,500 total (this includes airfaire both ways, accomodations, etc.), but I am only hoping to raise a total of $2000. The money raised will be going directly to the cost of my trip, which is paid for through the University's fee bill system.

However, I don't want money without doing work! My campaign involves my participation in a 5K race taking place on April 22, 2012 called the ENOUGH! Race to end Violence hosted by the Sexual Assault Crisis Service in partnership with the Hartford Marathon Foundation and Central Connecticut State University. For every donation I receive per person I will donate an additional dollar towards the ENOUGH! fund (in addition to the money I pay to enter the race). Thus, by supporting me in my travel and education you will be simultaneously supporting this wonderful cause and overall, a chance to improve the quality of life both here and overseas. 

The Impact

As an Ecology and Evolutionary Biology major, this trip would be an incredible and most likely once in a lifetime opportunity for me, because not only will it enhance my educational experience but it will also pave the way for hopefully a successful career. In this field a classroom setting can only take you so far; being out in the midst of your passion is what it's all about!

Also, if you are looking for further incentive, supporting the Sexual Assult Crisis Service with your donation helps not only spread awareness about issues of violence here in our backyard but also helps to cease that violence once and for all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, spreading the word about my campaign would be a wonderful way to help! Or even considering running the ENOUGH! race to support that cause would be wonderful as well (after all, this campaign is not all about me :]).

story:
*******************************************************************

Click here to donate to Word Up Community Bookshop's 2014 fundraiser: Word Up ¡para siempre!

*******************************************************************

Dear everybody,

We did it. We signed a lease on June 3, 2013, for a new space for our bookshop on the corner of 165th Street and Amsterdam. Thank you so very much for all your help and your patience and your love. We are immensely grateful!

 

A todos nuestros queridos amigos y familia,

Lo logramos. El 3 de junio 2013, firmamos un nuevo contrato para nuestra nueva librería en la esquina de la Avenida Amsterdam y Calle 165. Muchísimas gracias por todo su apoyo y paciencia y amor. Estamos increíblemente agradecidos!

 

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

Listen to author and loving Word Up supporter Junot Díaz tell you why you should donate  

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

 

Check us out!

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

To see a group of young people who have worked together to
profoundly change the local community is fantastic. . . .
These guys kick ass and I love them.
—MacArthur “Genius” Fellow & Pulitzer Prize winner JUNOT DíAZ,
at Word Up’s one-year birthday celebration


Help Word Up Community Bookshop/Librería Comunitaria move to a new home.

Word Up Community Bookshop—the only 100% volunteer-powered, community bookshop and arts space in Washington Heights, New York City—needs your help to remain a viable community resource for our neighbors. After more than a year serving Northern Manhattan, our month-to-month lease at 4157 Broadway was terminated August 31, 2012. Help us open a new location, so we can continue fostering a positive environment for literacy, arts, and education in Northern Manhattan.

Word Up is a project of Seven Stories Institute, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, so your donation is tax-deductible.

Why?

It’s simple: our neighborhood—and every neighborhood—needs space to share and create, where people of all backgrounds, ages, and abilities can participate in their community. Word Up has been that space for so many residents of Northern Manhattan and visitors from all over the place. It is truly a space made for the community, by the community.

Our goal is to raise $60,000+ so we can continue the important work of promoting literacy, the arts, and social awareness in one of the most densely populated districts in Manhattan, and hopefully inspire similar projects all over New York City, the United States, and the world.

What is Word Up?

Intended as a 1-month-long pop-up bookshop during the 2011 Uptown Arts Stroll—a neighborhood-wide festival every June celebrating local artists with events around Northern Manhattan—Word Up opened its doors June 17, 2011.

What happened in the following days was beyond all expectation. People—all kinds of people! from the very young to the very old, longtime residents and newcomers, readers and not-yet-readers—cycled through with enthusiasm, then stayed a while to let themselves become a part of the curious story that was being written into the history of our neighborhood.

Neighbors expressed a variation of the same theme: We need you here! They felt welcome and became more involved. Our colorful storefront, on a block with many vacant storefronts, became a haven for open minds and real dialogue.

On the very first day, visitors began asking us many things, but the one we heard most was "Can you please stay?" It was repeated so frequently, it turned into a declaration: "PLEASE STAY."

So, we stayed. With the help of Northern Manhattan Arts Alliance (NoMAA), Seven Stories Institute, and the work of 100+ volunteers Word Up thrived for over a year at 4157 Broadway until the month-to-month lease was terminated by the building’s new owners. Although temporarily homeless, Word Up is still active at community events, promoting literacy and the arts around Northern Manhattan and New York City at large.

Junot Díaz talking about the importance of Word Up AT WORD UP on June 7th, 2012

What’s the neighborhood like?

Washington Heights is an ethnically and economically diverse historical neighborhood located in Northern Manhattan, New York City.

Like many neighborhoods in New York City, Washington Heights is a multicultural crossroads where the different values, traditions, and ideas of many immigrant groups interact. Many residents of the Heights have roots in the Dominican Republic, which is why you may have heard Washington Heights referred to as “Quisqueya Heights” or “El Alto.” Prior generations earned  the neighborhood names like “Frankfurt on the Hudson,” or “Moscow on the Hudson” because of the large pockets of Jewish residents with roots in Central and Eastern Europe and Russia. Residents with Greek and Irish heritage are scattered around the neighborhood, as well.

Spanish, English, and Russian are the languages you’ll hear most frequently while walking up Broadway, and all three are represented at Word Up. In addition to its astounding diversity, our neighborhood is the second most populated district in Manhattan, and we have the highest concentration of kids in the borough. Word Up is for our neighbors of all backgrounds, of all ages.

Why should you help Word Up open a permanent storefront in Washington Heights, NYC?

YOU MISS WORD UP! Perhaps you saw Junot Díaz speak on our stage, or interacted with People’s Theatre Project’s Immigration Circus, or danced bachata with your sweetheart at the Washington Heights Music Festival, or helped your child find a great book by her favorite author on our shelves, or maybe you just had a stimulating conversation with a neighbor. We miss you too!

YOU LOVE BOOKS & BOOKSHOPS. We do, too. The all-volunteer crew at Word Up works tirelessly to keep books, and the conversations they generate, a part of our community. Plus, we've done the math: for every dollar donated to Word Up, another book gets distributed to the Northern Manhattan community.

YOU’RE A SUPPORTER OF THE ARTS. Word Up is an uptown stop for the NYC literary community, as well as home-base for neighborhood artists and arts organizations. Prior to the existence of Word Up, there was little opportunity for the creative folks in Washington Heights to read their poetry, display their art, perform their plays, drop their new album, or hold a calligraphy workshop under one roof. If you support the arts, you know the importance of generating dialogue and collaboration across disciplines. The unique, community-driven spirit of Word Up encourages exactly that.

YOU SUPPORT COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS. Word Up is a creative space for the community, by the community. Even without a brick and mortar location, the Word Up volunteer collective continues to have a presence at many community and city events, including the Little Red Lighthouse Festival, the Young Urban Moms Conference, the Inwood Greenmarket, the launch of the United Palace of Cultural Arts, and many more!

YOU SUPPORT YOUTH PROGRAMMING. Word Up has hosted events and workshops targeted to our younger neighbors in order to engage the nearly 54,000 residents under the age of 18 in Nothern Manhattan. In fact, young people make up 25% of our neighborhood. At a time when the city is facing more cuts to after-school budgets, community-supported youth programs—like Word Up’s teen writing and theater program developed in collaboration with People’s Theatre Project—are especially crucial.

YOU BELIEVE CREATIVE SPACES ARE AS IMPORTANT AS BIG PROFIT-GENERATORS IN ANY NEIGHBORHOOD, ANYWHERE. In New York City, there are too-big-to-fail banks and big-name pharmacies on every corner, because smaller businesses and creative organizations can’t keep up with rising rent prices. We want to prove the value of open, creative spaces in our neighborhood by reopening Word Up and making it more vibrant than ever.

 


Did you know?

Since June 2011, Word Up has:

DISTRIBUTED 30,000+ books in English, Spanish, and Russian to our neighbors, many for only $1.

FEATURED 1,200+ performers on our stage including Pulitzer Prize–winning author Junot Díaz, radical comic book artist Seth Tobocman, poet Meena Alexander, comedian Tom Shillue, photographer Arlene Gottfried, homeless and formerly homeless artists Concrete Justice, storyteller Michele Carlo, folksinger Ed Askew, local jazz legend Marjorie Eliot, as well as the literary and musical talents of our neighbors.

PROVIDED an open space for after-school programs, workshops, community meetings, and language exchanges for our neighbors.

SUPPORTED neighborhood authors, artists, and small, independent presses.

COLLABORATED with numerous creative organizations and small businesses such as Uptown Collective, United Palace of Cultural Arts, Fresh Press/Fresh Youth Initiatives, Young Urban Moms, Seven Stories Press, Washington Heights Free Radio, Planned Parenthood, World War 3 Illustrated, and so many more.

OPERATED thanks to a corps of over 100 volunteers, 7 days a week, for more than 1 year.

The next chapter:
We are actively seeking a new storefront in Washington Heights. Every week the Word Up real estate committee reports back with photos and pertinent information on potential spaces. We look. We debate. We get repair and build-out estimates. It’s a slow process.

Until we find the storefront that suits the needs of our community best, you can find the Word Up volunteer collective at community events around Washington Heights. Check out our website to see where we’ll be next!

Other ways to participate:
VOLUNTEER. The Word Up volunteer collective will need your help once we reopen. Check out our website to see how you can get involved. Even if you don’t live around Washington Heights, we hope you’re inspired to start a Word Up-type space in your neighborhood. With big businesses ever-present in our lives, we need to reassert the importance of conversations in our communities. It’s not easy, but trust us: it’s worth all the work!

POST OUR INDIEGOGO URL TO YOUR WEBSITE OR BLOG. If you made it this far, you must care about Word Up as much as the whole volunteer collective does. Indiegogo makes it super easy to share our story. Help us out and spread the word about Word Up!

Thanks for helping out! We hope to see you when we reopen!

 Watch a recent DANCE video featuring Word Up volunteers here!

¡¡¡AHORA EN ESPAÑOL!!!

Ayude a la Librería Comunitaria Word Up a mudarse a su nuevo hogar.

Librería Comunitaria Word Up—la única libreria comunitaria y espacio artístico en Washington Heights, ciudad de Nueva York,  propulsada por voluntarios solamente—necesita su ayuda para poder continuar siendo una fuente viable para la comunidad.  Después de más de un año de servir al Norte de Manhattan, nuestro contrato de alquiler mensual en 4157 Broadway se terminó el 31 de Agosto de 2012. Ayúdenos a abrir un local nuevo, para que así podamos continuar fomentando un ambiente positivo para la lectura y la escritura, el arte y la educación en el Norte de Manhattan.


Word Up es un proyecto de Seven Stories Institute, una organización 501(c)(3) sin fines de lucro, de manera que su donación es deducible para efectos impositivos.

 
Por qué?

Es simple: nuestro barrio—y todo barrio—necesita un espacio para poder compartir y crear, donde las personas de todo origen, edad y capacidad puedan participar en su comunidad. Word Up ha sido ese espacio para muchos residentes del Norte de Manhattan y para visitas provenientes de otros lugares también. Es verdaderamente un espacio creado para la comunidad, por la comunidad.

 
Nuestro objetivo es recaudar más de $60,000 para poder así continuar la importante tarea de promover la escritura y la lectura, las artes, y la conciencia social en uno de los distritos más densamente poblados en Manhattan, con la esperanza de inspirar proyectos semejantes en todo Nueva York, en los Estados Unidos, y en el mundo entero.

 

Qué es Word Up?

Word Up abrió sus puertas el 17 de junio de 2011 como una librería que aparece espontáneamente (un “pop-up shop”), con la intención de participar durante un mes en el Uptown Arts Stroll—un festival que se realiza todos los años en el mes de junio en todo el barrio para celebrar artistas locales en el norte de Manhattan.


Lo que sucedió en los días siguientes sobrepasó todo lo esperado. Gente—toda clase de gente! desde los más jóvenes hasta los más viejos, residentes nuevos y veteranos, lectores y no-aun-lectores—pasaron rápidamente con gran entusiasmo, y luego permanecieron para formar parte de este cuento curioso que estaba siendo escrito en la historia de esta comunidad.

Los vecinos expresaron variaciones sobre el mismo tema: Nosotros te necesitamos aquí! Se sintieron bienvenidos y se comprometieron más. El frente colorido de nuestro local, en una cuadra donde varios locales están desocupados, se convirtió en un paraíso para aquellos seres de pensamiento libre y para el diálogo verdadero.


Desde el primer día, los visitantes comenzaron a hacernos muchas preguntas, pero la más frecuente fue “Es posible que ustedes se queden aquí?” Esta pregunta fue repetida tantas veces que finalmente se convirtió en una declaración: “POR FAVOR QUEDENSE.”

Y así fue que nos quedamos.  Gracias a la ayuda de Northern Manhattan Arts Alliance (NoMAA), Seven Stories Institute, y el trabajo de más de 100 voluntarios, Word Up prosperó durante más de un año en 4157 Broadway hasta que los nuevos propietarios del edificio terminaron el contrato de alquiler mensual. A pesar que por el momento no tiene un hogar, Word Up permanece activo en eventos comunitarios, promoviendo la lectura y escritura y las artes en el norte de Manhattan y en la ciudad de Nueva York en general.

 

Cómo es el barrio?

Washington Heights es un barrio diverso étnicamente y económicamente, situado en el norte de Manhattan en la ciudad de Nueva York.

De manera semejante a otros tantos barrios en la Ciudad de Nueva York, Washington Heights es un cruce de varias culturas donde valores y tradiciones diferentes se encuentran, y donde las ideas de muchos grupos de inmigrantes obran recíprocamente. Muchos residentes de Washington Heights tienen sus raíces en la República Dominicana, por lo cual es posible que usted haya escuchado referirse a Washington Heights como a “Quisqueya Heights” o “El Alto.” Las generaciones anteriores captaron el nombre de “Frankfurt sobre el Hudson” o “Moscú sobre el Hudson” debido a las grandes cantidades de residentes Judíos con raíces en Europa Central y Oriental y Rusia. También existen residentes de origen griego e irlandés diseminados por el barrio entero.

Español, inglés y ruso son los idiomas que escuchará más frecuentemente caminando por Broadway, y estos tres idiomas están representados en Word Up. Además de su diversidad asombrosa, nuestro barrio es el segundo distrito más poblado en Manhattan, y tenemos la mayor concentración de niños en el distrito. Word Up sirve a nuestros vecinos de diferentes orígenes, de todas las edades.

 

Por qué usted debe ayudar a Word Up a abrir un local permanente en Washington Heights, NYC?

USTED EXTRAŇA A WORD UP! Tal vez usted lo vio hablar a Junot Díaz en nuestro escenario, o participó en el Immigration Circus del People’s Theatre Project, o bailó bachata con su enamorado en el Festival de la Música en Washington Heights, o le ayudó a su niño a encontrar un libro fabuloso escrito por su autor favorito en nuestros estantes, o tal vez usted solamente tuvo una conversación estimulante con un vecino. Nosotros lo extrañamos a usted también!

USTED AMA A LOS LIBROS Y A LAS LIBRERIAS. Nosotros también. El equipo de Word Up, compuesto de voluntarios únicamente, trabaja infatigablemente para conservar a los libros y al diálogo que ellos generan, como parte de la comunidad. Más aún, hemos hecho nuestros cálculos: por cada dólar donado a Word Up, un libro más es distribuido a la comunidad del norte de Manhattan.

 
USTED APOYA A LAS ARTES. Word Up es una estación en el norte de la ciudad para la comunidad literaria, así como también la base del hogar para los artistas locales y las organizaciones artísticas. Previamente a la existencia de Word Up, la gente creativa en Washington Heights no tenía muchas oportunidades para leer sus poesías, exhibir su arte, presentar sus obras de teatro, o conducir un taller de caligrafía, todo bajo un mismo techo. Si usted apoya a los artes, usted reconoce la importancia  de generar el diálogo y la colaboración entre las diferentes disciplinas.     Eso es precisamente lo que fomenta el espíritu único de Word Up, dirigido hacia la comunidad.

USTED APOYA ORGANIZACIONES COMUNITARIAS. Word Up es un espacio creativo para la comunidad, por la comunidad. Aún sin tener un local físico, el colectivo de voluntarios de Word Up conserva su presencia en muchos eventos de la comunidad y de la ciudad, incluyendo el Little Red Lighthouse Festival, la Young Urban Moms Conference, el Inwood Greenmarket, la inauguración del United Palace of Cultural Arts, y muchos más!

USTED APOYA PROGRAMAS PARA LA JUVENTUD. Word ha hospedado eventos y talleres dedicados a nuestros residentes más jóvenes a fin de atraer acerca de 54,000 residentes menores de 18 años en el norte de Manhattan. En realidad, los jóvenes constituyen el 25% de nuestro barrio. En tiempos como éstos en que el presupuesto de los programas para la juventud fuera de las escuelas es reducido, los programas apoyados por la comunidad—tales como el  programa de Word Up de escritores adolescentes y de teatro desarrollado en colaboración con People’s Theatre Project—son crucialmente importantes.

USTED CREE QUE LOS ESPACIOS CREATIVOS SON TAN IMPORTANTES COMO LOS GENERADORES DE GANANCIAS EN CUALQUIER BARRIO, EN CUALQUIER SITIO. En la ciudad de Nueva York, existen bancos y farmacias poderosos en cada esquina debido a que los comercios más pequeños y las organizaciones creativas no pueden pagar los alquileres que van aumentando. Queremos demostrar el valor de los espacios creativos en nuestra comunidad abriendo una vez más Word Up y convirtiéndolo en un centro mas vibrante que nunca.

 

Usted sabía?

Desde junio  2011, Word Up ha:

DISTRIBUIDO más de 30,000 libros en inglés, español, y ruso a nuestros vecinos, muchos de ellos por $1 solamente.

PRESENTADO a más de 1,200 artistas en nuestro escenario incluyendo al autor Junot Díaz ganador del Premio Pulitzer, el artista radical de libros cómicos Seth Tobocman, el poeta Meena Alexander, el comediante Tom Shillue, la fotógrafa Arlene Gottfried, artistas sin hogar en el pasado y en el presente Concrete Justice, la narradora de cuentos Michele Carlo, el cantante popular Ed Askew, la leyenda local del jazz Marjorie Eliot, así como los talentos literarios y musicales de nuestros vecinos.

PROVEIDO un espacio abierto para programas fuera de las escuelas, talleres, reuniones comunitarias, e intercambio de idiomas para nuestros vecinos.  

APOYADO a autores, artistas, y pequeñas prensas independientes.

COLABORADO con muchas organizaciones creativas y negocios pequeños tal como Uptown Collective, United Palace of Cultural Arts, Fresh Press/Fresh Youth Initiatives, Young Urban Moms, Seven Stories Press, Washington Heights Free Radio, Planned Parenthood, World War 3 Illustrated, y muchos más.

OPERADO gracias a un equipo de más de 100 voluntarios, 7 días por semana, durante más de un año.

 

El capítulo próximo:
Nosotros estamos buscando activamente un nuevo local en Washington Heights. Cada semana la comisión encargada de encontrar una propiedad para Word Up presenta un informe con fotografías e información relevante sobre locales potenciales. Lo examinamos. Deliberamos. Obtenemos estimaciones del costo de arreglos y construcción. Es un proceso lento.

Hasta que encontremos un local que satisface las necesidades de nuestra comunidad de la mejor manera posible, usted puede encontrar el colectivo de voluntarios de Word Up en los eventos comunitarios alrededor de Washington Heights. Fíjese en nuestra página de web dónde tendrá lugar el próximo evento!

 

Otras formas de participar:

SIRVA COMO VOLUNTARIO. El colectivo de voluntarios de Word Up necesitará su ayuda después que abramos las puertas. Verifique en nuestra página de web de qué manera usted puede participar. Aún si usted no vive en Washington Heights, esperamos que Word Up le sirve como inspiración para comenzar una iniciativa semejante en su barrio. Debido a la presencia permanente de grandes empresas en nuestras vidas, necesitamos reafirmar la importancia de las conversaciones en nuestras comunidades. No es fácil, pero confíenos: vale la pena todo el trabajo invertido!

 
ANUNCIE NUESTRO INDIEGOGO URL EN SU PAGINA DE WEB O BLOG. Si ha llegado hasta aquí, debe ser porque  a usted Word Up le interesa tanto como al resto del colectivo de voluntarios. Indiegogo facilita considerablemente compartir nuestra historia. Ayúdenos y disemine las noticias sobre Word Up!

Gracias por su ayuda! Esperamos verlo cuando abramos las puertas por segunda vez!

 

También puede encontrar esta campaña en:

  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • YouTube
  • Página de web

 

 

*Your donation is tax-deductible | Su donación es deducible de impuestos*
story_txt:
*******************************************************************Click here to donate to Word Up Community Bookshop's 2014 fundraiser: Word Up ¡para siempre!
*******************************************************************Dear everybody,
We did it. We signed a lease on June 3, 2013, for a new space for our bookshop on the corner of 165th Street and Amsterdam. Thank you so very much for all your help and your patience and your love. We are immensely grateful!
 
A todos nuestros queridos amigos y familia,
Lo logramos. El 3 de junio 2013, firmamos un nuevo contrato para nuestra nueva librería en la esquina de la Avenida Amsterdam y Calle 165. Muchísimas gracias por todo su apoyo y paciencia y amor. Estamos increíblemente agradecidos!
 
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

Listen to author and loving Word Up supporter Junot Díaz tell you why you should donate  
••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
 
Check us out!


••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••
To see a group of young people who have worked together toprofoundly change the local community is fantastic. . . .These guys kick ass and I love them.—MacArthur “Genius” Fellow & Pulitzer Prize winner JUNOT DíAZ,at Word Up’s one-year birthday celebration




Help Word Up Community Bookshop/Librería Comunitaria move to a new home.Word Up Community Bookshop—the only 100% volunteer-powered, community bookshop and arts space in Washington Heights, New York City—needs your help to remain a viable community resource for our neighbors. After more than a year serving Northern Manhattan, our month-to-month lease at 4157 Broadway was terminated August 31, 2012. Help us open a new location, so we can continue fostering a positive environment for literacy, arts, and education in Northern Manhattan.Word Up is a project of Seven Stories Institute, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, so your donation is tax-deductible. Why?It’s simple: our neighborhood—and every neighborhood—needs space to share and create, where people of all backgrounds, ages, and abilities can participate in their community. Word Up has been that space for so many residents of Northern Manhattan and visitors from all over the place. It is truly a space made for the community, by the community.Our goal is to raise $60,000+ so we can continue the important work of promoting literacy, the arts, and social awareness in one of the most densely populated districts in Manhattan, and hopefully inspire similar projects all over New York City, the United States, and the world.


What is Word Up?

Intended as a 1-month-long pop-up bookshop during the 2011 Uptown Arts Stroll—a neighborhood-wide festival every June celebrating local artists with events around Northern Manhattan—Word Up opened its doors June 17, 2011. What happened in the following days was beyond all expectation. People—all kinds of people! from the very young to the very old, longtime residents and newcomers, readers and not-yet-readers—cycled through with enthusiasm, then stayed a while to let themselves become a part of the curious story that was being written into the history of our neighborhood. Neighbors expressed a variation of the same theme: We need you here! They felt welcome and became more involved. Our colorful storefront, on a block with many vacant storefronts, became a haven for open minds and real dialogue.On the very first day, visitors began asking us many things, but the one we heard most was "Can you please stay?" It was repeated so frequently, it turned into a declaration: "PLEASE STAY."So, we stayed. With the help of Northern Manhattan Arts Alliance (NoMAA), Seven Stories Institute, and the work of 100+ volunteers Word Up thrived for over a year at 4157 Broadway until the month-to-month lease was terminated by the building’s new owners. Although temporarily homeless, Word Up is still active at community events, promoting literacy and the arts around Northern Manhattan and New York City at large.


Junot Díaz talking about the importance of Word Up AT WORD UP on June 7th, 2012
What’s the neighborhood like?
Washington Heights is an ethnically and economically diverse historical neighborhood located in Northern Manhattan, New York City.

Like many neighborhoods in New York City, Washington Heights is a multicultural crossroads where the different values, traditions, and ideas of many immigrant groups interact. Many residents of the Heights have roots in the Dominican Republic, which is why you may have heard Washington Heights referred to as “Quisqueya Heights” or “El Alto.” Prior generations earned  the neighborhood names like “Frankfurt on the Hudson,” or “Moscow on the Hudson” because of the large pockets of Jewish residents with roots in Central and Eastern Europe and Russia. Residents with Greek and Irish heritage are scattered around the neighborhood, as well.


Spanish, English, and Russian are the languages you’ll hear most frequently while walking up Broadway, and all three are represented at Word Up. In addition to its astounding diversity, our neighborhood is the second most populated district in Manhattan, and we have the highest concentration of kids in the borough. Word Up is for our neighbors of all backgrounds, of all ages.



Why should you help Word Up open a permanent storefront in Washington Heights, NYC?YOU MISS WORD UP! Perhaps you saw Junot Díaz speak on our stage, or interacted with People’s Theatre Project’s Immigration Circus, or danced bachata with your sweetheart at the Washington Heights Music Festival, or helped your child find a great book by her favorite author on our shelves, or maybe you just had a stimulating conversation with a neighbor. We miss you too! YOU LOVE BOOKS & BOOKSHOPS. We do, too. The all-volunteer crew at Word Up works tirelessly to keep books, and the conversations they generate, a part of our community. Plus, we've done the math: for every dollar donated to Word Up, another book gets distributed to the Northern Manhattan community. YOU’RE A SUPPORTER OF THE ARTS. Word Up is an uptown stop for the NYC literary community, as well as home-base for neighborhood artists and arts organizations. Prior to the existence of Word Up, there was little opportunity for the creative folks in Washington Heights to read their poetry, display their art, perform their plays, drop their new album, or hold a calligraphy workshop under one roof. If you support the arts, you know the importance of generating dialogue and collaboration across disciplines. The unique, community-driven spirit of Word Up encourages exactly that. 

YOU SUPPORT COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS. Word Up is a creative space for the community, by the community. Even without a brick and mortar location, the Word Up volunteer collective continues to have a presence at many community and city events, including the Little Red Lighthouse Festival, the Young Urban Moms Conference, the Inwood Greenmarket, the launch of the United Palace of Cultural Arts, and many more! 
YOU SUPPORT YOUTH PROGRAMMING. Word Up has hosted events and workshops targeted to our younger neighbors in order to engage the nearly 54,000 residents under the age of 18 in Nothern Manhattan. In fact, young people make up 25% of our neighborhood. At a time when the city is facing more cuts to after-school budgets, community-supported youth programs—like Word Up’s teen writing and theater program developed in collaboration with People’s Theatre Project—are especially crucial.
YOU BELIEVE CREATIVE SPACES ARE AS IMPORTANT AS BIG PROFIT-GENERATORS IN ANY NEIGHBORHOOD, ANYWHERE. In New York City, there are too-big-to-fail banks and big-name pharmacies on every corner, because smaller businesses and creative organizations can’t keep up with rising rent prices. We want to prove the value of open, creative spaces in our neighborhood by reopening Word Up and making it more vibrant than ever.
 




Did you know?Since June 2011, Word Up has:DISTRIBUTED 30,000+ books in English, Spanish, and Russian to our neighbors, many for only $1.FEATURED 1,200+ performers on our stage including Pulitzer Prize–winning author Junot Díaz, radical comic book artist Seth Tobocman, poet Meena Alexander, comedian Tom Shillue, photographer Arlene Gottfried, homeless and formerly homeless artists Concrete Justice, storyteller Michele Carlo, folksinger Ed Askew, local jazz legend Marjorie Eliot, as well as the literary and musical talents of our neighbors.PROVIDED an open space for after-school programs, workshops, community meetings, and language exchanges for our neighbors.SUPPORTED neighborhood authors, artists, and small, independent presses.COLLABORATED with numerous creative organizations and small businesses such as Uptown Collective, United Palace of Cultural Arts, Fresh Press/Fresh Youth Initiatives, Young Urban Moms, Seven Stories Press, Washington Heights Free Radio, Planned Parenthood, World War 3 Illustrated, and so many more.OPERATED thanks to a corps of over 100 volunteers, 7 days a week, for more than 1 year.


The next chapter:We are actively seeking a new storefront in Washington Heights. Every week the Word Up real estate committee reports back with photos and pertinent information on potential spaces. We look. We debate. We get repair and build-out estimates. It’s a slow process.Until we find the storefront that suits the needs of our community best, you can find the Word Up volunteer collective at community events around Washington Heights. Check out our website to see where we’ll be next!Other ways to participate:VOLUNTEER. The Word Up volunteer collective will need your help once we reopen. Check out our website to see how you can get involved. Even if you don’t live around Washington Heights, we hope you’re inspired to start a Word Up-type space in your neighborhood. With big businesses ever-present in our lives, we need to reassert the importance of conversations in our communities. It’s not easy, but trust us: it’s worth all the work! POST OUR INDIEGOGO URL TO YOUR WEBSITE OR BLOG. If you made it this far, you must care about Word Up as much as the whole volunteer collective does. Indiegogo makes it super easy to share our story. Help us out and spread the word about Word Up! Thanks for helping out! We hope to see you when we reopen! 

 Watch a recent DANCE video featuring Word Up volunteers here!
¡¡¡AHORA EN ESPAÑOL!!!
Ayude a la Librería Comunitaria Word Up a mudarse a su nuevo hogar.  Librería Comunitaria Word Up—la única libreria comunitaria y espacio artístico en Washington Heights, ciudad de Nueva York,  propulsada por voluntarios solamente—necesita su ayuda para poder continuar siendo una fuente viable para la comunidad.  Después de más de un año de servir al Norte de Manhattan, nuestro contrato de alquiler mensual en 4157 Broadway se terminó el 31 de Agosto de 2012. Ayúdenos a abrir un local nuevo, para que así podamos continuar fomentando un ambiente positivo para la lectura y la escritura, el arte y la educación en el Norte de Manhattan.


 Word Up es un proyecto de Seven Stories Institute, una organización 501(c)(3) sin fines de lucro, de manera que su donación es deducible para efectos impositivos.
  Por qué?  Es simple: nuestro barrio—y todo barrio—necesita un espacio para poder compartir y crear, donde las personas de todo origen, edad y capacidad puedan participar en su comunidad. Word Up ha sido ese espacio para muchos residentes del Norte de Manhattan y para visitas provenientes de otros lugares también. Es verdaderamente un espacio creado para la comunidad, por la comunidad.
  Nuestro objetivo es recaudar más de $60,000 para poder así continuar la importante tarea de promover la escritura y la lectura, las artes, y la conciencia social en uno de los distritos más densamente poblados en Manhattan, con la esperanza de inspirar proyectos semejantes en todo Nueva York, en los Estados Unidos, y en el mundo entero.
 
Qué es Word Up?
Word Up abrió sus puertas el 17 de junio de 2011 como una librería que aparece espontáneamente (un “pop-up shop”), con la intención de participar durante un mes en el Uptown Arts Stroll—un festival que se realiza todos los años en el mes de junio en todo el barrio para celebrar artistas locales en el norte de Manhattan.

 Lo que sucedió en los días siguientes sobrepasó todo lo esperado. Gente—toda clase de gente! desde los más jóvenes hasta los más viejos, residentes nuevos y veteranos, lectores y no-aun-lectores—pasaron rápidamente con gran entusiasmo, y luego permanecieron para formar parte de este cuento curioso que estaba siendo escrito en la historia de esta comunidad.   Los vecinos expresaron variaciones sobre el mismo tema: Nosotros te necesitamos aquí! Se sintieron bienvenidos y se comprometieron más. El frente colorido de nuestro local, en una cuadra donde varios locales están desocupados, se convirtió en un paraíso para aquellos seres de pensamiento libre y para el diálogo verdadero.

 Desde el primer día, los visitantes comenzaron a hacernos muchas preguntas, pero la más frecuente fue “Es posible que ustedes se queden aquí?” Esta pregunta fue repetida tantas veces que finalmente se convirtió en una declaración: “POR FAVOR QUEDENSE.”  Y así fue que nos quedamos.  Gracias a la ayuda de Northern Manhattan Arts Alliance (NoMAA), Seven Stories Institute, y el trabajo de más de 100 voluntarios, Word Up prosperó durante más de un año en 4157 Broadway hasta que los nuevos propietarios del edificio terminaron el contrato de alquiler mensual. A pesar que por el momento no tiene un hogar, Word Up permanece activo en eventos comunitarios, promoviendo la lectura y escritura y las artes en el norte de Manhattan y en la ciudad de Nueva York en general.
 
Cómo es el barrio?
Washington Heights es un barrio diverso étnicamente y económicamente, situado en el norte de Manhattan en la ciudad de Nueva York.
De manera semejante a otros tantos barrios en la Ciudad de Nueva York, Washington Heights es un cruce de varias culturas donde valores y tradiciones diferentes se encuentran, y donde las ideas de muchos grupos de inmigrantes obran recíprocamente. Muchos residentes de Washington Heights tienen sus raíces en la República Dominicana, por lo cual es posible que usted haya escuchado referirse a Washington Heights como a “Quisqueya Heights” o “El Alto.” Las generaciones anteriores captaron el nombre de “Frankfurt sobre el Hudson” o “Moscú sobre el Hudson” debido a las grandes cantidades de residentes Judíos con raíces en Europa Central y Oriental y Rusia. También existen residentes de origen griego e irlandés diseminados por el barrio entero.
Español, inglés y ruso son los idiomas que escuchará más frecuentemente caminando por Broadway, y estos tres idiomas están representados en Word Up. Además de su diversidad asombrosa, nuestro barrio es el segundo distrito más poblado en Manhattan, y tenemos la mayor concentración de niños en el distrito. Previamente a la existencia de Word Up, la gente creativa en Washington Heights no tenía muchas oportunidades para leer sus poesías, exhibir su arte, presentar sus obras de teatro, o conducir un taller de caligrafía, todo bajo un mismo techo. story:
Our Story

The New Mexico Center for Therapeutic Riding is a certified member of PATH (Professional Association of Therapeutic Horsemanship) an international, highly accredited therapeutic horseback riding program for individuals and families with special physical, cognitive and emotional needs with over 350 centers worldwide.

 

Our center is a non-profit organization. Our curriculum for the past five years includes all equine assisted activities and our therapeutic services produce tangible physical, psychological, cognitive, social and educational benefits.

 

Our program is located in a peaceful setting at a private stable on over 100 acres in Santa Fe, NM. Our PATH certified instructors design each lesson with the following goals in mind: physical development, emotional growth and intellectual stimulation. We strive to accomplish our goals in a safe, fun, family and community oriented atmosphere.

 

The horse is a motivator that connects therapy through movement to sport, pleasure and education. The dynamic relationships among students, teachers, volunteers and horses strengthens our program. This community family is enhanced through summer camps, horse shows, trail rides, birthdays and holiday parties.

 

Our vision is to create a larger, premier public facility that will partner with local government institutions that have children and adults that will benefit from our center. We receive revenue from grants, schools, individual lessons and from charitable donations.

 

We had an amazing past year because of the tremendous interest in our center and our goal is to grow at least 100% this year. We have very low administration costs (a program director/teacher) and a large, wonderful group of dedicated volunteers. 

 

The horses are our biggest expense and because of the fires in neighboring states this past year, the price of hay has tripled. Please help us keep these wonderful animals who are so very important to the people we help by donating to our cause.

 

The New Mexico Center for Therapeutic Riding is a tax exempt, non-profit charitable organization under the umbrella of the New Mexico Community Foundation. All donations are tax deductible .

 

The Impact


Therapeutic horseback riding because of it's group orientation format, can provide significant help to many children with physical and behavioral needs which in turn also helps the parents and other family members cope. The almost instantaneous benefits of therapeutic riding are key to changing attitudes and well being of the children and helping families continue on a path towards improvement and progress that leads to a lifetime of accomplishment.

  

Children/Adults with special needs:

Family members see for themselves the benefits that therapeutic horseback riding offers. The improvement is evident after the first session and the possibilities are endless! After a session with a horse the self-image, persona and the self-confidence of the child with a disability is greatly impacted thus opening the way to more improvement and achievement. The interaction with the animal improves motor skills and social skills as well as other physical and behavioral challenges they might face (Imagine a wheelchair bound child sitting on a horse and looking down at people, from a position of strength, for the first time.)

 

Parents/Family members with special needs:

Parents with special needs children often feel overwhelmed and isolated. Through the community activity that therapeutic riding offers they are afforded the opportunity to share experiences, ideas, successes and disappointments with people who have similar situations and are able to lend an understanding and supportive ear, particularly in times of stress. The parents are the most important source of motivation and support for the child. It is vital that they be given as much assistance as possible in fulfilling this role.

 

Community:

Our primary target audiences are students in the public school system who have physical and behavioral special needs. At present there are over 700 students in our public schools with special needs that would benefit from therapeutic horseback riding. (We are currently serving 85+ students and want to enlarge our enrollment). We are also working with our County Health and Human Services as well as other organizations to provide a program for seniors who have special needs. We also have families who are economically disadvantaged that we help. The impact on the community when one of our beneficiaries succeeds and is able to function better in society and lead a more productive life is immeasurable.  

 

With your financial help we will achieve this ... It is a win-win situation!  

We are improving lives one stride at a time!

 

What We Need & What You Get


Yearly Costs for keeping one horse for NMCTR:

 

Basic veterinary care (check ups and inoculations): $150

Hoof trimming (around $40 every 6 weeks): $360

A year's worth of hay: $1,200

Boarding cost: $1,000  

Total: $2,710 per horse. Currently we have 10 horses. The cost to keep all of the horses for a year is $27,100. 

 

This year we would like to add two more horses to the NMCTR family. Each new horse would cost $2,500.

 

Your donation would go towards supporting the cost of the horses. Donating $25 would pay for one lesson with a horse. Donating $50 would pay for four bales of hay. Donating $100 would pay for three hoof trimmings. Besides the warm, fuzzy feeling you get from knowing that you made a difference, you also receive great NMCTR swag for your contribution! 

 

The NMCTR relies on donations and volunteering to stay in business. Grants and private donations provide most of our funding, also we rely on in-kind donations and volunteer time from the local community. We hold annual fundraising events locally. All of the funds we receive are managed through the Santa Fe Community Foundation, an organization with a proven record of making a difference in the community. Every penny donated makes a positive impact in the lives of people with special needs.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Would you like to get involved directly with the New Mexico Center for Therapeutic Riding? Email info@nmctr.org for volunteer opportunities. Are you looking for other ways to help? Share our campaign and website on Facebook, and become our friend!

 

Perks:

$25 â€“ Stable Person - Donating $25 pays for a lesson with a horse. For your donation, we will send you a sticker with the NMCTR logo.

 

$50 â€“ Hay Baler - Donating $50 buys four bales of hay of the horses, we will send you a NMCTR T-shirt for your contribution.

 

$100 â€“ Farrier - Donating $100 would help pay for 3 hoof trimmings, we will send you a NMCTR sweatshirt for your contribution.

 

We hope that you will join us in this mission.

 

Thank you!

story:
My name is Catrina Kroeger

I am in my second year as a student at Saint Mary's College of Notre Dame. I'm paying for all expenses myself, which has proven to be a struggle. I am currently pursuing a double major in Political Science and Spanish. I have a part-time job as a means to send myself to college. I participate in fund raising for Riley's Children's Hospital, in hopes of becoming a stronger candidate for future employers and a more connected future professional.

I have just recently decided to turn my Spanish minor into a second major. My dream is to spend the Spring 2013 academic semester in Seville, Spain as a part of my academic and personal growth. Spanish Studies Abroad is a program that provides an opportunity for U.S. students to live with a host family in another country. It allows us to enroll in a foreign university, participate in academic courses for credit. Study abroad is recognized by both academia and the workforce.

 

While I am in Spain, I will be attending La Universidad de Sevilla, and earning credits towards both of my majors. Most importantly, my goals are:

  • Language proficiency: to immerse myself in the Spanish language and culture, which will make me more knowledgeable about and able to communicate with a new interesting group of people.

  • To become a more productive member of society and my own community by utilizing the knowledge and perspectives I gain while abroad.

  • To obtain a degree in Spanish, so that I can use it as a means of gaining employment after graduation.

What I Need

The tuition cost of the Study Abroad program is the same as the cost of Saint Mary's tuition. This cost is $16,280 per semester. I have taken out $5000 in loans for this year. Room and board fee for the program is $5070, which I do not normally pay because I live off campus. This is what I need to first come up with, in order to go to Spain. The Study Abroad Fee is $360. This is a total of $5430 on top of all loans and expenses that I normally pay. The cost of the tuition for the program does not include airfare, visa/passport costs, books, materials/supplies, food or spending money while I am in Spain. According the the estimated costs, I will need roughly $2635 for these expenses. My ultimate goal is to raise $6,000 for this trip.

Join Me 

In exchange I am offering you the chance to join me in this venture and follow my journey. I have some awesome perks!

  • With a minimum of $10 you will be sent a personal thank you and newsletter about my campaign and trip.
  • If you donate just $15, I'll send you a postcard or souvenir from across the world!
  • If you donate $250 or more, I will donate a piece of my artwork to you. 

 

Your contributions, big or small will make such a difference.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that not everyone is in a place to contribute. I would be humbled by any financial contribution that you can make.

  • Spread the Word: Use the share tool above to tell your friends and family about my campaign.
  • Pray for me. 

The Impact

This is my dream. This trip is more than just about studying in Spain. I know this experience will shape my future professional life. I am committed to being a productive member of my community, and of society as a whole. This experience will allow me to communicate with an entirely new group of people. I will be able to connect with people from across the world, and I hope to create long-lasting relationships. 

I also plan on volunteering while in Spain, in some way.

I welcome you to join me in this journey. 

 

 

Muchas Gracias,

 

Catrina

story:
Short Summary

Greetings! My name is Rachel Simpson. For the last 6 years of my life, I've been passionately pursuing both my love to teach and visual arts. I began this path by going back to school at first to Whatcom Community College, then transferred to Western Washington University (WWU), to be in the Arts program, and I'm enrolled in Woodring College of Education for my degree in Secondary Arts Education (high school teaching).

After 5+ years of being a full-time student with a 3.5 GPA, I'm close to completing my Secondary Arts Education degree, with big dreams of becoming experienced in global teaching. The last phase of my program is to student teach Visual Arts next fall semester in a high school.

I've been given the chance to be a part of the Educators Abroad Program via WWU & Woodring College of Education, to go study abroad in Europe for 3 months. I hope to be placed in either Italy or Spain. Just by each one of you helping by giving a small amount of only $10-20 to raise these funds, I'll be able to afford my plane tickets & pay for the required student program fees.

What We Need & What You Get

  1. The costs of a round-trip flight range anywhere between $1100-$1500 and the Educators Abroad program fee is $300.
  2. By donating to this fund, you will enable me to study in an international high school along side a highly experienced educator, while learning what it is like to be immersed within another culture, within another country, to better my overall outlook on education and the visual arts.
  3. Even if I don't reach the final goal of $1500, I will still put it toward my planned trip to Europe in this program, for the upcoming fall semester. I'm utilizing every possible resource I have to come up with the total amount necessary to reach this new beginning in my life of multicultural education within the arts.

The Impact

You will be a part of a greater global community for our future in education, in our economy, critical thinking skills, and the future of our world becoming ever more global. Why? Because I very much plan to come back to the United States to teach students how to be creative, independent, critical thinkers, inventors, and to see the world in a much bigger picture.

I have already successfully observed and taught in both high school and a middle school, as a part of my independent studies and my practicum classes in college. I've been accepted to join the honors role as my GPA is a 3.5 while I continue my last quarter of classes over this school year.

I will be updating a Blog webpage with my daily opportunities, experiences, in both writing and photographs. (Either a Livejournal or a Google Blog & it will be updated here) You will be able to subscribe, read, comment, and watch to see how my trip to Europe will be. 

While I know this may seem like a pipe dream to be able to travel abroad to another country, I don't believe it is just that. It is a chance for me to grow and learn from an amazing experience, while at the same time, gaining the understanding, compassion, and knowledge of what I need to be a qualified, credited, and certified educator for Washington state. It is more than a dream. It is a vision that I am going to succeed at doing.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate to my fund, then you can do something just as important. You can spread the word to your friends and family. Every little drop helps add to the bucket of this big vision of a goal. You can also add www.indiegogo.com to your webpage, Facebook page, and even in your email to spread the word.

Thank you for all your time and efforts to reach my goal. You may or may not know how much this means to me, but I thank you again and again.

story:
“Until we're educating every kid in a fantastic way, until every inner city is cleaned up, there is no shortage of things to do.”

- Bill Gates  

 

Today there is an ever-widening gap emerging between those that succeed and those shun education (and lose out).  Disadvantaged students rarely have the opportunity to participate in learning opportunities that utilize higher technology (along with access to cutting-edge resources). Aside from access to resources, economic deprivation and social background are also major factors which can instill a sense of disillusion with education. 

≈

IT’S TIME TO PREPARE OUR YOUTH

FOR A BRIGHTER FUTURE WITH BETTER TOOLS!

 

 

 

In the Fall of 2012, 21st Century Youth Project (21CYP) will join forces with the House Development Corporation, as the technology component of the FirehouseCommunityArtsCenter.  This will enable us to actively reach out to (and enroll) around 50 students at a time. As the interest on-site continues to grow, we expect our enrollment rates to continue to climb upwards to as much as 200 youths per day. The House Development Corporation was the brainchild of Phil Jackson, who served for many years as youth pastor of Lawndale Community Church (under 'Coach' Wayne Gordon) and also created a unique hip-hop church for youth residing in North Lawndale. Embracing the hip-hop culture of rap, rhythm, graffiti, spoken word, and music, Pastor Phil and The House have been featured on NBC Nightly News, ABC7 news, BET, FOX, PBS, and WGN.

In 2007, the House Development Corporation bought a historic Chicago Firehouse to renovate for the purpose of becoming the FirehouseCommunityArtsCenter.   What was the purpose?  To be able to offer daily arts training and mentoring in a creative, nurturing environment, while teaching youth marketable skills through entrepreneurship.   

The 21st Century Youth Project strives to provide a high-quality, accessible and free after-school education that enables and empowers its diverse cluster of students in order to help develop their intellectual gifts. We are offering education and hi-tech training opportunities, and student success is one of our highest priorities; we aim to give students the chance to succeed by providing accessto tools that engage their interest and develop their leadership skills through entrepreneurial activity. Through the support of entrepreneurs and tech enthusiasts, students will develop the skills needed to succeed in the 21st century workplace. 

 

 “Innovation distinguishes between a leader and a follower.”

- Steve Jobs

Since 2011, the 21st Century Youth Project has been committed to providing access to advanced mobile technology and 21st century skills (which are necessary to become the tech leaders and creators of tomorrow) to youths from underrepresented communities.    

We’re Winning the Battle…

…But we Need your Help! 

≈

The Realities we are ALL Facing…

  • American students rank 25th in math and 21st in science, compared with students in 30 industrialized countries, and the Broad Foundation estimates $192 billion in lost income and taxes due to dropouts each year.
  • Only 15 % of US college students earn degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) areas compared to 50 % and higher overseas.  Because of this, the placement rate for Computer Science students can range upwards of 95% at leading universities.
  • According to Afterschool Alliance, more than 25% of America’s school children are on their own after 3pm on school days.

 

 

The program model for 21CYP is based on closing the technological achievement gap for students who lack access to good resources; while at the same time, giving them marketable entrepreneurial skills to be used to join the global STEM workforce. 

The 21st Century Youth Project (21CYP) selects low-income students in grades 5-12 and interjects the idea of spending more time on S.T.E.M. learning through means of real-life application.  21CYP is an after school model that’s broken into 4 x 13-week phases. 

≈

Phase 1:Immersion – Connect with fellow students and business/program directors.

Phase 2:Concept Development – Learn about building a product (i.e. a mobile app) while following a tailored curriculum that’s delivered to you by esteemed professionals.

Phase 3:Business Course – Collaborate with instructors to develop, practice, and deliver a pitch for “mobile app demo day”.

Phase 4:Post-21CYP Access– Alumni students are encouraged to share resources and engage in mentoring relationships.  

 

 

 

*Below are the current offerings that 21CYP specializes in:

  • Mobile App Development using the Google Android and iOS platform
  • SAT Math Training
  • Business Planning
  • Mentorship Programs 
    • Instructor Mentor, College Mentor, Community/ProfessionalMentor
  • Tutoring
  • Student Consulting Projects (Experiential Learning – students after 1yr. integrate 21CYP learning’s and work into the form of a deliverable product [web design, mobile app, etc.] for local businesses.)
  • Internship Placement
  • Alumni Community

 

The Impact

The 21CYP teaches students that…Technology is a path to Opportunity.  It is a free & comprehensive after school program that prepares low-income middle and high school students for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering & Math) careers. 

The program focuses on improving skills Today (through teaching and tutoring), Tomorrow (through coaching and mentoring), and In the Future (through internship placement) with an entrepreneurial focus. 

 

 

Deliverables for student participants include the creation of mobile apps (for Google Android, iPhone, iPad, etc.), accompanying business plans, accrual of college credits and case studies for their future resumes and portfolios (due to hands-on tangible skills gained through internship placements). 

21CYP harnesses a students’ natural enthusiasm for technology showing them how they can become the designers of the future; while at the same time, delivering foundational skills in STEM curricula.

The program has multiple levels of involvement not only training students in business, technology, and math, but also further developing their critical thinking skills, entrepreneurial abilitywhile bolstering self-confidence. The 21st Century Youth Project was inspired by the ideas outlined in Malcolm Gladwell’s book “Outliers: The Story of Success,” specifically the concept that “success is a matter of perfect placement, timing and training”.  

Since our launch in 2011, the 21st Century Youth Project has held its 13-week session programs in several cities covering Mobile Programming, SAT Math, and Entrepreneurship for youth ages 13-18 in Chicago. We are experiencing tremendous interest here in Chicago and in other cities as well. We will continue to work on partnering with local community centers to bring these service offerings into communities on a nationwide scale. We will also be launching a web-based platform similar to Khan Academy and other online schools, enabling our students to access tremendous instruction, without the additional costs incurred through traditional expansion. We can basically "flip the classroom" while adhering to a strict curriculum that engages a network of students which we hope to connect with engineering colleges and other institutions across the country.  

 

Even though our program is self-sustaining and is off to a great start, we do need your helpto continue to grow.  It is our goal to become the #1 go-to program in the community for cutting-edge technical resources and relevant training for underrepresented youth.    

This journey begins during our Firehouse partnership – 21CYP plans to reach more than 200 students by holding three weekly two-day sessions in 13-weeks.  

The 21st Century Youth Project has had a remarkable positive impact on our local Chicago communities.  Subsequently, we have also been featured on CNN, in magazines (Crain’s Chicago Business, SiliconAngle, and Techli), and has won a Gold award in education’s Best New Product in the Edison Awards by a selection panel that consisted of around 3,000 professionals, academics and specialists.

 

 

With your donation (and support) of 21CYP, we can introduce even more youth to the possibilities in the tech world.    
 

 

 

 

 

What We Need

If you’re ready to join up and make this exciting journey possible, have a look at what your direct contributions will accomplish:

  • Invest in a portable computer lab so we can take our workshops to the kids that need it the most! Purchase 15 loaner laptops and accessories.   $8000
  • Sponsor after-school registration fees for 30 youth in Chicago $3000
  • Supplement various program expenses, marketing materials, class materials, and travel expenses throughout Chicago $4500
  • Providestipends and expenses for our 21CYP Graduate Student Instructors $3000

 

   

What You Get  

Oh, the great "perks" you will receive in return…In addition to our immeasurable gratitude, we have selected a whole host of incentives and perks to accompany your generous contribution (in support of our cause).  

Please choose the donation level that is appropriate for you from the list on the right and we will send you both a token, and an expression of our gratitude.   

 

21st Century Youth Project in News:

  • Crain’s Chicago Business - http://bit.ly/vkCbAG 
  • CNN Video Feature - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xWvY9PqxwRc -
  • SiliconAngle - http://bit.ly/fV582v
  • Gold Medal Edison Award Press Release in Techli -  http://bit.ly/N4oIuP

≈

Other Ways You Can Help

Tweetabout it, Post the info all over the net, Blog about it, and just help us to get the word out! We truly appreciate your efforts to assist the 21CYP and its many grateful students.   Link up with our campaign across Facebook, Twitter, email, or any other avenue of communication that you can think of, so that we can let everyone know about the great work we are doing.  We need YOU to make this campaign a success! Let's do THIS!
story_txt:
“Until we're educating every kid in a fantastic way, until every inner city is cleaned up, there is no shortage of things to do.” 
- Bill Gates  
 
Today there is an ever-widening gap emerging between those that succeed and those shun education (and lose out).  Disadvantaged students rarely have the opportunity to participate in learning opportunities that utilize higher technology (along with access to cutting-edge resources). Aside from access to resources, economic deprivation and social background are also major factors which can instill a sense of disillusion with education. 
≈
IT’S TIME TO PREPARE OUR YOUTH
FOR A BRIGHTER FUTURE WITH BETTER TOOLS!
 
 
 
In the Fall of 2012, 21st Century Youth Project (21CYP) will join forces with the House Development Corporation, as the technology component of the FirehouseCommunityArtsCenter.  This will enable us to actively reach out to (and enroll) around 50 students at a time. As the interest on-site continues to grow, we expect our enrollment rates to continue to climb upwards to as much as 200 youths per day. The House Development Corporation was the brainchild of Phil Jackson, who served for many years as youth pastor of Lawndale Community Church (under 'Coach' Wayne Gordon) and also created a unique hip-hop church for youth residing in North Lawndale. Embracing the hip-hop culture of rap, rhythm, graffiti, spoken word, and music, Pastor Phil and The House have been featured on NBC Nightly News, ABC7 news, BET, FOX, PBS, and WGN.
In 2007, the House Development Corporation bought a historic Chicago Firehouse to renovate for the purpose of becoming the FirehouseCommunityArtsCenter.   What was the purpose?  To be able to offer daily arts training and mentoring in a creative, nurturing environment, while teaching youth marketable skills through entrepreneurship.   
The 21st Century Youth Project strives to provide a high-quality, accessible and free after-school education that enables and empowers its diverse cluster of students in order to help develop their intellectual gifts. We are offering education and hi-tech training opportunities, and student success is one of our highest priorities; we aim to give students the chance to succeed by providing accessto tools that engage their interest and develop their leadership skills through entrepreneurial activity. Through the support of entrepreneurs and tech enthusiasts, students will develop the skills needed to succeed in the 21st century workplace. 
 
 “Innovation distinguishes between a leader and a follower.” 
- Steve Jobs
Since 2011, the 21st Century Youth Project has been committed to providing access to advanced mobile technology and 21st century skills (which are necessary to become the tech leaders and creators of tomorrow) to youths from underrepresented communities.    
We’re Winning the Battle…
…But we Need your Help! 
≈
The Realities we are ALL Facing…

American students rank 25th in math and 21st in science, compared with students in 30 industrialized countries, and the Broad Foundation estimates $192 billion in lost income and taxes due to dropouts each year.
Only 15 % of US college students earn degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) areas compared to 50 % and higher overseas.  Because of this, the placement rate for Computer Science students can range upwards of 95% at leading universities.
According to Afterschool Alliance, more than 25% of America’s school children are on their own after 3pm on school days.
 
 
The program model for 21CYP is based on closing the technological achievement gap for students who lack access to good resources; while at the same time, giving them marketable entrepreneurial skills to be used to join the global STEM workforce. 
The 21st Century Youth Project (21CYP) selects low-income students in grades 5-12 and interjects the idea of spending more time on S.T.E.M. learning through means of real-life application.  21CYP is an after school model that’s broken into 4 x 13-week phases. 
≈
Phase 1:Immersion – Connect with fellow students and business/program directors.
Phase 2:Concept Development – Learn about building a product (i.e. a mobile app) while following a tailored curriculum that’s delivered to you by esteemed professionals.
Phase 3:Business Course – Collaborate with instructors to develop, practice, and deliver a pitch for “mobile app demo day”.
Phase 4:Post-21CYP Access– Alumni students are encouraged to share resources and engage in mentoring relationships.  
 
 
 
*Below are the current offerings that 21CYP specializes in:

Mobile App Development using the Google Android and iOS platform

SAT Math Training
Business Planning
Mentorship Programs 

Instructor Mentor, College Mentor, Community/ProfessionalMentor

Tutoring
Student Consulting Projects (Experiential Learning – students after 1yr. integrate 21CYP learning’s and work into the form of a deliverable product [web design, mobile app, etc.] for local businesses.)
Internship Placement

Alumni Community

 
The Impact
The 21CYP teaches students that…Technology is a path to Opportunity.  It is a free & comprehensive after school program that prepares low-income middle and high school students for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering & Math) careers. 
The program focuses on improving skills Today (through teaching and tutoring), Tomorrow (through coaching and mentoring), and In the Future (through internship placement) with an entrepreneurial focus. 
 
 
Deliverables for student participants include the creation of mobile apps (for Google Android, iPhone, iPad, etc.), accompanying business plans, accrual of college credits and case studies for their future resumes and portfolios (due to hands-on tangible skills gained through internship placements). 
21CYP harnesses a students’ natural enthusiasm for technology showing them how they can become the designers of the future; while at the same time, delivering foundational skills in STEM curricula.
The program has multiple levels of involvement not only training students in business, technology, and math, but also further developing their critical thinking skills, entrepreneurial abilitywhile bolstering self-confidence. The 21st Century Youth Project was inspired by the ideas outlined in Malcolm Gladwell’s book “Outliers: The Story of Success,” specifically the concept that “success is a matter of perfect placement, timing and training”.  
Since our launch in 2011, the 21st Century Youth Project has held its 13-week session programs in several cities covering Mobile Programming, SAT Math, and Entrepreneurship for youth ages 13-18 in Chicago. We are experiencing tremendous interest here in Chicago and in other cities as well. We will continue to work on partnering with local community centers to bring these service offerings into communities on a nationwide scale. We will also be launching a web-based platform similar to Khan Academy and other online schools, enabling our students to access tremendous instruction, without the additional costs incurred through traditional expansion. We can basically "flip the classroom" while adhering to a strict curriculum that engages a network of students which we hope to connect with engineering colleges and other institutions across the country.  
 
Even though our program is self-sustaining and is off to a great start, we do need your helpto continue to grow.  It is our goal to become the #1 go-to program in the community for cutting-edge technical resources and relevant training for underrepresented youth.    
This journey begins during our Firehouse partnership – 21CYP plans to reach more than 200 students by holding three weekly two-day sessions in 13-weeks.  
The 21st Century Youth Project has had a remarkable positive impact on our local Chicago communities.  Subsequently, we have also been featured on CNN, in magazines (Crain’s Chicago Business, SiliconAngle, and Techli), and has won a Gold award in education’s Best New Product in the Edison Awards by a selection panel that consisted of around 3,000 professionals, academics and specialists.
 
 
With your donation (and support) of 21CYP, we can introduce even more youth to the possibilities in the tech world.      
 
 
 
 
What We Need
If you’re ready to join up and make this exciting journey possible, have a look at what your direct contributions will accomplish:


Invest in a portable computer lab so we can take our workshops to the kids that need it the most! Purchase 15 loaner laptops and accessories.   $8000


Sponsor after-school registration fees for 30 youth in Chicago $3000


Supplement various program expenses, marketing materials, class materials, and travel expenses throughout Chicago $4500


Providestipends and expenses for our 21CYP Graduate Student Instructors $3000

 
   
What You Get  
Oh, the great "perks" you will receive in return…In addition to our immeasurable gratitude, we have selected a whole host of incentives and perks to accompany your generous contribution (in support of our cause).  
Please choose the donation level that is appropriate for you from the list on the right and we will send you both a token, and an expression of our gratitude.   
 
21st Century Youth Project in News:


Crain’s Chicago Business - http://bit.ly/vkCbAG 


CNN Video Feature - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xWvY9PqxwRc - 


SiliconAngle - http://bit.ly/fV582v


Gold Medal Edison Award Press Release in Techli -  http://bit.ly/N4oIuP

≈
Other Ways You Can Help
Tweetabout it, Post the info all over the net, Blog about it, and just help us to get the word out! We truly appreciate your efforts to assist the 21CYP and its many grateful students.   Link up with our campaign across Facebook, Twitter, email, or any other avenue of communication that you can think of, so that we can let everyone know about the great work we are doing.  We need YOU to make this campaign a success! Let's do THIS!

story:
Short Summary

Veterinarians Without Borders Czech Republic is a Public Benefit Corporation. The main goal is providing the developmental and humanitarian assistance in the area of veterinary and human medicine, agriculture and community development in the Third World countries under the slogan One Health: Healthy Animals = Healthy People. 

Since 2006, our pilot project is the vaccination campaign against rabies around Lake Turkana in North-East Kenya. In this area of extremely harsh climate, Rabies is still one of the major threaths to residing tribal people. As in other developmental countries, veterinary service in this area is very limited. Majority of the rabies cases, disease that is always deadly to infected humans, is among the local children due to the fact, that they spend most of the time with the local dogs on the pasture. In contrast to other diseases transmissible from animals to humans, rabies can be eliminated and controlled quite easily by preventive vaccination of potential reservoirs, in case of our project dogs and cats. Continuity of the project can only be achieved by every year re-vaccination of already vaccinated dogs and vaccination of new animals in the covered localities. The magnitude you will achieve as the contributors is the fact, that this will happen also in the year 2013.

What We Need & What You Get, The Impact

All the funding we will achive goes to realisation of the vaccination campaign in 2013. We estimated the costs needed based on our experience with this project in the past five years. Specifically, the funding goes to: flight tickets to Kenya for 4 veterinarians in the team, rent of the car to get from Nairobi to Lake turkana region in northern Kenya and back, material needed for vaccination of about 600 animals and a three week salary for for our local assistants. Based on the rough statistic data (always difficult to get in Africa), we might state that the continuation of this campaing will result in saving around 50 people in the discussed area. For us as a veterinarians, this is a great chance how to help in the areas where our knowledge and skills has such effect. As our contriburors, you will help us to help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you decide to help us financially, we really appreciate that! However, this is not the only way you can support us. Tell your friends, send them the link, share this campaing on Facebook and other social netwoks...simply, let people know about it!
