story:
Hello,

We have reached our initial funding goal. Thanks to all who participated. If further funds are raised we will first bring electricity to the school ($350.00) and second begin funding our Nepali Women's Scholarship Program!

Please come with me for a moment to Central Nepal.

My name is Todd and in 2011 I traveled to central Nepal to visit a small village and its school. I have assisted at various educational projects over the years but have decided to place all of my efforts here. In addition to the project described below we have begun a series of Social Businesses whose focus is in providing scholarships for young women in Nepal. So often they are unable to partake in higher education due to gender based socio-economic living conditions. Our current water project is described below.

 The Shree Saraswoti Kunja primary school is located in the village of Loruk in central Nepal, just outside of Pokhara. It is nestled in a valley of rice farmers surrounded by the foothills of the Himalayas. A beautiful place where subsistence living creates many boundaries. Food, clean water and education are just three. The government primary school is home to approximately 110 children with 85 attending on any given day. Only the basics are available at the six room school. No electricity, no water, some desks, a few books but I have to tell you; There is a tremendous amount of enthusiasm in the students for education. The teaching staff is kind, knowledgeable and motivated but is in need of help.

 We began working at the school in Loruk days after we arrived. We began by assessing the school structure itself. Windows were missing, doors were off their hinges, and floors were a mixture of dirt and degraded cement. Most of all the school needed paint. We decided we would begin these necessary repairs. Through the help of many volunteers, masons, woodworkers and dozens of paintbrushes we were able to restore the school to a colorful, clean focal point of education for the valley. Many thanks to all of the volunteers that helped with the project. Adam, Berry, Rosmary, Amy and Stephan to name just a few.

Books, teaching aids and basic supplies were also purchased. Later in the year we began the completion of an adjacent building that the Nepali government was unable to finish. Soon it too will be echoing the children's voices of grades 6 and 7.

 One major component that is missing at the school is clean water. Water for many uses but most importantly for drinking and personal hygiene.

 We have located a spring 2000 meters (1.3 miles) up the mountain that has fresh, cool, clean drinking water. This water is unpolluted and the owner of the land has agreed to allow us to tap into and create an intake to collect the water to. Tapping into the spring necessitates creating an intake, a sand filter and a 3,000 liter tank (750 gallons) at the spring-head. After the tank we will bury 1” pipe in the ground except where it needs to cross two rivers. We can’t cross the river below ground because during the monsoon season it becomes torrential rapids with large boulders constantly moving downstream. In order to cross the rivers we will need to change to metal pipe and elevate it for that part of its passage. On the waters gravity fed journey it will pass rice farms, small forests, livestock pens and vegetable gardens. When it arrives at the school we will place a 1000 liter (250 gallon) tank on the top of the school. From there the water will flow directly to taps for the children’s use.

 Water, such an essential that I feel we so often take for granted. What would we do without it? Or how would our lives be changed if it was rationed or not available? Can you imagine your early school years without available water?

 Our request for help is simple and I truly believe that your single act of kindness will be returned to you many times over. We have 2000 meters (6000 feet) to pipe the water to the school.

 If you could afford $5.00 it would purchase 5 meters (15 feet) of pipe and we will keep you updated on our progress and also send you a photo of the children.

 If you could afford $5.00 it would purchase 5 meters (15 feet) of pipe and we will keep you updated on our progress and also send you a photo of the children.

If you would be so kind to donate $25.00 it would purchase 25 meters (75 feet) of pipe and we will send you our heartfelt thanks, a photo and place your name on the section of pipe that you have purchased.

 If you would be able to donate $100.00 it would purchase 100 meters (300 feet) of pipe and we will send you a photo and place your name on the elevated sections of pipe that will be crossing the rivers.

 What better way of continuing your money’s work and the merit of your donation than having the water continuously passing by your name. Day by day, Year after year.

Thank you for this opportunity to present to you our request for funding, and please even if you cannot donate at this time help us by spreading the word.

 Sincerely,

Todd Pellizzer

story:
Send Steven to U.S.C.

Steven Taylor is from the small island of Trinidad & Tobago. He has been accepted to the Film School at U.S.C., but needs to have $56,291.00 available to him as part of the admissions process.

Steven is an aspiring film maker that has a unique oportunity to attend one of the oldest and most prostigious films schools in the world. We need t make his dream happen.

What We Need

As part of the admissions process, Steven needs to show a bank statement to the admissions office of U.S.C. that covers his first year tuition of $56,291.00.

Steven has reached out to local companies and the local Trinidad & Tobago film industry for assistance, but the response has been underwhelming and slow.

This is an URGENT request

The documents have to be send to U.S.C. admissions no later than April 1st, so this is an urgent request. Steven only found out about this earlier this month, and has been actively seeking support from the local business community since.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, PLEASE HELP US SPREAD THE WORD TO YOUR NETWORK AND SEND STEVEN TO U.S.C.!

story:
My Story:

Growing up in the Midwest for all 22 years of my life has limited the amount of diversity I’ve been able to experience. Since I was a little girl I have longed to understand others different than myself and serve those who are oppressed and discriminated against. I have simultaneously felt that same longing and passion for traveling to experience and understand diversity among cultures and the world around me. When I learned that I could work in a profession whose main focus is what I have longed to do since I was a little girl, I knew that I had to be a part of it. I am now in my senior year of college at Missouri State University where I am working towards finishing my bachelors in Social Work. To graduate from my program in May 2014, I must complete a 450-hour practicum. In the beginning of this semester I searched out international practicum opportunities in which I was officially offered a position with the Children and Youth Divisions of Social Services in Hudiksvall, Sweden. I will be living there for four months, from the beginning of January until the end of April.  

My role as a practicum student will be to facilitate and assist with assessments, case management, research, and groups, along with various other responsibilities that include working with and advocating on behalf of refugee children and youth. My personal goals for my practicum and this opportunity in general include:

  •  First and foremost, in everything I do, show unconditional love and support to those I come in contact with through my actions, speech, and life. 
  • Immerse myself in the culture in order to gain a stronger sense of cultural competence and sensitivity to human diversity. 
  • Apply social work theories, values, and ethics in practice. 
  • Step out of my comfort zone to gain more self-awareness through a totally new experience.       
  • Travel, learn, meet new people, serve others, and enjoy this journey!

 

I believe this opportunity has been divinely presented to me for a reason and I cannot wait to see what all is in store from here on out. While in Sweden, I will be involved in community building, strengthening families, and outreach efforts to serve refugee children and youth. By contributing to my campaign, you will not only help me achieve a personal dream, but you will be apart of the bigger picture:

  •  Bringing comfort and voice to children who are oppressed and in need.
  • Contributing to the understanding and collaboration of multiple cultures and nations.
  • Information and education allowing humanity to be one step closer to harmony among diversity.    

How You Can Help and What You'll Get in Return:

The total cost of my entire trip is approximately $6,000. A breakdown of the expected cost is as follows:

Airfare: $1,300

Housing: $2,000

Food: $1,000

Misc (travel within Sweden, Visa expenses, etc.): $1,500

I am only asking for $2,000 to confirm my housing arrangements while living in Sweden for four months. This will give me a good financial head start for my new journey. Anything raised over that amount will contribute to the remaining expenses of this experience. Your generous donations will be very appreciated and in turn you can receive some neat perks!

$5: Thank you, thank you! Your support means so much. Every dollar will go towards getting me to Sweden and efforts to serve others while there.

$15: Email Updates. You will get bi-monthly email updates about what is going on with me and the work I’m doing in Sweden.

$25: Shout out from Sweden. I will give you a personal thank you shout out on the blog I will be keeping while in Sweden, along with all preceding perks.

$50: Picture from Sweden. You will get a picture of me in Sweden, holding a sign with your name tagged on Facebook, along with all preceding perks.

$100: From Sweden With Love. You will get a post card from Sweden, personally addressed from me, along with all preceding perks.

$500: Skype from Sweden. You will have the opportunity to personally skype with me about my experience and the work I have been doing while in Sweden, along with all preceding perks.

$1,000: Documentation of my Experience. You will get a video presentation of my experience while in Sweden sent you to, as well as a picture of me at my graduation, along with all preceding perks.

Other Ways You Can Help:

I understand that not everyone can contribute financially and that's okay! Other ways you can be involved and help is by spreading the word. Tell a friend or share my story to facebook, twitter, etc. by using the Indiegogo share tools. Anything will help :)
story_txt:
My Story:
Growing up in the
Midwest for all 22 years of my life has limited the amount of diversity I’ve
been able to experience. Since I was a little girl I have longed to understand
others different than myself and serve those who are oppressed and discriminated against. I have
simultaneously felt that same longing and passion for traveling to experience
and understand diversity among cultures and the world around me. When I learned
that I could work in a profession whose main focus is what I have longed to do
since I was a little girl, I knew that I had to be a part of it. I am now in my
senior year of college at Missouri State University where I am working towards
finishing my bachelors in Social Work. To graduate from my program in May 2014,
I must complete a 450-hour practicum. In the beginning of this semester I
searched out international practicum opportunities in which I was officially
offered a position with the Children and Youth Divisions of Social Services in
Hudiksvall, Sweden. I will be living there for four months, from the beginning
of January until the end of April.  
My
role as a practicum student will be to facilitate and assist with assessments,
case management, research, and groups, along with various other
responsibilities that include working with and advocating on behalf of refugee
children and youth. My personal goals for my practicum and this opportunity in
general include:



 First and
foremost, in everything I do, show unconditional love and support to those I
come in contact with through my actions, speech, and life. 

Immerse
myself in the culture in order to gain a stronger sense of cultural competence
and sensitivity to human diversity. 
Apply social
work theories, values, and ethics in practice. 
Step out of
my comfort zone to gain more self-awareness through a totally new experience.       

Travel,
learn, meet new people, serve others, and enjoy this journey!



 I
believe this opportunity has been divinely presented to me for a reason and I
cannot wait to see what all is in store from here on out. While in Sweden, I
will be involved in community building, strengthening families, and outreach
efforts to serve refugee children and youth. By contributing to my campaign,
you will not only help me achieve a personal dream, but you will be apart of
the bigger picture:


 Bringing comfort and voice to children who are oppressed and in need.
Contributing to the understanding and collaboration of multiple cultures and
nations.

Information and education allowing humanity to be one step closer to harmony
among diversity.    



How You Can Help and What You'll Get in Return:
The total cost of my entire trip is approximately $6,000. A breakdown of the expected cost is as follows:
Airfare: $1,300
Housing: $2,000
Food: $1,000
Misc (travel within Sweden, Visa expenses, etc.): $1,500
I am only asking
for $2,000 to confirm my housing arrangements while living in Sweden for four
months. This will give me a good financial head start for my new journey.
Anything raised over that amount will contribute to the remaining expenses of
this experience. Your generous donations will be very appreciated and in turn
you can receive some neat perks!
$5: Thank you,
thank you! Your support means so much. Every dollar will go towards getting me
to Sweden and efforts to serve others while there.
$15: Email
Updates. You will get bi-monthly email updates about what is going on with me
and the work I’m doing in Sweden. 
$25: Shout out
from Sweden. I will give you a personal thank you shout out on the blog I will be
keeping while in Sweden, along with all preceding perks.
$50: Picture from
Sweden. You will get a picture of me in Sweden, holding a sign with your name
tagged on Facebook, along with all preceding perks.
$100: From Sweden With Love. You will get a post card from Sweden, personally addressed from me,
along with all preceding perks. 
$500: Skype from
Sweden. You will have the opportunity to personally skype with me about my experience and the
work I have been doing while in Sweden, along with all preceding perks. 
$1,000:
Documentation of my Experience. You will get a video presentation of my experience
while in Sweden sent you to, as well as a picture of me at my graduation, along
with all preceding perks.


Other Ways You Can Help:
I understand that not everyone can contribute financially and that's okay! Other ways you can be involved and help is by spreading the word. Tell a friend or share my story to facebook, twitter, etc. by using the Indiegogo share tools. Anything will help :)

story:
LAST DAY!!!!! New target: £3,800!!! Lets go!!!!!!

ALL FURTHER FUNDS ARE BEING DONATED TO THE 'AFRICA SINOMUSA FOUNDATION'- a grass-root organisation in the township of Khayelitsha

Nomsa, the founder: "Africa Sinomusa Foundation, is a community initiative, a non-profit organisation that makes a difference to the lives of children experiencing poverty. We believe that every child has the right to experience happiness. Our programmes promote the welfare of children and the youth with the aim of empowering them to overcome challenges on both a community and global level."


I know from first hand experience what an incredible charity this is, now we can really go for it! Contribute away! You will get evidence of the joy it will create!

http://uckfieldnews.com/uckfield-people-asked-to-help-with-fund-raising-campaign/



My name is Natalie Armitage. I am a postgraduate student in the UK studying a masters degree in Human Rights.

If you are reading this, you are part of the same international community that supported a worldwide campaign to release Mandela from prison on Robben Island. At the time, people outside of Africa felt insignificant to the larger struggle at stake within. However- when the world almost gave up that the South African government would ever listen, they announced they were going to negotiate. One contribution in support, even from a person a million miles out of South Africa: can go a long, long, long way.

The South African Reconciliation Barometer survey, December 2013, showed that class inequality in South Africa continues to reflect racial divisions. In addition to that, it has become the greatest impediment to national reconciliation, preventing the country from moving forward. In 2014, it shouldn't be this way. 

What it means: When it comes to poverty, race and class there is a real problem. Sir Nelson Mandela's life work…isn’t finished. We have to carry it on.

The Impact

Education, knowledge and research are crucial. I believe that creating global dialogue about issues that remain challenges in South Africa, inducing discussions around race and class economic injustice, supporting ideas with detailed evidence and academic research- will have an impact. It might not solve anything overnight, it may take 27 years…but we must not give up.

Reconciliation wasn't just a political process that happened, it was a personal experience for millions of people. Social divisions across boundaries of race and class can be overcome. We can build bridges with stronger, more meaningful relationships between us. Democracy alone, can't do it for us.

What is so important about this research, is that is covers and issue that isn’t just true for the situation in South Africa. Countries across the world where division across racial boundaries still exists, including in my own the UK, can be improved. The dissertation I’m writing is on a concept called ‘Radical Reconciliation’. Be a part of this project and have your own say.

What I need, What you get & Who will benefit:

I need to raise £2,800 to go to the Institute for Justice and Reconciliation in Cape Town. This target will fund the research, travel, basic accommodation and living costs while the information needed is collected.

The Perks!! I have designed every single one to be personal and contribute to the greater vision of the project. These are exclusive, unique to this project only.

Your name can be stamped on the dissertation, addressed on a postcard, pinned to original art by children in the townships or literally carried, by me, all the way to Robben Island. I want you to be a part of this journey.

Extra contributions over the target amount will be donated to The Africa Sinomusa Foundation, a grass-root charity based in Khayelitsha. It provides support programs designed for young people vulnerable to criminal activity growing up in the townships. I know from personal first hand experience, what a noble cause it is.

In 2009, I volunteered there and was deeply affected by the poverty that appeared to shadow the boundaries that apartheid left. The community building we were operating in, burnt down, so I campaigned online and offline, to get a new one built. It took a lot of hard work and much help from international volunteers, but in time they managed to secure a new one, with additional new equipment.

Where I was influenced the most, was going through the painful process of securing food donations from local factories and suppliers, even just for fruit and vegetables they were planning to throw away. We made this into soup to feed long lines of hungry people across the townships. Physically feeding children that hadn't eaten a nutritious meal in days, is an experience that changed my life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page!!

Share on your facebook wall, twitter, blog it, email it, instagram it, snapchat about it, spread the message as far and wide as you can. How far the project can go is driven by how far this page reaches in 60 days.

Once you have shared because you care, get your friends and relatives to as well!

Remember, 60 days are on the clock for this page to reach as many people as possible and you are the person to make that happen.

Contributing to this project is a step forward. Let's keep walking.

just for fruit and vegetables they were planning to throw away. We made this into soup to feed long lines
of hungry people across the townships. Physically feeding children that hadn't eaten a nutritious meal in days, is an experience that changed my life.
Other Ways You Can Help
Share this page!! 
Share on your facebook wall, twitter, blog it, email it, instagram it, snapchat about it, spread the message as far and wide as you can. How far the project can go is driven by how far this page reaches in 60 days.
Once you have shared because you care, get your friends and relatives to as well! 
Remember, 60 days are on the clock for this page to reach as many people as possible and you are the person to make that happen.
Contributing to this project is a step forward. Let's keep walking.

story:
Let's make the first public library in Pomacocha, Ayacucho, Peru!

High in the Peruvian Andes, the historic village of Pomacocha is nestled among high cliffs, rivers and volcanic mountains. With a population of around 800-1000 people, Pomacocha boasts a preschool, a primary school, and a high school. Despite the curiosity and enthusiasm of the students, Pomacocha does not have a public library. The schoolchildren have only basic textbooks that emphasize memorization of facts. Because of the lack of resources in Pomacocha, the schools cannot afford to buy non-curriculum books. We all can remember books that were crucial in changing the way we see the world and changing our lives for the better. By helping fund this project, we can expand imagination and opportunities for the children of Pomacocha. We can help them become more competitive so that they can go to college and make a positive difference in their own village.

The idea for this project started in 2011 when I carried out an archaeological project in the community. The high school students reached out to the project and gave their enthusiastic support and participation. They even participated in the excavations one day! That year, they made me the madrina, or godmother, of their graduating class.

The teachers expressed their regret that neither they nor their students had access to quality books. The next summer, in 2012, I bought seven books for the high school; the teachers were very appreciative and said that the books had helped them in their teaching.

The next summer, in 2013, I met with the director of the high school to formalize plans for installing a library for the students of Pomacocha. The letter from the high school principal states that "At present, we have more than 150 students...who do not have an accessible library to do their homework...The enrolled students come from various communities such as Quillqui, Hercomarca, Qollpacucho, Pucaragay and other close communities; students who are generally from precarious economic conditions..." You can view a scan of the letter in the gallery tab.

Pomacocha and its neighboring villages are listed as communities in poverty or extreme poverty by INEI (Instituto Nacional de Estadística e Informática). There are few opportunities for employment, and when there are, people have to walk 3-4 hours to get paid about 8 dollars for a whole day's hard labor. Despite the lack of opportunities, the students have an unquenchable desire to learn and improve their own lives as well as those of their families.

What We Need & What You Get

For the first phase of the public library project, we plan to install two bookshelves in one of the less used rooms of the high school. That room currently has a few computers for typing documents. You will receive updates and photographs from the field. Also, be aware that ALL the funds I receive will go straight to the books and bookshelves. That means I'm personally covering the shipping to Peru, shipping within Peru (about half or more of the books will be purchased in Peru itself), logistics, and the framed list of benefactors. We plan to stock the shelves with about eighty accessibly written books in the following categories:

Fiction, World Cultures, History, Astronomy, Science and Technology, Animal Kingdom, Human Biology, Art, and Botany.

Your donation will go straight to the purchase of the books and to the construction of the bookshelves. The books will be primarily in Spanish, and a few will be in Quechua, the local indigenous language.

The more money donated, the more books there will be! Each book costs 10-40 dollars.

In exchange for your donation, you can get one of the perks listed. The list of possible perks include:

1) Your name on a framed list of benefactors to be hung inside the library.

2) Adopted book- A book will bear your name on the inside cover on a dedicatory bookplate. Via email, I will send you a photo of the book bearing your name, as well as a photo of your book in Pomacocha.

3) A personalized black and white drawing of your favorite animal doing a favorite activity (Various sizes available: see “Perks” for more details). Think about why you love those animals and those hobbies/activities. Could the books you read have anything to do with those?

4) A personalized color painting of your favorite animal doing a favorite activity (Various sizes available: see “Perks” for more details).

For the art, you can request characteristics of the animal: realistic vs. cartoony, resemblance to a photo of your pet, or an animal anthropomorphized to look like yourself.

Below is an example of a painting of a bunny and bee that I painted recently.


An example of my black and white line drawings can be found in the gallery.

The Impact

Books are one of the most sustainable ways of enriching young peoples' lives. By helping Pomacocha build and stock the first public library in the whole province, you are taking part in the beginning of a bright future. Depending on the success of phase I, the library project may expand book donations in not only Pomacocha, but also to other villages in the province such as Vilcashuaman. 

When I was a child growing up in some of the poorest neighborhoods of Cleveland, Ohio, two things made my daily life happy. One was free lunch in school, and the other was free access to books at the public library. The children and high school students of Pomacocha have neither. Without a doubt, the public library had positive long-term contributions to the improvement of my life. Let's start making a real difference today in Pomacocha and its surrounding villages!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

•You can forward this campaign to your friends and family!

•You can send suggestions for books in Spanish, for children and/or young adults, to dihuster_at_gmail.com

• If you have books to donate and will be in Lima, Peru in June, I will gladly accept the books. To coordinate, please send an email to dihuster_at_gmail.com to make sure that we will overlap in Lima.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
ClassBytes

Our goal is to pass on the knowledge and skills necessary to help the next generation of electronic tinkerers and computer programmers.


ClassBytes will offer:


-Education - classes geared toward beginning & advanced students


-Mentoring – giving students an  environment where knowledge, self guided research, & leadership can be developed


-Outreach - bringing together students from the Austin, Cedar Park, Pflugerville, & Round Rock, TX communities to educate the future thinkers of the world.


ClassBytes brings a fun, interactive computer & electronics lab to the home school and after school communities.
With your help, we hope to set up a computer lab to educate students ages 13 - 99 in basic to advanced computer & electronic skills.






Background

Hi! My name is George and I am trying to bring my vision of Class Bytes to life!


It was Christmas 1989. Under the tree I would find a Vtech Laser 50 Educational Computer, and my interest in computers was born!




My fascination with computers grew watching my older brother play video games.  We had several gaming systems: the Atri 2600, Coleco Vision, ADAM computer system. He and I played PacMan, Tapper, Fortune Builder, and occasionally I would watch him program in Logo.


In retrospect, I must pay homage to my great high school computer science teacher, Ms Thompson.  She helped to cement my enjoyment of computers & played a vital role in advancing my education. It wasn't long before I discovered my love for computers & electronics!


I have a passion for computers!  From my “orange” screen luggable 45 Hz Gridcase Model 1520...


...to the many different Windows and Linux machines I have built over the years!


While attending the University of Texas at Austin, I worked in the  W. R. Woolrich Computer Lab. There, I maintained the computer lab with over 40 PCs running a variety of engineering software, such as Matlab and Mathematica.



After attending the University of Texas for Computer Science, I worked for International Business Machines.

At IBM, I tested and debugged laptops before they hit the production line.


I was then recruited by the up and coming computer company Dell. There, I installed custom software on business machines – sometimes the orders totalled over 1000 computers a day!

Then one day I noticed that I was not doing what I enjoyed – tinkering with, and teaching others about, computers.  I decided that I wanted to start my own lab, geared toward teaching young "novices" about the things I love most - Computers! 

So, in August of 2012, ClassBytes.net was born, and the journey to start my own computer lab had begun! 


Now you can find Class Bytes on Facebook and Twitter, where I post ideas & projects for future Class Bytes activities!


I have developed curriculums for:

-Introduction to Computer Hardware
-Introduction Web Design
-Advanced Web Design
-Introduction Programing
-Advanced Programing  
-Introduction to Game Design
-Advanced Game Design
-Introduction to Electronics


I am currently managing a network of five Raspberry Pi Linux based computers(see below for more details)



I have started to make contacts with local after school, home school, and church communities



The Lab!



After much research, I have decided to make the Raspberry Pi the main cornerstone of the computer lab. For those of you that are not familiar with the Raspberry Pi, it is a very compact computer that was developed with computer and electronic education in mind.



The Raspberry Pi is a small computer that was designed for programming and electrical experimentation. The computer was developed with Python, which is great programming language to introduce new students to the world of programming. The Raspberry Pi is also capable of running many of the leading programming languages of today – including C, C++, and Java. 


Ever since the Raspberry Pi appeared, the Internet has been a buzz with different DIY (Do-It-Yourself) projects & self-made experiments which create new and interesting devices that, just a few years ago, would not have been possible.


Raspberry Pi with Breadboard.

A breadboard is used to test electrical circuits without the need to permanently solder wires in place. This way, you can quickly test circuit designs. In the above picture, the Raspberry Pi is controlling 3 LEDs (Light Emitting Diodes) which blink, controlled by software on the Raspberry Pi.


Raspberry Pi & Monitor powered by AA batteries

The above image highlights the portability of the Raspberry Pi system. Here we have the Raspberry Pi & monitor running on several AA Batteries. The display screen is a low-powered TFT (Thin Film Transistor) 7in. monitor.

One benefit of Class Bytes' Computer Lab is that it will be completely mobile. The entire “Rasberry Pi Lab” can be packed up & easily transported to homes, outdoor class projects, or events!



Another goal of the fund raiser is to acquire 10 Snap Circuits kits (SC-750R Student Stations) to go along with each computer station.


Snap Circuits SC-750R Kit


The SC750R is a great, all-encompassing system for learning electronics in a safe & exciting way. There is limitless room for experimentation, and the system is battery powered & very portable.



Where Your Funding Goes-


The main expense in creating Class Bytes' Computer Lab, is the lab itself.


I have searched & discovered the most economic way to get as many working computers into a lab with as little set-up as possible.

A Raspberry Pi Computer Workstation


A Single Raspberry Pi Computer Workstation costs between $75-$150, and includes:

-Raspberry Pi Computer (w/protective case)

-Monitor

-Keyboard

-Mouse

-SD Card

 
One goal of this Class Bytes fundraiser is to fund the purchase of 6 more computer stations.  This would bring the total number of student lab stations to 10.


If the fundraiser yields more than our goals, additional computer systems can be purchased for loaning to students that do not have access to computers at home, and for community events & workshops for underprivileged students.


To be more concise, funding will go to:


1. More Raspberry Pi Computers


2. Needed Computer Peripherals, such as Keyboards, Mice, SD cards, Power Cables, Wireless Cards, & Monitors


3. Snap Circuits SC-750R Student Training Electronic Kits


4. Tools & Parts necessary for running Electronic Experiments, including:

    -Breadboards

    -Cables (Copper Wire)

    -Batteries

    -LED's (Light Emitting Diodes)

    -Motors

    -Sensors

    -Transistors, Resisters, Diodes, etc.


5. A Video Projector & Projection Screen that will allow the students to see the Teacher's Computer Screen in Real Time 


6. Desks, Chairs, Office Supplies & Other Classroom-Related Necessities


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in the Austin, TX area and have office supplies, computer accessories, desks, chairs, tables, or other equipment you are interested in donating to Class Bytes, or if you would like to volunteer your time or services for class projects and/or community events, please contact us via email and we will be happy to make arrangements!
story_txt:
ClassBytes
Our goal is to pass on the knowledge and skills necessary to help the next generation of electronic tinkerers and computer programmers.


ClassBytes will offer:

-Education - classes geared toward beginning & advanced students


-Mentoring – giving students an  environment where knowledge, self guided research, & leadership can be developed-Outreach - bringing together students from the Austin, Cedar Park, Pflugerville, & Round Rock, TX communities to educate the future thinkers of the world.

ClassBytes brings a fun, interactive computer & electronics lab to the home school and after school communities.With your help, we hope to set up a computer lab to educate students ages 13 - 99 in basic to advanced computer & electronic skills.
BackgroundHi! My name is George and I am trying to bring my vision of Class Bytes to life!
It was Christmas 1989. Under the tree I would find a Vtech Laser 50 Educational Computer, and my interest in computers was born!


My fascination with computers grew watching my older brother play video games.  We had several gaming systems: the Atri 2600, Coleco Vision, ADAM computer system. He and I played PacMan, Tapper, Fortune Builder, and occasionally I would watch him program in Logo.In retrospect, I must pay homage to my great high school computer science teacher, Ms Thompson.  She helped to cement my enjoyment of computers & played a vital role in advancing my education. It wasn't long before I discovered my love for computers & electronics!
I have a passion for computers!  From my “orange” screen luggable 45 Hz Gridcase Model 1520...

...to the many different Windows and Linux machines I have built over the years!While attending the University of Texas at Austin, I worked in the  W. R. Woolrich Computer Lab. There, I maintained the computer lab with over 40 PCs running a variety of engineering software, such as Matlab and Mathematica.

After attending the University of Texas for Computer Science, I worked for International Business Machines.At IBM, I tested and debugged laptops before they hit the production line. 
I was then recruited by the up and coming computer company Dell. There, I installed custom software on business machines – sometimes the orders totalled over 1000 computers a day!

Then one day I noticed that I was not doing what I enjoyed – tinkering with, and teaching others about, computers.  I decided that I wanted to start my own lab, geared toward teaching young "novices" about the things I love most - Computers!  So, in August of 2012, ClassBytes.net was born, and the journey to start my own computer lab had begun!  

Now you can find Class Bytes on Facebook and Twitter, where I post ideas & projects for future Class Bytes activities!


I have developed curriculums for:-Introduction to Computer Hardware-Introduction Web Design-Advanced Web Design-Introduction Programing-Advanced Programing  -Introduction to Game Design-Advanced Game Design-Introduction to ElectronicsI am currently managing a network of five Raspberry Pi Linux based computers(see below for more details)


I have started to make contacts with local after school, home school, and church communities
The Lab!



After much research, I have decided to make the Raspberry Pi the main cornerstone of the computer lab. For those of you that are not familiar with the Raspberry Pi, it is a very compact computer that was developed with computer and electronic education in mind.The Raspberry Pi is a small computer that was designed for programming and electrical experimentation. The computer was developed with Python, which is great programming language to introduce new students to the world of programming. The Raspberry Pi is also capable of running many of the leading programming languages of today – including C, C++, and Java.  
Ever since the Raspberry Pi appeared, the Internet has been a buzz with different DIY (Do-It-Yourself) projects & self-made experiments which create new and interesting devices that, just a few years ago, would not have been possible.Raspberry Pi with Breadboard. 
A breadboard is used to test electrical circuits without the need to permanently solder wires in place. This way, you can quickly test circuit designs. In the above picture, the Raspberry Pi is controlling 3 LEDs (Light Emitting Diodes) which blink, controlled by software on the Raspberry Pi. Raspberry Pi & Monitor powered by AA batteries
The above image highlights the portability of the Raspberry Pi system. Here we have the Raspberry Pi & monitor running on several AA Batteries. The display screen is a low-powered TFT (Thin Film Transistor) 7in. monitor. One benefit of Class Bytes' Computer Lab is that it will be completely mobile. The entire “Rasberry Pi Lab” can be packed up & easily transported to homes, outdoor class projects, or events! 


Another goal of the fund raiser is to acquire 10 Snap Circuits kits (SC-750R Student Stations) to go along with each computer station.

Snap Circuits SC-750R Kit


The SC750R is a great, all-encompassing system for learning electronics in a safe & exciting way. There is limitless room for experimentation, and the system is battery powered & very portable.Where Your Funding Goes-
The main expense in creating Class Bytes' Computer Lab, is the lab itself.

I have searched & discovered the most economic way to get as many working computers into a lab with as little set-up as possible.

A Raspberry Pi Computer Workstation


A Single Raspberry Pi Computer Workstation costs between $75-$150, and includes:
-Raspberry Pi Computer (w/protective case)
-Monitor
-Keyboard
-Mouse
-SD Card
  One goal of this Class Bytes fundraiser is to fund the purchase of 6 more computer stations.  This would bring the total number of student lab stations to 10.


If the fundraiser yields more than our goals, additional computer systems can be purchased for loaning to students that do not have access to computers at home, and for community events & workshops for underprivileged students.

To be more concise, funding will go to:

1. More Raspberry Pi Computers

2. Needed Computer Peripherals, such as Keyboards, Mice, SD cards, Power Cables, Wireless Cards, & Monitors

3. Snap Circuits SC-750R Student Training Electronic Kits

4. Tools & Parts necessary for running Electronic Experiments, including:
    -Breadboards

    -Cables (Copper Wire)

    -Batteries
    -LED's (Light Emitting Diodes) 

    -Motors
    -Sensors
    -Transistors, Resisters, Diodes, etc.


5. A Video Projector & Projection Screen that will allow the students to see the Teacher's Computer Screen in Real Time  


6. Desks, Chairs, Office Supplies & Other Classroom-Related Necessities

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are in the Austin, TX area and have office supplies, computer accessories, desks, chairs, tables, or other equipment you are interested in donating to Class Bytes, or if you would like to volunteer your time or services for class projects and/or community events, please contact us via email and we will be happy to make arrangements!

story:
I've been extremely fortunate in my life to travel to many parts of the world and to discover firsthand the wondrous web of communities that exist out there.  It's one of the great passions of my life, stemming not only from my love of languages but from my own experiences of living abroad and discovering the "other".  In my career, my work has concentrated on helping younger adults reach their goals in terms of cross-cultural experiences, since I myself had felt such an enormous impact from those "abroad" experiences.  In January of 2013, almost one year ago, I was fortunate enough to co-lead a community service program to Peru, through the Adelphi University's College of Nursing and Public Health.  Not only was I re-visiting a country that I had never expected to see again, but this time, I was able to participate and watch as these young students were touched by the different communities we worked with.  Among a small Willoq village, we helped to hoe fields with traditional tools.  We learned how they cooked their staples in their wood stoves.  We created "dream pillows" with the children and got to learn what made up their visions of the world and of their future.  We attended to young burn victims at a clinic, distributed Toms shoes to school children, visited with a local (and locally sustainable) orphanage located under the glacier peaks of the sacred valley and  helped in a clinic for the local poor.  It was remarkable how much we could help in such a short amount of time.  It was touching to work with the children and to see my own students transformed by the experience.  The most memorable moment was at a school along the coast where we had done a bit of health training and distributed shoes to all of the kids.  At the end of the day, I was waiting in the clinic for my group to finish and one of the little girls came in with her mother.  She saw me and sat for a second with her mother before coming over to give me a hug and a little kiss on the cheek.  It was so sweet.  She was so happy to have new shoes.


In January, I have another great opportunity to do some good.  I will be accompanying another trip through the College of Nursing, this time to Guatemala, where we will be stationed with an organization called Mayan Families (link below), which works with all ages within the local Panajachel community to deliver services and goods, from education to medicine to food for the elderly.  Our students will be performing health assessments for the children, audiology screenings for the elderly, building stoves for local homes and learning about nursing practices in their community.  


This morning, I was inspired to take this extra step to see who might like to help.  There is no perk, no flash or gimmick.  A simple request at the year's end to help me (and us) start 2014 on a kind foot.


My intention is to donate all of the funds to their educational programs, so that young children can receive the supplies and education that may better help the community.


I thank you for your time in reading this and look forward to helping.


http://mayanfamilies.org/

story:
Hi, 

My name is Jerri Johnson.  I am a single mother and Doctoral Student at the University of Missouri-St. Louis in the department of Teaching and Learning.  I am entering my 17th year as an educator in urban and suburban districts in St. Louis, Missouri, Indianapolis, Indiana, and Kansas City, Missouri.  I have served as a classroom teacher, Reading Specialist, Instructional Coach, Assistant Principal and District Administrator.  Currently, I am an Instructional Coach trying to complete my Doctorate program (Ph.D.). 

I have an chance, through the University, to present my research at an international conference in Bangkok, Thailand in January.  Even though I have not completed my research the opportunity has presented itself and I am excited. However, there are expenses to be paid before I can go.  The prospect of presenting my research to an international audience before it is even completed if HUGE!  The feedback that I could receive would be priceless! I would also get to visit schools and colleges in order to observe teaching and learning in Thailand.  Eventually I would like to publish my research in an international journal and continue to provide more research in the area of teaching and learning (education).  

I love being an educator and any chance I get to further my craft and give back to my community, parents, colleagues and students, I try to take advantage of it.  Your contribution would greatly help me in this endeavor. 

What I Need 

The total amount that I would need would be $3000. This would cover the cost of my travel, transportation and meals while presenting at the conference.  The university will be taking care of the hotel stay. I also will have to register for 4 extra credit hours  for the spring semester, this will cost me $1600. If I do not reach my entire goal the funds will be applied to my travel first ($1400). JUST $100 from 30 people can get me there!!!

The Impact

I'm sure that you have known or know a undergraduate, graduate or doctoral student. The financial pressure of being a single mother and student is high. Meanwhile the cost of tuition and educating yourself is rising.  I plan to teach our future teachers using my doctorate degree that I will be obtaining in December 2014. Your contribution will get me one step closer to contributing to the education of future students and teachers. My hope is that this will be the first of many international conferences In which i will attend and present in my quest for knowledge regarding the international education of students. I would love if YOU could help me contribute to OUR future! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if YOU can't contribute at this time I appreciate you reading about my campaign.  If you could do me a favor and tell your friends that would great! Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! Our names are Marwin Arellano and Elizabeth Sanchez.

We are two first generation Latino students, passionate about social justice and education as a form of empowerment.  We want to participate in a Literacy Brigade in San Salvador, El Salvador this summer with CISPES (Commitee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador).  In this Literacy Brigade, we will be promoting the literacy program in communities where it is needed most, doing outreach to get more community members involved in this critical and resource limited program, and attending local literacy circles where we will be assisting volunteers.  We believe that education is a fundamental step in empowering ourselves and our communities, that international solidarity is critical, and that both of these things are needed towards envisioning and enacting social justice. 

¡Hola! Nos llamamos Marwin Arellano y Elizabeth Sanchez.

Somos dos estudiantes latinos de primera generación, apasionados por la justicia social y la educación como una forma de empoderamiento. Queremos participar en un Programa de Alfabetización en San Salvador, El Salvador este verano con CISPES.  En este program, estaremos promoviendo el programa de alfabetización en las comunidades donde más se necesita, haciendo difusión para conseguir más miembros de la comunidad que participan en este programa crítico y de recursos mínimos, y asistir a los círculos de alfabetización locales donde se asisten a los voluntarios. Creemos que la educación es un paso fundamental en la potenciación de nosotros mismos y nuestras comunidades, que la solidaridad internacional es fundamental, y que ambas cosas son necesarias para imaginar la promulgación de la justicia social.

What We Need:

We need 4,000 dollars to help offset the cost for both of us to get there and participate.  As students, we don't have much money, so any support helps!  Donations will be spent on:

-Airfare   

-Housing

-Supplies to take such as: pencils,pens, notebooks, reading glasses, and portable cd/mp3 players (The program uses digital recordings to increase acess to literacy classes. 

-Part of what we pay to participate in the Literacy Brigade will also help fund more local grassroots community organizing in El Salvador.

For more information on the cost and CISPES as an organization, visit the Cispes website:

http://www.cispes.org/travel-to-el-salvador/delegations/literacy-brigade/

 

Necesitamos 4,000 dolares para ayudar a compensar el costo para los dos llegar y participar. Como estudiantes, no tenemos mucho dinero, por lo que cualquier apoyo ayuda! Las donaciones se destinarán a:

-Avion

-Vivienda

-Suministros tales como: lápices, bolígrafos, cuadernos, gafas de lectura, y reproductores portátiles de CD/MP3 (El programa utiliza las grabaciones digitales para aumentar la restricción de acceso a clases de alfabetización.
para mas informacion visite el sitio de CISPES
http://www.cispes.org/es/travel-to-el-salvador/delegations/literacy-brigade/

The Impact

In El Salvador, 18% of citizens over the of age 15 – 690,000 people - can not read or write, with significantly higher illiteracy rates among women than men. In 2009, the new Ministry of Education began the National Literacy Program with the goal of reducing illiteracy by 4% over 5 years, as a stepping stone towards 0% illiteracy by 2021. In a dramatic departure from previous administration's nominal education investment, the budget for the Literacy Program was increased 10-fold in 2009 – from less than $4 million to $40 million dollars  - to jumpstart this immense national effort. Since then, over 100,000 people have been taught to read and write through 15,000 volunteer-led literacy circles across the nation, using innovative curriculum that relies on both in-person teachers and lessons aired by community radio stations. About 14,000 Salvadoran students and community members have volunteered their time to contribute to this enormous, concerted effort against illiteracy to date.

En El Salvador, 18% de los ciudadanos sobre la edad de 15 – 690.000 personas – no pueden leer ni escribir, con índices más altos para las mujeres que para los hombres.  En el 2009, el nuevo Ministro de Educación comenzó un Programa Nacional de Alfabetización con la meta de reducir el analfabetismo por 4% entre cinco anos, como un paso primero hacia 0% de analfabetismo en el 2021.  Con la nueva orientación del gobierno,  el presupuesto del Programa de Alfabetización ahora es 10 veces más grande que los presupuestos de los gobiernos anteriores, de menos de $4 millones antes de 2009 a $40 millones actualmente -para lanzar este gran esfuerzo nacional.  Desde 2009, más de 100.000 personas han aprendido leer y escribir a través de 15.000 círculos comunitarios dirigidos por voluntarios en muchas zonas del país. Se usa un currículo innovador que depende de clases con maestro/s tal como clases transmitidas por las estaciones de radios comunitarios.  Hasta la fecha, cerca de 14.000 estudiantes universitarios/as s y otros/as miembros de la comunidad han ofrecido su tiempo para contribuir a este esfuerzo enorme contra el analfabetismo.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word and get in touch with your local CISPES chapter.  Any way you can help is highly appreciated! Thank you.

Help spread the word and get in touch with your local CISPES chapter.  Any way you can help is highly appreciated! Thank you.

story:
OUR STORY

Culture City Kids is an edutainment online service for children based on fourteen arts and culture disciplines. 


An online cultural playground for children is the brainchild of Emmy-award winning producer and filmmaker, Opal Comfort. Her dedication to children and the arts will be manifested through her latest project: Culture City Kids. "It's been my life-long dream for children to find confidence by discovering, recognizing and acknowledging their talents through the arts and technology can participate in this mission in a very significant way."

The "Dream Team," working to develop Culture City Kids is made up of Emmy Award-winning former PBS producers, writers and videographers, a composer who has worked for Save the Children, Cirque du Soleil and NAACP, a rising pop artist and a former Disney executive.

The internet service gives children ages 5 through 18 an opportunity to learn about
architecture, dance, design, culinary arts, fashion, film, fine arts, language
arts, literature, music, new media, performing arts, photography and television
by engaging children, parents arts organizations and educators in new and
exciting ways.

WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

The future of arts and culture are in your hands! This is your opportunity to support the arts:

Inspire confidence in children to enjoy, learn and even aspire to work in the world of arts and culture

Provide a platform and audience for young arts and culture students to perform,        demonstrate, discuss and share their talents, experiences and knowledge

Give another choice to children who have made playing internet games wildly popular 

Answer the void and diminishing arts and culture programs in our schools 

Offer an alternative internet activity where both parents and children can participate

 WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET


The online service is designed to inspire young children, showcase emerging artists and recognize both for their participation. The project has completed the research and development stage and is in need of funding to build the elaborate website.

Donor Appreciation Culture City Kids Listings on Website


Silver Circle: $10 -$100= Special Online Thank You Listing

Gold Circle: $100-$500=Special Online Thank You, brick in building of choice

Bronze Circle:$500-$1,000=Special Online Thank You with logo in building of choice

Platinum Circle:$1,000--$5,000=Special Online Thank You with photo in building of choice

                                             $10,000- Special Online Thank You brick video

                                              $25,000- Video Page and building dedication

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

  • contact   www.info@culturecity.com

exciting ways.
WHY YOU SHOULD CAREThe future of arts and culture are in your hands! This is your opportunity to support the arts:
Inspire confidence in children to enjoy, learn and even aspire to work in the world of arts and culture

Provide a platform and audience for young arts and culture students to perform,        demonstrate, discuss and share their talents, experiences and knowledge

Give another choice to children who have made playing internet games wildly popular 

Answer the void and diminishing arts and culture programs in our schools 

Offer an alternative internet activity where both parents and children can participate

 WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GETThe online service is designed to inspire young children, showcase emerging artists and recognize both for their participation. The project has completed the research and development stage and is in need of funding to build the elaborate website.Donor Appreciation Culture City Kids Listings on WebsiteSilver Circle: $10 -$100= Special Online Thank You Listing

Gold Circle: $100-$500=Special Online Thank You, brick in building of choice

Bronze Circle:$500-$1,000=Special Online Thank You with logo in building of choice

Platinum Circle:$1,000--$5,000=Special Online Thank You with photo in building of choice

                                             $10,000- Special Online Thank You brick video
                                              $25,000- Video Page and building dedication

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELPcontact   www.info@culturecity.com

story:
ABOUT THE INITIATIVE

The Arusha Arts Initiative is a group of ten Juilliard-trained artists who believe in the power of change through the arts. Since 2009, the AAI team has offered workshops in Dance, Drama and Music in Arusha, Tanzania each summer. This year, the Initiative is returning to Arusha to conduct arts empowerment workshops at 4 schools in the area including a special needs school and a primary school. 




For more information about our 2012 project and team member biographies, please visit: www.arushaartsinitiative.org.


Arts education encourages creative thinking while developing skills necessary for independent and collaborative work. Our arts workshops offer the opportunity for our students to conceptualize the learning process in a new way that stretches the limits of their personal risk-taking. Our programs strive to develop communication, problem solving and teamwork skills needed in everyday life.


OUR MISSION

 

"Our mission is to empower our students through teaching the performing arts. We strive to use the arts as a vehicle to help our students understand their individuality, their power and their full potential. This empowerment will enable our students to initiate creative and positive change within their community. We aim to engage in a cultural exchange as we share what we know about dance, drama and music."




OUR CAMPAIGN

In years past, a Volunteer Visa through the Tanzanian government cost $120.00 USD per person. This year, the price has been dramatically increased to $500.00 USD per person. This fundraising campaign is specifically designed to cover the cost of our Volunteer Visas for our 2012 Project.


$500 x 10 teaching artists = $5000 USD


For a detailed breakdown of our 2012 budget, please: click here. Please note that this online campaign to cover our Volunteer Visas is only part of our entire 2012 fundraising campaign which includes fundraising events, applications for grants and soliciting private and corporate donations. 


HOW YOU CAN HELP

1) Help us spread awareness about our project! Tell a friend about this campaign and start a conversation about the importance of the arts as a way to foster creativity and compassion in today's youth! Check out the share links on this page.


2) Provide us with guidance and connect us with people who can help us! If you have a great idea- we want to hear it! Please e-mail us at arushaarts@gmail.com. We look forward to hearing from you!


3) DONATE TODAY! Any amount is appreciated. Thank you!

story:
Who are Welcome To My Yard?

Welcome To My Yard is an innovative not for profit social enterprise working with street children and young people in Kathmandu, Nepal, providing holistic community based support, education, training, and income generation programmes. We hope that through our dedication and creative approaches to involve and inspire young people we will have a positive social impact in the community as well as provide an unforgettable experience for our customers through our not for profit business projects.

 

Supporting street children and young people

We are working with a street community of children and young people in Kathmandu Nepal. This community is built up of children, young people and families that either live on the street or have basic shelter and are forced into street life and working. They age from 2-25 both girls and boys.

What we need to start the young people's project?

We need a project work space in the heart of this street community. This will become a safe contact point in which children and young people can come and get to know us, receive support and get into our programme which helps them with work experience, vocational training and education opportunities. The project space will run the innovative bite size workshops, kids clubs and young people's groups and provide a place for our key workers to provide emotional support 1:1 with young people.

The Art Space

As part of our strengths based work and encouraging children and young people's creativity, we want to dedicate entire walls of our building just for them. Young people as individuals or groups will have the opportunity to use this space to express themselves in any way they like; murals, photographs, paintings and more! We will then exhibit their work for 2-3 months and invite local people and tourists to come and see what they have created. Then, we will white wash and start all over again! We will encourage local art students and artists to come and work with the children and young people to hone their skills and develop their abilities to put their imaginations into colour and materials.

What will your funds cover?

Your funds will pay for the project space and bills for one year; provide basic equipment for the office, purchase art materials and provide lighting for the art space. We need to keep fundraising in order to fulfill all the aspects of the project we need, but these funds will enable us to get running! If we raise over this amount  we will put it towards other items needed for the project such as resources and much needed basic salaries for team.  


::DON'T FORGET:: you don't need to be alone in getting together your donation. As we are a UK registered Community Interest Company you are perfectly entitled to get together with a group of friends or colleagues and do a fun fundraising event or activity to raise the donation as a group!:: See our website for some ideas of what you could do.

Want to find our more?

You can see what we have been up to with the young people so far such as our indoor rock climbing programme, street children photography book and see how we have funded young people already into education or vocational training.

Check out our website www.welcometomyyard.com, go to our Facebook Page  'Welcome to My Yard' or drop us an email at contact@welcometomyyard.com and we would be happy to answer any questions you have about what we are doing.

story:
The Project

Greetings and thank you for taking the time to look at my campaign! First some background, I have been teaching yoga and meditation here in Madison since 2004 and have been an avid student and practitioner since 1999.  I have taught to a broad range of individuals, from kids to police officers to pregnant mothers, and in a variety of settings, such as hospitals, colleges, and studios. My enthusiasm for yoga's (from here used to connote meditation as well) effects on health and overall wellbeing only grows.  There is a lot of yoga available today, more than at any time in its 5000 year history, and in this country the focus tends to be on increasing strength and flexibility. But let's be clear, whereas I love the freedom in my back when I'm regularly opening my hamstrings, my passion surrounds the larger picture of what yoga can offer--how to make one's life better irrespective of how flexible you are or how old you are.  If you can breathe, you can do yoga. As a system, yoga has lots of techniques, some body oriented and some not, to increase energy, mental clarity and stability, and to connect with our heart's longing for a life that is meaningful and reflects our unique talents.  This is the yoga I am committed to sharing.  In 2007 I met my teacher, Rod Stryker of ParaYoga, who has condensed the best of yoga into a system that makes this greater scope accessible to the modern individual and in terms that are relevant to our times, without losing any of yoga's original integrity.  ParaYoga specializes in working with people one on one, which is how most of yoga has been imparted throughout its history. By crafting a personal practice that takes into account the current conditions and circumstances of the individual and then matching what techniques best suit his/her desired outcome, yoga's sophistication as a holistic tool for healing and positive development is fully utilized. Whether the desired outcome is better rest, support and growth through a tough time (such as divorce, addiction recovery, or job loss), or spiritual deepening, yoga can address any of this- more than health in just physical terms.  My understanding as a student and skill set as a teacher of this vast science has grown immensely since studying ParaYoga.

So this is where the project comes to life.  In January there is an event in India, called the Kumbha Mela, which for millenia takes place every 12 years. It is the largest gathering of yogi's on the planet (as well as folks of many spiritual paths and traditions) and is a super conference of sorts for deepening personal practice and learning from the high caliber of teachers present who have much to share regarding yoga techniques and philosophy and the wisdom on how to best incorporate this information for accelerated growth.  My teacher and his teacher, Pandit Rajmani Tigunait, of the Pennsylvania based Himalayan Institute are hosting a three week trip to India in Allahabad, site of the Himalayan Institute's Indian campus, and 2 miles from the epicenter of the Kumbha Mela.  I will be joining many dedicated students and sharing in the opportunity to learn from and accompany these two masters to the home of these teachings.  

For me this trip is an extraordinary opportunity to walk the land where these teachings came to life, to glean from the knowledge and wisdom of these two renowned teachers, deepen my practice, and expand my understanding of yoga. My ultimate intention in all of this is to then bring this knowledge home to better serve my students and my community.  There are moments in life when the invitation to step out of the day to day reality and be a part of something much larger than ourselves comes.  This moment has arrived and I don't want to miss it!

I raise two young girls with my husband and what I make from teaching yoga is enough for our household needs, but not for this epic excursion.  I am asking for support from friends, family, and the greater community the make my dream a reality without sinking my family into debt.

What I Need & What You Get

This is a tall order I realize, and $5000 is no small change.  This is the cost of the excursion that is being offered by the Himalayan Institute of which my teacher is affilliated. Specifically this covers:

  • Airfare getting to and from India
  • The three weeks of lodging at the Himalayan Institute's Allahabad campus and HI lodging in Khajuraho 
  • The food being served at both of these locations 

Any funding that exceeds the $5000 (a girl can dream!!) will go towards spreading the best of yoga here at home by updating my website, creating fresh marketing materials, and all the business stuff that goes into this line of work.

I'm not asking for handouts here and have a great many perks to offer if you choose to take advantage, so take a look.  By the way, I also work as a photographer (and plan to document my travels to Kumbha Mela) so if you're into supporting me but are not keen on practicing yoga, there are some photography perks that may appeal to you.  If you live outside of the Southern Wisconsin region but would like to work together through one on one yoga guidance, I serve clients through phone/Skype consultations and video record practices and share via YouTube.  Anyone from my homeland of Michigan- we can arrange to meet next time I'm there visiting family.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the means to contribute, you can still help! The success of all of these home grown campaigns depends on word of mouth. Talking about this project and sharing the link via facebook and e-mail is a huge source of support for me and you have my utmost gratitude for spreading the word.  Thank you!!!

story:
Why Gardens?
Because gardens produce healthier food. Only 2% of American children eat enough fruits and vegetables, and 1 in 3 American children born after 2000 is at risk for Type II diabetes. A garden is an introduction to the real, healthy food students and families need access to.

Because gardens can help fix America's nature deficit. With more than 80% of Americans living in cities and suburbs, we need to work harder than ever to teach the values of natural processes.

Because gardens are a living laboratory for education. Not just healthy food—a lesson on what producing healthy food requires. Not just exposure to nature—a way for children to literally harvest the fruits of their labor.

A True Seed Investment
For as little as $10, you can help a community reap all the benefits a garden has to offer. In just 39 days, we plan to raise $2500 per garden; to feed,  teach, and inspire people in each of these 100 communities. Here are a few things our garden plans to do with your donations:

Last year, three garden beds were constructed, planted and tended last year at Gardiner Regional Middle School into a 4-acre wooded trail system by a newly established and enthusiastic student Garden Club. Although the garden’s rustic setting -- with the beds nestled among the trees and the brush -- is beautiful, it has also turned out to be impractical: the garden is over 500 feet from the school building, where there is no water source, no space for expansion, no protection from crop damage by wild animals, no visibility from the school and, in the summer months, an insect infestation made it impossible to stand in the garden for more than five minutes without being coated in bug bites. It became clear that the existing beds need to be moved closer to the school in order to create a manageable, expandable and sustainable garden project.

The move will greatly enhance students exposure to the garden, and make it an accessible resource for hands-on learning across all grades and subjects. The new site will be located within striking distance of the cafeteria doors, helping to spatially connect the concepts of growing food, eating food, and enjoying food. Help us grow this unruly garden into an edible schoolyard!

CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR IMAGES & VIDEOS

Look Good, Do Good
With every contribution to our garden, donors will receive organic, ethical perks from PACT. Our socks, undies, and t-shirts are produced to high standards of sustainability, with the comfiest organic materials we can find. You'll be giving out of the goodness of your heart, and in return you'll get PACT goodies. It's a win-win situation.

story:
If your mother, grandfather or son lost their home to a natural disaster, what would you do?

Across the country, thousands of individuals have lost their home due to natural disasters. Together, we can bring relief. 

Hurricane Katrina:

  • Date of event: August 29, 2005
  • Area Impacted: Gulf Coast from Florida to Texas covering over 90,000 square miles.
  • Number of Houses Destroyed: 275,000
  • Number of Deaths: 1833
  • Number of people impacted: 1.2 million

Joplin E5 Tornado:

  • Date of event: May 22, 2011
  • Area Impacted: Six miles long by 1 mile wide tornado touched down in east of the Kansas state line travelling through Jasper and Newton Counties in Missouri.
  • Number of Houses Destroyed: 7,500
  • Number of Deaths: 161
  • Number of people impacted: 50,000+

Hurricane Sandy:

  • Date of event: October 22-29, 2012
  • Area Impacted: Eeast coast from the Carolina’s all the way to Maine, for a total of 24 impacted States. Of the states affected, New York and New Jersey were hit the most severely. The storm itself measured, at its widest, 1,100 miles wide.
  • Number of Houses Destroyed:
    • New York: 305,000 housing units damaged or destroyed
    • New Jersey: 72,000 housing units damaged or destroyed
  • Number of Deaths: 159 direct and indirect deaths
  • Number of people impacted: Incalculable

 

How you can help:

  • Contribute. Treat yourself to one of our great perks! More importantly, you’ll become a part of changing the lives of three families in three communities. Plus, your contibution is tax deductible!
    • $5 = A box of nails
    • $10 = A smoke alarm
    • $25 = Shelving for a closet
    • $50 = An interior door
    • $100 = Paint for two bedrooms
    • $250 = A bathtub and shower fixture
    • $500 = Flooring for two rooms
    • $1,000 = Kitchen appliances
    • $5,000 = Materials for a new roof
  • Share. Tell your friends. Your loved ones. Your coworkers. Post this link on Facebook, tweet about us. 
  • Ride. If you’re interested in investing yourself even more, consider getting on a bike and joining us in Joplin. Visit jomonola.org for more details!

100% OF PROCEEDS WILL BE USED TO REBUILD HOMES IN NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY, NEW ORLEANS AND JOPLIN.

story:
Greetings!

Midwifery is a deep calling not only to support women through pregnancy and birth, but to help them realize their own strength and natural ability to partake in one of the most rewarding, sacred and meaningful moments of their lives. 

 

The Florida School of Traditional Midwifery, one of only ten accredited Direct Entry Midwifery Schools in the United States, is committed to providing quality educational programs for those who share our desire to provide the best care for childbearing women and their families.  Graduates of our midwifery program are eligible to become Florida Licensed Midwives and Certified Professional Midwives.

 

Emphasis is placed on teaching the art of out-of hospital birth, differentiating between low-risk and high-risk pregnancies and preparing students to organize, operate and promote their practices after licensing.  Along with the rigorous hard science classes our students must take, they also are on-call with midwives in clinical sites in their local communities. It is here that they get to assist with prenatals, observe births, postpartum care and obtain their “hands on” experience.

 

Here are some of the comments we have heard from our senior students.

“I have not yet had the privilege of becoming a mom, but today I felt like my heart would burst with pride as I witnessed a new mom spread her wings and fly, so to speak, into her new role as mother with excellence. As women make their journeys into motherhood I get to walk with them and when they get to the point of saying “thank you for your help; I got this from now on” I am both ecstatic and sad, as it is a sort of goodbye. Continuity of care (prenatal visits, the birth, and postpartum visits) is something I love about midwifery. I love building relationships with these families, watching “my babies” grow, and welcoming new siblings for them."

Peachy Sloan – Ormond Beach, Florida

 

“My number 36 baby caught by Dad and myself weighing 9lbs 6oz looking absolutely adorable! I LOVE MY JOB TO BE!”

Jessica Baynes – Tallahassee, Florida

 

“I have to reach the number 50 for my numbers for school, but honestly it’s so much more than that. To the 50 families who got counted, thank you. To the 25 observes who got counted, thank you. To the many births I’ve attended that for one reason or another didn’t get counted, thank you. To the hundreds of bellies I’ve touched, heart tones I’ve listened to, and friends I’ve made, thank you. Thank you to all the mamas who let me in, taught me something, and allowed to be a part of their very special moments.”

Allison Lynum – Delray Beach, Florida

 

There is such love, respect, commitment, patience, wisdom and knowledge that midwifery students demonstrate daily. We are so proud of them.    

 

We hope that you will partner with us and donate now!   As a nonprofit organization, we rely on the support of donors to assist us with upgrading our teaching lab, providing scholarships, and offering students emergency funds in times of need. This year we are implementing new software to upgrade our paperwork systems for billing, registration, grades, and transcripts. We are also planning improvements to our historic building and upgrades for our IT infrastructure, website, and social media. Improvements like these will enable our school to run more efficiently.

 

Please repost this campaign on your Facebook page and send out the link to your email lists.

 

The more Licensed and Certified Professional Midwives there are in the world, the more low risk pregnant women are able to receive full attention during their pregnancies, more babies being brought into this world in a peaceful setting, and more families benefitting from the skillful hands of midwives.
